text: Dark brown beer with a tan head. Strong aromas of dark coffee. Tastes of dark coffee, burnt wheat, charred notes, and some earth. Bitter coffee finish. A bit one dimensional and too heavy handed on the dark coffee. Decent.
Rich coffee aroma youd expect from a big stout. Pours almost black brown. Taste is bright hops and coffee. Finishes light. Really good.

Pours brown with an off white head. The aroma has coffee, nuttiness and toasted malt. It has a nice medium body. The taste is quite coffee, but balanced just enough with the toasted malt. Very clean coffee like cold brew. Really tasty.

16 oz can shared with ebone1988 for the book. The pour is a dirtier dark brown color with a thicker khaki colored head and a couple spots of lace as it falls down to a thin ring. The aroma is very green peppery. The coffee on it is sharp and acidic. There is a malty sweetness to it and a that acidity. The green pepper is huge. The flavor is much of the same. The pepper doesnt do it for me. I thought this should fade with time, but damn. The mouth feel is a little more watery and thin with a decent carbonation and a sharp acidic coffee and pepper on the finish. Not really my jam.

Can shared with koleminer20. For the book. Aroma is green peppers, coffee, bitter roasted malt, nutty, eh. Appearance is brown, light tan head, slightly hazy. Taste is green pepper, coffee, nutty, roasted malt, probably past its prime. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light carbonation, peppery coffee aftertaste. Overall, Im not a huge fan but would like another shot at it one day fresher.

Can. Murky reddish brown color. Off white foamy head. Big coffee ground aroma. Fresh beans. Coffee bean flavor. Bitterness apparent. Dark malts, chocolate, coffee ground. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can. Pours black with a small beige head. Intense roasted coffee aroma. Big roasted malt flavor with this and dominant coffee notes. Full bodied and tastes almost like drinking coffee. Excellent.
Tap at new bohemia in uptown with samadueche. Brown black with small white head. Coffee aroma. Rich flavor of malt, coffee, smooth finish. Good.

Pours a reddish brown color with a bready light canvas colored head. Notes of chocolate coffee ice cream, fresh ground beans, and cookies. Really good. Made some car bombs later in the day with this as well.

Type: 16-oz. can
Glass: Clear 14.75-oz. porter/stout glass
From: My cousin, Sam

Thanks, Sam!

Had been wanting to try this one for a long time and was lucky enough to get a can from Sam. Big Surly fan and big coffee beer fan. Looking back I gave Bender a 3.88 back in the summer of 2011 but I was just starting my reviewing process then. Have some high hopes here.

Poured a dark-to-light black brown color with two fingers of khaki tan frothy head. Could see a few bubbles coming up from the bottom of the glass. Bad watery spotty lacing. Poor retention. (Sight - 2.50)

Smelled bitter coffee beans, roasty malts, bitter dark chocolate, espresso, slight char wood, burnt molasses and ashtray. For the style and type of beer, nailed it. (Smell - 4.50)

Taste followed the nose almost exactly. Probably had this a tad too cold. Got roasted bitter coffee malts, dark espresso, mocha, char wood, ashtray, burnt molasses, licorice, toasted toffee and hints or dark caramel. (Taste - 4.50)

Medium body. Oily-to-creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, bitter, roasty finish. (Feel - 4.25)

Loved this one. No hiding it and a great name. I really need to start drinking coffee. (Overall - 4.50)

4.36 97 A
Black as night strong roasted coffee aroma and flavor not a coffee beer guy but this one is great.
Old rating from CBC 2014. Beer in the glass dark brown, nice head. Fine malty-coffee aroma. Starts mild malty, fine notes of coffee, dry malty, not too intense. Earthy dry-malty finish. Not bad!

16 Fl. Oz. Can. Pours clear, dark brown with about a two finger tan head, that left lots of lacing. Aroma is COFFEE, roasty coffee, some malts and some spices. Taste is also COFFEE, smooth cold brewed coffee, malty, some spices. Extremely good.

Can. Aroma of coffee and chocolate malts. Medium sweet taste up front with that roasty flavor. Medium body, very smooth. Some bitter coffee flavor in the finish mixes well with the sweet malts. Overall very good.

Pint can. Very nice iced coffee aroma! Dark nut brown color, clear, with thick white head that dissipates pretty quickly. Smooth flavor, coffee, light bitterness. Body is a little thin. Overall, it is a very nice tasting coffee. Good brown ale base with awesome coffee flavor.

Intense coffee, dark roast filter, dark toasted malts. Clear, dark brown, medium, creamy, off-white head. Light bitter. Some sweet, dark, toasted malts coming up, coffee, chocolate, soft carbonation. Nice Coffee Brown Ale, Keg at the brewery, Minneapolis.

On tap at Deadwood winery with Erica, Chris and Patty. Black color. Off white head, quickly receding. Aromas: sweet coffee, mocha, light coffee-sourness, fruity. Flavor is moderate sweet, roasted, light coffee sourness. Light to medium bodied. Very good.
Can. Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are lots of coffee, some nuttiness, and creamy.

16 oz can. Pours clear light ruby brown with a medium frothy light tan head that retains fairly well and leaves little lacing.

The aroma is sweet chocolate malt and roast coffee.

The flavor is a lot of roast with some sweet nutty chocolate malt and a lot of roast coffee. The mouthfeel is medium bodied and a little thin.

Overall, a nice coffee beer.
Pretty great coffee, intense but not overwhelming coffee. Creamy body. Nice all around.

If youve seen the other reviews youll know that has a really strong coffee taste. Not in a bad way but pretty intense dark flavor. I like that it comes in pint cans. A couple of these are really nice with a meal or just sipping. Im not a coffee drinker at all but this one is pretty tasty.
Intense coffee bomb. Not much else. Sone malt and light roast. Black pour with decent head and lacing. Ligh caramel in finish. Tap at Churchkey.

Can.

A- Sauteed vegetables, earthy coffee, roasty.

A- Dark brown color, dark liquid, beige head.

T- Coffee, bell peppers, earthy, slightly bitter.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, strong finish.

O- A pretty good brown ale. Wish the coffee would have been a sweeter type of coffee instead of a vegetal/earthy kind of coffee. Either was it was good, but maybe not the best.

Encore merci à Stéphane pour le partage de cette bière qui fait suite à la version originale de la Bender. Ohhhh que ça ne va pas bien... Encore le même look ordinaire. Nez de café froid, de cendrier, de vieux percolateur et de tuyaux de cafetière remplis dhuile de café mal lavé. Même histoire en bouche que la version originale: sèche mais sucrée, courte suite à une attaque franche de mauvais café. Les Bender sont dans le top 50. Ça ne va pas...
Wow. Just a ton of coffee here. Actually not so over the top, but you are rooting for other flavours around the press. Has a certain creaminess, especially in the finish.
Sample from can. Pours dark brown, tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee, nutty and malty. Taste was semi sweet, roasted coffee.

Surly didnt invent the coffee-infused Brown Ale, but Ill damned if they havent brewed the best one Ive tasted. Dark brown pour and tan suds. Huge, gorgeous cold-brewed coffee smells. Flavors of rich grains, coffee-style fruitiness, caramel, and creamy coffee tastes and textures like mocha/cappuccino. Theres also a bright, roasty sensation. This beer gave me a hard-on thats unlikely to go down anytime soon.

25 Apr 2016, can. brown/ruby. nose is coffee with cream, mostly dark roast but slightly sweet. Thin body and moderately fizzy. lots of burnt malt, mild dark coffee. nose is much more creamy cappuccino than actually comes out in the taste. Ok.
pour brown with a tan head. lots of coffee aroma with caramel notes. light bitter light sweet taste. medium bodied, with average carbonation.

Tap. Pours clear deep brown with a medium sized, creamy, beige head that leaves a fair lacing. Aroma of caramel, slightly roasted malt, coffee nuts and breaddy notes. Sweet flavor that end up more dry and quite bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. An excellent Brown. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar Aarhus. Pours reddish brown with a medium offwhite head.
Lots of coffee, light earthiness, roasty, bitter, chocolate, cocoa, light fruity.
Taste is roasty, coffee, bitter, cocoa, light citrussy. Delicious!
Tap @ Mikkeller bar, Aarhus. Clear dark brown pour with a generous head. Tons of coffee on the nose and taste, caramel, vanilla, roast, more coffee and some sweet malts. I like coffee! Nice!

From Tap: Reddish dark-brown with off-white head, aroma is fresh roasted coffee, iced-coffee, tastes liked iced-coffee with some malty sweetness, milky mouthfeel, soft carbonation, great if you like coffee

Lata. @Mikkeller Bar (Barcelona). 05/03/2016 Canned on: 07/02/15
Color marrón, sabor maltoso, predominio del cafe, cuerpo medio, agradable.
Big damn can. Pours brown with a huge nose of coffee and some roastiness. Flavors are the same with a big coffee taste. Very drinkable and delicious.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
COD 11/20/15. Pours a rich dark brown, almost as dark as a stout. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

World class nose of rich coffee - fresh brewed medium roast that is not stale or over roasted. Underneath is a mere hint of chocolate malt.

Light body that is smooth. Superb carbonation that delivers a fair burst of effervescence in the middle and a strong prickly punch in the finish.

The taste profile is not complex but is quite outstanding. It delivers what it was designed to do, rich iced coffee flavor over a subtle malt base. As stated, this is coffee forward but it is also perfectly balanced. Coffee flows throughout the tasting experience with the middle being the transition point for the other flavors. Here, a very mild roast like bitterness emerges that is buttressed by subtle notes of caramel and chocolate. These flavors persist throughout the slowing fading finish.

Can to tulip. Brown with a average beige head that leaves nice lacing as it shrinks. Aroma is coffee, hazelnut, cream, and a little chocolate. Flavor is coffee, roasted malts, toffee, and hazelnut. Light bodied and a slight dry finish. Nice beer.

Do you like coffee? If the answer is no, avoid this because that is all this tastes like. I do like coffee myself and the coffee this beer tastes like is very good coffee so Im into it. I guess I can kind of criticize it for being one dimensional but that seems to be so obviously the point that its hardly a negative. It is very nice, bold, roasty coffee beverage that gets you drunk at a reasonable clip. There are many worse things to drink in this universe, let me tell you.

Surly főzetet elcsípni sem a legunalmasabb dolgok közé tartozik, amit egy sörissza elképzelhet magának, ez esetben pedig kávéval főzött sörről van szó, az élénkítő hatás tehát már csak emiatt is garantált. Ez utóbbi tulajdonságát kár is lenne tagadnia, az őrölt, pörkölt kávé jelenléte ugyanis ott munkálkodik mind színében - mely a fény felé tartva azért borostyán árnyalatokat is megcsillant -, mind illatában, ami bármely kereskedelmi forgalomban kapható kávé tasakjában megállná a helyét. Pörkölt, világos földes aromáit természetesen eszpresszós zamatok követik, ahogyan arra az alkoholtartalom tudatában számítani is lehet, könnyed, kevésbé testes, cseppet vizes és átérezhetően pörkölt malátás szerkezetben. A lecsengése kiegyensúlyozott, hosszú utóízt produkáló. Kávés sört inni, de még inkább készíteni manapság nem nagy kunszt, a Surly főzete azonban valószínűleg példaképpen szolgálhat egy efféle mezőny számára.

Can. Pours Dark Amber with a thin tan head. Aroma is Coffee and Toffee. Taste is Coffee, Malt, Toffee with a coffee finish. I think its excellent. Kind of reminds me of a iced toffee coffee. Caution a lot of coffee in this one!

If this beer were more affordable and available in New Mexico, it might be the only beer I drink. I love the light body and the explosion of coffee flavor. I have to ration myself when Im able to get my hands on a four pack. Itd be pretty easy to drink the whole thing in one night.

Sampled from a 1 pint can purchased at Macy's on State Street in Chicago. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Smells like coffee, tastes like coffee. Very good if you like coffee, which I do. Hints of ash, brown sugar, vanilla and milk. Very lightly bitter finish. Quite drinkable, but a little lacking in bitterness.

A 16 fl oz can canned on 2nd July 2015 and poured into a Duvel tulip glass. It poured a clear dark brown colour much like a French pressed coffee. There was a one finger tanned head that dissipated quickly but leaves some nice stringy lacing. Aromas were like a fresh brewed cup of coffee from freshly grounded coffee beans with a hint of vanilla and brown sugar. Tastes of roasted coffee, coffee grounds followed by some nuttyness with a hint of milk and vanilla. Creamy, medium bodied with medium carbonation. Overall a very good brown ale with nice coffee flavours. Very easy to drink especially if you like coffee.

0,5l can at home courtesy of Saeglopur, big thanks. Canned 07/02/2015. almost black color, small coffee-colored head. smells of coffee, coffee grounds, roast, bitter herbs, nettle, ash, spices. nice smell. medium body, soft rather light carbonation, light mouthfeel. tastes of coffee, light charcoal, bitter herbs, nettle, roast, coffee grounds, some resin & light pines towards the finish. finishes nicely with light roast & light coffee, nettle and with a light fruitiness. good stuff, in the middle (between start and finish) the taste looses a bit, might be a issue of freshness, but overall quite nice beer, would drink again.

Pours a dark brown with a nice beige head, good lacing. Aroma is old, stale bitter coffee. Thats the best kind. Taste matches aroma. Overall, this is a really thin, watery beer and I enjoyed every drop of it. If I was young enough to enjoy pitching a tent on a lake, river of stream, this would be the ultimate early morning waker upper! Good stuff!

From a tall boy to a glass...pours rich brown with minimal head. Nose and initial taste is COFFEE, COFFEE, and a tad bit more Coffee...hard to this flavorful beer a brown ale...which are renown for being Stouts and even Porters blah relative.

Love it....another great part of winter!
Caoba oscuro, espuma beis ligera. Aromas de café expreso. Cuerpo medio, inició maltoso y sabor intenso de café.
Pours a deep brown. Aroma is of fresh brewed coffee. Taste is moldly bitter. Slightly oily, not to heavy, lightly bitter on yhe finish. Overall, loved this beer, it would pair perfect with dessert.

Taste: smooth coffee cocoa, toffee, toasted dry malts.
Dark brown and mostly clear.
creamy coffee sweet aroma.
medium body, refined head, some lace.
50cl bottle from mikkeller webshop. Dark red brown color. Thin to medium beige head. Body is medium. Taste is light sweet, medium bitter. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, cacao, roasted, dried fruits.
Deep dark brown pour with a beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is strong dark roasted coffee beans. Taste is bitter black coffee and nutty with some caramel in the finish. Light body.

can poured into a snifter..dark brown with a fluffy off-white head..aroma of coffee,coffee and more coffee..tastes like..coffee...with some roasted nuts,
smokiness..good stuff.

On tap at Simones. Nice chocolate colored head, dark coke colored body. Really nice nose, coffee with smoke and liquor. Great flavor, in line with the nose. Could use a little more body on the palate. Overall, very good. Would drink again.

Mild coffee aroma, with a hint of chocolate malt. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a full light tan head. Not really as much coffee flavor as I was expecting, it comes through just a bit at the finish. Theres a touch of sweet malt, then mild coffee, fading to a light roast finish. Medium bodied, so its easy to drink. I prefer my coffee beers with a bit more coffee in them.

500 ml canned on 07/02/15, from Mikkeller Webshop.
Dark brown, a bit copperish body, with a medium, creamy, lacing, dark beige head.
Aroma with a lot of distinctive coffee beans, espresso, cocoa, dark chocolate, subtle dark fruits.
Taste follows this, coffee-forward, with the typical Brown Ale notes far in the background.
Medium, creamy mouthfeel, with a quite lively carbonation.
Finishes dry, roasty, mainly with coffee.

Very nice. Lovely, direct coffee notes, otherwise not so much else tasteable. Drinks pretty easy, with a pleasant dryness. Overall quite one-dimensional and not among my favourite Brown Ales, but still enjoyable stuff for coffee lovers like me.
Pours a slightly brown shade of black with a slight brown head. Aroma is coffee, liquorice, roasty. Taste is coffee, roast malts, slightly earthy, slight liquorice and a touch of leather.

Can. Clear, dark red brown, tiny offwhite head. Sweet coffee aroma, hints of chocolate. Flavour has freshly brewed coffee, notes of roasted malt, some kind of coffee-candy I once had... Sweetish with ok bitterness. Well, not bad but the candy-coffee-like flavour disturbs me.
Can.Dark brown colour with small head.Aroma of coffee amd malt,flavor of roasted malt and ashtray,also nots of cocoa and some bitterness,medium body and toasted finish.
Can. Pours dark brown with beige head. Aroma coffe, caramel, malts, nutty, hops. Taste is very sweet, coffe, Hazel, quite bitter hops. Slot of coffe. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2015 Can - Thanks Martin! Aroma is heavy on coffee, toffee, roasted nuts and and sweet candy-like aroma. Taste is bitter, heavy on the coffee (too heavy?), dry, roasted malts and a bitter finish. I hate brown ale, this didn't change my mind.

Murky medium brown with a soft ringed head and no discernable lacing. Nose is bright with the wrench of stale cafetiere, kinda nutty and mostly cocoa choc chalkiness. Initial taste is smooth and lean with the bean. Rich damp bark woodiness comes billowing through and a fleshy bitterness. Palate is a massage of maltiness with a wee carbed heel kick. Chewy orangey choc finish and a decent wrench of a rinsed out coffee mug. Cold press all the way, would like to stack this against the original. Keg, Hanging Bat, post Rainbow Daying
Keg at the hanging bat. Pours black, nose is roasted coffee, chocolate, mocha, taste is dry, bitter, mocha flavour.

Can. Beautiful brown. Coffee aroma. Tastes almost like one of those small cans of iced doubleshot espressos. Pecan and acidic aftertaste. Delicious. It would be interesting if they did variants of this with different types of coffee. Thx Maltser85.

Brown with an off white head. LOADS of coffee in the aroma, ice coffee. Palate is all about coffee, some slight hint of roast, hops, nice bitterness in the finish that balances the coffee. One of the best brown ales in the world.

A-like a root beer with head
S-coffee, fresh roasted.
T-so much like an iced coffee that it fit the brewers description perfectly. It put a smile on my face.
O-the only thing that holds this beer back is that it taste more like iced coffee than beer. But it is still amazing

Hm, nice coffee ale with some brown characteristics. Fresh coffee, some caramel, toffee, cocoa in the aroma. Flavors similar to nose, fairly dry, good balance between tang, bitter, and the other qualities. Very drinkable.

Pours dark brown with a nice khaki head. Head retention is good. AROMA: malty, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, earthy, alcohol, herbs, roasty, nuts, smoke, spices, brown sugar, molasses, clove, mellow herbal hops and slight peppercorn. TASTE: malty, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, nuts, alcohol, brown sugar, molasses, earthy, smoke, hop spice, herbs, roasty, peppercorn, fizzy, spices and very slight vanilla. AFTER TASTE: bitter coffee, smoke, roasted malt and spices with a oily medium finish.

Coffee, coffee, coffee -- as in aroma, taste (acidic but just lightly bitter) and finish. There is sweetness in the taste and aftertaste, too, as the brown ale base is discernible. But this is really mostly coffee. Note to self: Take along a few cans to a tailgate party for a noontime football game this fall. It could be even more tasty.

16 oz can, shared @ In De Wildeman. Black color. Off white head, quickly receding. Aromas: sweet coffee, mocha, light coffee-sourness, fruity. Retronasal theres more roast, mocha. Flavor is moderate sweet, roasted, light coffee sourness. Light to medium bodied. Even though this was already past the BB date, it still held up pretty nicely.

From tap. Dark brown color with beige head. Roasted malty aroma, coffee, dusty cold instant coffee, light chocolate, caramel. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Light to medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Poured coffee to caramel in color with a strong nose of coffee, caramel, and chocolate. Palate is oily in a way a good cup of coffee is, that clings pleasantly. Taste is straightforward coffee, chocolate, and a little bit of caramel with a surprising hop/citrus note that is right in the middle of the taste. If you like coffee or need an excuse to drink beer in the morning this is a great beer...tastes like another!
Can. Sad to say that Superspak has not had this one. So nothing fun to quote on this rating. That makes me a sad panda.

Straightforward and content with its identity, this is all black Folgers morning coffee and toffee malt. Strong roasted flavors, some hops lingers, a bit thin on the backbone and very one-dimensional, but easy drinking in the morning.

This beer is our regular Bender beer with a cold-press coffee-brewing process. We steep 20 gallons at a time, so this beer will pop up at Tours, beer fests and special tappings. The coffee is roasted locally at Coffee & Tea Limited in Linden Hills.

16 oz can into a pint glass, from Hy-Vee Wine & Spirits in downtown Muscatine. Brown/black appearance with a lacy, light brown head. Aroma of strong coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts and light earthy notes. Similar flavor with a medium body. Pretty damn good.

Brune aux allures de coca (reflets rubis pour être gentil). Le col de mousse est mince, leffervescence est faible. Le nez présente un café froid légèrement fumé. En bouche, le café est plutôt cendré. La bière est relativement mince et la finale est plus terreuse.

From a can into a snifter. Large beige head with medium bubbles, mostly opaque dark brown body. Nice full coffee aroma, some mocha, smells exactly like coffee ground that have been left in a percolator overnight, hints of barley. Creamy medium body, soft carbonation, oily, medium sweetness, moderate to low bitterness on the finish. Some smoke on the finish with more coffee and hints of toffee. Different and enjoyable.
Can. Basically cold, carbonated coffee. So thin. Low boost. Waste of time. Wouldnt drink again.
Pour is a black with a small tan head. Aroma is espresso coffee with a large creamy richness. flavor is a nice coffee with an almost rich roasted nut. Finish is full of coffee and nice dark roast.

Can at home. Pours a dark brown, almost black. Nice thick white head. Aroma is coffee coffee coffee. Wow. Probably the most coffee aroma Ive smelled in a beer. Nice! Taste is coffee, with a bit of cream, slight sweetness and a mild bitterness. Medium body, medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. This is like a nice boozy glass of cold brew coffee. Mmm.
16oz can pours s dark brown color with a bit of head. Loads of coffee in this. Some faint roasted malt flavor coming through, but otherwise this is just a glass of cold coffee.

16oz can poured into a coffee mug. The aroma is a mild and smooth coffee with some woody spices. It pours a rich, dark caramel color with an off-white, dense filmy head that has a moderate retention. The taste is a medium, balanced bittersweet. The texture is oily and creamy with a fuzzy carbonation and a medium body. Flavors of coffee, chocolate, earth, and nuts blend nicely on the palate with a finish thats earthy, but smooth with a tinny quality and flavors of pecans. The aftertaste is light with a flavor profile of spice and tin, but mostly clean.

Pours a dark brown colour with a nice tan head. Aroma is distinctly of coffee with a slight malt undertone. Taste is mildly sweet but mostly dry and quite malty with no real bitterness to speak of. Medium body, light carbonation, smooth and slightly creamy on the palate. Really enjoyable brew, highly recommended.
Draft - espresso nose. Sip adds roast and slight grounds. Light considering the strong nose. Light sweet finish.
Very dark amber huge with a good looking tan head. Smells of metallic notes and coffee. Taste is strong coffee with some malt and hops. A little thin and fizzy. Overall good beer.
Clear mahogany, dark brown, light tan. Big coffee nose (obviously), dark roasted malts. Some bitterness, but not much in the way of sweetness. Light body, good amount of carb, shorter finish. Good.
Pours black with small tan head. Aroma is coffee, lots of it. Fairly light body, nice creamy texture. Lots of fresh coffee and dark roasty malts. Pretty normal stuff but very good.
Deep brown in color. Strong coffee aroma. Light bodied with a coffee strength in the flavor.

Sampled at ESBLS. Dark brown with a lot of amber. Minimal head. Lots of coffee in the aroma. That dominates the flavor, too. Dry and very roasted. Again, coffee. A little grass under that. Pretty good stuff.

Black with ruby highlights when held up to light, small head. Sweet mocha aroma. Taste is sweet coffee, chocolate and caramel with light roasted malt and some hop bitterness that provides balance. Very smooth and pleasant tasting. Very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

can pour at home, thanks Andrew for picking this one up really awesome trying this one. you can pretty much sum this up in one way, "cup of joe in the morning, that is what this is, so much coffee, personally i love it.

16 oz can poured a couple times recently, and this beer just keeps getting better and better. Pours a cloudy muddy brown color with a huge black coffee grounds aroma. Flavor is coffee up front, as expected. This beer is heavier on coffee than any other beer I can think of. Good thing I love coffee. If you do, you will absolutely love this beer. Espresso flavor will stick around for the better part of the evening. This beer seems like it would be fantastic at about 7 A.M. Not that Im gonna go do that, but this beer is so coffee centered, it would go quite appealing. Another incredible beer from these guys. Loved it.

Reminiscent of your first newborn, that heavy aroma of coffee in the waiting room air. Big, juicy malt balanced by a tiny cut of hop bitterness. Hop fruitiness is nice and tames the huge coffee flavor. This is incredible 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can, thanks to Andrew! Pours a mostly clear darker brown color with a moderate pillowy tan head on there. Nose is heavy on the coffee and roasting, with just a hint of bread underneath. Taste has a nice little coffee bite to it with some bitterness, and a dry toasty finish. Really nice drink.
Aroma is coffee, malts, chocolate and earth. The flavor is coffee, mocha/chocolate, mild nuttiness, dark malts and a mix of slight hops and acidity in the finish.

Dark garnet brown pour with a two finger tan head that has great retention and leaves sparse lacing. Aroma is big on roasty, smooth, cold brewed coffee, some chocolate, caramel, cereal and light woody notes. Flavor is roasty, mellow coffee, a little char, light woody notes, brown malt, light floral notes and some spicy, sprucy hops. Light to medium body, creamy, but slightly dry entry, with a slight acidity, medium, blanketing carbonation. Really good stuff, great, surprisingly fresh coffee character.

Look: pours a dark brown. Clear. Light brown head. 
Smell: coffee. Expresso. Roasted malts. 
Taste: heavy coffee. Expresso. Roasted malts. Smoked malts. Tastes like cold coffee that needs sugar.
Feel: slightly dry from the coffee. 
Overall: good beer if you like coffee. Not my style. 
First drank: home 3/9/15
Vintage: 2/9/15
Can. Pours dark ruby with very little head. Nose is big time cold press coffee. Taste is fresh coffee with a little caramel sweetness. Lingering coffee bitterness in the aftertaste.

16 oz Can. Tasted on 2/19/15. Can from France 44. This one has a great coffee aroma. The taste is strong coffee dark Malta & a bitter finish. Really enjoyed this one.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at ward 6 in minnisoda with nate hakes lamont rusty padget. . Perfect coffee taste and very smooth

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Flight at MSP. Rating based on my personal distaste for coffee beers. Coffee forward, dominates taste and aroma. Completely obscures wonderful brown ale (previously rated). Go with the overall ratings here, not to my liking.

Clear brown black colour, firm light beige head. Aroma of coffee, sweet Starbucks coffee. Bitter flavour, cold Starbucks coffee. Bit watery. Finish coffee, lingering bitter.(from draught @ CBC green session, Copenhagen 2014. Thanks for sharing todays beers, RateBeer crew!)

9/I/15 - 1Pt. can @ home - BB: n/a, canned: IX/26/14 (2015-21) Thanks to sebletitje for sharing the can!
Clear purple brown beer, creamy beige irregular head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: lots and lots of coffee, roasted, no, just coffee. MF: soft carbon, medium body, smooth creamy texture. Taste: lots and lots of coffee, more coffee, soft bitterness, cocoa powder. Aftertaste: lots of coffee, dark chocolate, more coffee still... Not my cup of tea. :p
16 oz can pours brown with a tan head. Aroma of coffee, malts and caramel. Taste is caramel and coffee.

Draught at Mikkeller, Black sensation. Smell is light and has some malts, coffee and caramel. Pours dark brown with a small beige head. Taste has some subtle malts and some chocolate and is quiet fresh. Thin palate. Overall a decent beer though a bit too thin.

Pour from a can is a nice dark rich brown similar to coffee. Aroma is straight from a fresh pot of regular coffee. Taste is a little bitter like black coffee but goes down smooth. Leaves a clean after taste.

Poured from can into shaker. Translucent brown with frothy off-white head. Smell is like coffee grounds. Taste is almost all brewed coffee, with a little bit of hops and beer taste lingering in the background. Feel is a little thin, but smooth, like coffee, so appropriate. Overall, a cool, interesting beer. It REALLY tastes like coffee, which is kind of incredible. Couldnt drink it all day (probably not intended for that), but Im really enjoying it.

From can. Pours dark brown with a creamy, light brown head. Aroma has coffee... and thats pretty much it! Light roasted, fruity, smooth coffee, coffee berries. Taste is smooth, roasted coffee, a hint of roasted malts, more coffee. A slight caramel, but not very sweet. Slightly watery body, but overall really nice beer!

Can. Pours clear brown reddish, with minimal light brown head. Aroma is loads of coffee. Fresh green coffee, fresh grounded coffee, roast and some coffee berries. Taste is medium sweet and roasty dry coffee. Long dry finish and thin body. Clean coffee. Nice coffee beer!

Can 50cl. Dark clear brown, small tan head. Aroma of fresh pre-roasted coffee beans and not much else; some fruits and berries and a faint hint of chocolate. Taste is light on the tongue, but quite delicate; also one-dimensional and lacking the thick bitter body of most coffee beers. Fresh and easy to drink.

one dimensional for sure, but MAN is it a tasty dimension. all iced coffee. the nose, the flavor, even the feel. thin, but smooth. dark brown with a red tinge in light. covers up the original beer pretty well, which is both good and bad. if youre not a coffee person, youd hate this. its the most straight up coffee like beer ive ever had, and not a whole lot else."

Hazy dark brown with a beautiful light tan head. It smells like a used coffee filter. Taste is the same, used coffee filter, lots of coffee and kindda earthy. Medium bitter with earthy palate. Medium body. average carbonation and a long coffee aftertaste.

Can at home. Pour is deep town with a big tan head and good lacing. Huge coffee, malty, caramel, some cookie malt, light pepper and cocoa in the aroma. Taste is big coffee, some roast, graham crackers, caramel, toast, brown sugar, and bread. Medium body with soft carbonation. Tasty, but could truly benefit from a heavier body and a touch more cocoa.
UPDATED: MAY 4, 2015 A dark red beer with a small tan head. The aroma is pure roasted coffee. The flavor is also dominated by coffee. Its basically a cold cup of coffee at 5%.

Can from De Bierkoning, cheers Potje! Dark brown colour, dense beige head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate, espresso, just light fruity. Flavour is sweet, caramel, coffee, espresso, chocolate, coffee and hoppy bitter finish with a little chocolate. Light-bodied, oily mouthfeel. Nice.

Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma has fresh grinded coffee beans up front! Behind this you get the caramel malty notes and a little bit of fruity notes. Very coffee forward aroma. Taste of fruity and roasted coffee, nuts, roasted malts, sweeter caramel and some weak hoppy notes. This is really good! Takes the regular bender to another level! Nice coffee brown ale!

Can from unknown courtesy Dan Stepaniak. Pours a very dark color, really almost black, lots of tan head. Aroma arch, cold brew definitely comes through, with some dry, burnt roasty notes. Body medium lively, with a wonderfully complex finish, the slipperniess of cold brew, along with some nice citrus bitterness before giving way to along and impressive roasty, nutty taste. Really nice.

duft: stor duft af kaffe velter op af dåsen når man åbne den. den dufter lige som en hel kop ny lavet kaffe. 
smag: malt. grøn kaffe. karamel malt. en smule kakao eftersmag

Can from Mikkeller and Friends, Copenhagen. Dark brown pour with a beige head. Unsurprisingly lots of coffee in the aroma, splash of chocolate and vanilla in there too. Smoky coffee flavours with a hint of raisin. I could easily have one of these late at night with a bourbon biscuit or a chunk of plain/dark chocolate. Nice.

Can from a trade. Poured into a snifter at home. Big tan head on a deep brown,oily pour. Aroma is serious coffee with a hint of nut and caramel. The taste is...well...coffee heavy. Sort of an espresso roast. Also nut vanilla, caramel, and leather. Medium to full body and moderate carb. Very good beer...and from a can.

(can - 16 oz) Brown pour with a thin tan head. Huge roasted coffee aroma with some light nuttiness and malts. Tons of coffee in the flavor. Really stands out since the beer was lighter and the coffee didnt have to compete with as much.

Can. Dark Brown Body with nice lasting tan head. Aroma is coffee, slightly roasted malts some dreid fruits and hints of vanilla. Taste is coffee , malty sweetnes with cocoa and some vanilla. Aftertaste is medium bitter with coffee and malts. Nice one.
Pours a dark brown with khaki head. Coffee, roasted malt and some toast on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with malt. Wish the coffee was stronger.
Dark chestnut brown, thin head. Smells like coffee, bread, a little sweet. Taste hoppy, lots of chili flavor, plenty of coffee too. Body is a little thin. Ok.

Can from the Bierkoning. Deep brown pour with smallish off white head. Aroma of concentrated cold coffee, super coffee bomb, cant really get much else, maybe some light hazelnut. Taste is bitter, astringent coffee, very light bodied, a bit watery actually, just like drinking cold coffee. FFFs barrel aged espresso was better than this. Drinkable, but thats about it.

1 pint can. Pours a deep ruby/caramel with a one finger, khaki head and slight sediment. Mild lacing. Aroma has some nice notes of roasty malts, caramel, and coffee grinds. Taste is balanced but with a coffee bitterness on the backend. Roasted malts, caramel, bitter/sweet chocolate, fruity English yeast taste, and a smooth coffee. Medium body and carbonation. Clean in the mouth with a smooth finish. Overall a really nice coffee brew. Coffee is in balance and not overly bitter. Great!

16oz can, canned 4/25/14. Thanks to Scott L. for sharing! Brown, slight red color. Thin khaki head. Leaves bits of lace. Fantastic coffee nose on this. Some nutty earthiness in the flavor, and more coffee. Great coffee on it. Light to medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter carbonation. Good creamy full mouthfeel. Light dry finish. Good moderate bitter taste, moderate sweet. Awesome stuff. Coffee forward, yet still light and easy to drink. These Benders are very cool. Full flavor, without being unnecessarily sweet or heavy.

Can thanks to HoffDog43. Nose is a wonderful blend of coffee and espresso; just the right amount of roast. pour is a dark brown with an off white to light brown head. excellent lacing. Taste is all coffee with a bit of that tea-like graininess to it. Very enjoyable but the body/mouthfeel seems a bit thin. otherwise very good

Can thanks to trade with jdb288! Pours an opaque brownish black with thin lacy tan brown head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma is coffee out of the gate, with some nuttiness behind. Taste is again all coffee, cold brewed goodness, no astringency or bitterness. Very nice for what it is, soft carbonation, definitely a nice morning beer.

Can. Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue when held to the light, and a decent light beige head. Smells like cold, black, dark roast coffee, with a little maltiness coming through as well. Flavour is a lot like an iced coffee without cream. Bitter coffee with some sweeter malts to round it out. Lighter and more refreshing than a coffee stout without losing any coffee flavour. Definitely something different.

Can from Mikkeller online shop; dark brown pour with a big frothy light beige head, strong roast coffee aroma, taste has rich quality coffee, a hint of pine resin, some vanilla, caramel some woody notes, enjoyable.

47 cl can @ home. Pours brown with a little sediment and an off-white head that leaves quite a bit of lacing. Aroma and flavour are coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and nuts - with a slightly bitter finish.

Pours a dark cola brownish. Decent head, disappears fairly quickly. Lacing shows up. This one is all about the coffee- lots of coffee on the nose. The taste is more of the same - more coffee. Mouthfeel is light, creamy, and real smooth. Coffee notes are not overbearing nor do they detract from the beer still tasting like beer. A great beverage and recommended! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to the Minnesota Homebrewing Association for the beer at the AHA conference. Pours near black with purple hue, off white head, and no lacing. Aroma is huge coffee aroma...just like I stuck my head in a bag of foldgers coffee grounds. Taste is the same with some hazelnut, roasted malts, raisins, and a hint of strawberries.

HUGE coffee aroma. Really good roast and some chocolate shine as well. Pours a dark translucent black with little head retention. Taste is bright coffee up front and leads into more malt forward porter territory. One of the best coffee beers Ive ever had. Great stuff.
Aroma is all coffequite strong, but very nice coffee. Taste is lie a nice cold brew, malty brown ale, some sweet caramel malt. Very good stuff.

On tap at the POPE for beer week. Aroma is pure coffee. Pours deep brown with a very small brown head. Taste is coffee, oreo cookies, malt, and a roasty coffee finish. This is just a perfect example of beer tasting like coffee. Mouthfeel is not too thick so this is easy to drink. Nice.

Can from a bottle shop in Copenhagen. It has that aroma that reminds me of chili but that is actually coffee, and also a dark malty backbone. Similar taste. I had the regular bender before this and this coffee version was slightly better and I dont even drink coffee.

Black with a thin tan head. Smells like cold coffee some what light cola ish awesome and refreshing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Hazy brown body with a medium off-white head. Loads of coffee with some smokiness in it. Sweet caramel malt. Almost like iced coffee or something similar. Very interesting and very good.
Dark brown pour with a white head and lacing. Aroma is like opening a bag of fresh ground coffee. The taste is black coffee, cashews, light caramel and hops. Thin body but tasty. Good session brew.
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and sweet caramel malts. Mostly sweet to start and a bit bitter at the end. I could honestly drink one of these each day with breakfast.
Can at Scion. Pours a deep cola color, almost black. Aroma is cold brew, light roast, bitter chocolate, smoke, grassy hops. Taste is coffee, burnt caramel, cacao nib bitterness, marshmallow. Good.

Can, pours dark brown with a beige head, noticeable coffee aroma, the coffee flavor also defines the taste but there are also hints of caramel and malt, light bitter finish, another good beer from Surly

Can at Savor. If I was blindfolded and someone handed this to me, I might think I was poured a cup of coffee. This beer had an unmistakable coffee aroma, along with chocolate and deep roasted malt. Poured pitch black. Flavor was a follow through from the aroma. This is a special beer to savor!

Sample at CBC 2014. Poured a hazy dark brown with a big frothy light tan head. The aroma is big coffee earthy mineral. The flavour is medium bitter with a light earthy hop spice bitter palate. Medium to light bodied with average carbonation.

Sampled @ CBC 2014. Very dark red-brown color with a nice dark red glare coming through. Medium sized beige head. Overpowering aroma of coffee, mocha and espresso. Taste malts, dark malts, again strongly coffee, mocha and espresso and nicely bitter. Very heavy aroma, but more balanced flavorwise imo.
Strong coffee aroma smooth drinking no bitter after taste. Nice coffee color good beer.

CBC2014
Pours dark dark brown head low off white head
Aromas has loads of coffee powder, hints of chocolate, vrown sugar
Taste has good tones of coffee, dark malts, brown sugar
Had it on tap at the Tipsy Cow. This beer tasted just like drinking black coffee. It was good, but I like coffee stouts and porters more.
Tap @ CBC, cph. Dark mahogany, medium off white head, nice lacing. Cold coffee up front, malty, roasted notes, caramel, nutty. Again mostly coffee in the aroma.

Coffee Bender has a special place in my heart, as it's one of the beers responsible for piquing my interest in craft beer. That random taste at Hopleaf one night in 2008 was infectious. 

Deliciously pungent, fresh, roasty coffee aroma fills the air. Taste follows suit, delivering torrents of coffee to my palate courtesy of the fluent, moderately light body. 

Crushable. This beer has one goal and absolutely nails it. Probably my favorite brown ale on the planet. All day, erry day!

Fresh can. Pours deep brown/black, no head. Aroma is dark roast coffee, some mocha, faint raisin/fig/plum and dark chocolate. Taste is amazing coffee flavor - one of the better I can remember. Lighter bodied (and expected, at 5%), but huge flavor here. Ill drink as much of this as I can find.
Aroma: coffee. Appearance: cofee. Taste: coffee. Palate: coffee. Overall: pretty sure they gave me a cup of coffee.

Can: Thanks, Corey! Pours like a cup of medium strength coffee, hold the cream, topped with an ecru layer of froth that would be fit for a latte. Aroma is full-force cold pressed coffee... Smells like an iced coffee with cream & sugar, seriously. Lightly sweet mocha notes underneath. Taste is (not surprisingly) outright coffee, coffee, coffee. Iced coffee. But its beer. More roastiness on the palate than expected, but still a nice, milky sweetness undercurrent flowing through. Touch of astringent roast in the finish. The aftertaste leaves your mouth feeling like you just finished a cup of coffee. No shit. Very tasty beer for the coffee lovers (like me) in the world. Could use a little more body, perhaps.
Torréfaction intense, malts rôtis, noisettes grillés et moka dans une brown ale axé sur le café noir.
Pours dark brown with tan head from can. Nose is coffee taste us coffee with a creamy end. Great body and a damn good brown.

Pours a deep dark brown with minimal head. Just a small wispy ring around the glass. Big coffee flavor and aroma with some chocolate, cream, and cola notes. Smooth mouthfeel that is a little thin. Light body with low carbonation. Refreshing and delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2016 Can thanks to the other Ben. Serious coffee beer here. That?s one of the few styles I miss out in Denver. No one I know packages a coffee beer here that is as rich and genuine as Surly (or Bells or Terrapin or Founders). Deep, true whole bean coffee tantilizes my nose with a hint of sweet malts. Palate is medium. Real, rich coffee bean flavor to back up the aroma highlights the sweetish bready malts. Excellent beer.
16oz can pours a cloudy brown with a reddish hue and a nice tan head. Big coffee aroma with hints of caramel, chocolate, and hops. Slight bitter flavor with a clean finish. Delicious!!
Ruby amber body w/ creamy khaki head & good lacing. Espresso & roasted malt aromas. Intense coffee flavors w/ hint of nutty character. Nice.

Can (canned 1/6/14) poured into a nonic pint glass. Pours a dark brown almost black color with half an inch of light tan head. Big coffee on the aroma, bits of dark chocolate. Tasting notes of big roasty and burnt coffee, dark chocolate, caramel. Very coffee forward on the aroma and taste, coffee flavors dominate. Thin mouthfeel. Medium carbonation and body with a semi-dry finish. Pretty easy drinker for coffee lovers.
Another bravo to Surly for this delicious coffee beer. The aroma is as rich as the flavor in this amazingly tasteful beer. Rich foamy head with staying power. Amazing!

brought a pint can home from a trip to MN, along with several other Minneapolis area brews.

It pours out dark, dark brown with a tan head and the aroma of expresso wafts up from the glass. The taste was quite bitter, much more so than other coffee stouts I have had. The mouthfeel is a little thin too, not as boozy as I had hoped. Worth trying, but there are other brews from Surly I like a lot more
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Nose is of espresso and chocolate. Like a chocolate covered bean. Or iced coffee. Taste is exactly the same. Quite thin. Nice carb. Easy drinking.

going into this one i wasn?t sure what to expect.....tastes and smells like coffee of course....i would think it would be so-so, but this stuff is very tasty....i am not a beer in the morning guy, but i might be now.

beige head disappears with some structured lacing. brown colour. aroma of coffee (!!), roasted, coffee grounds, something fruity, skunky, hoppy. taste like aroma with aftertaste of coffee (!!). dry mouthfeel, quite thin body, lot of carbnation.  can 50 cl / bd 22-11-2013
Mörkbrun öl med lättare beige skum. Kaffe dominerar nästan helt i doften. I smaken finns lite mer choklad och vanilj. Lite som att dricka en god icecoffee.

thnx to Belgbeergeek
Pours almost black , good fast fading white head . 
Smell is pure cold coffee, and so is the taste . Bitter, indeed , and I can find some stuff in there I might like, but the cold-coffee factor ruins it all for me ...

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2014 THX! to Belgbeergeek for this one. I was previously interested in this one. 568 ml. can sampled. Pours a dark brown with little head. Smells straight-up like coffee, the real grounds, the actual stuff, roasted, just pure intense actual coffee, no beer ingredients, interesting. Taste is straight up iced coffee, like a glass of iced coffee with some ice cubes & carbonation, roasted, grounds, coffee beans, light chocolate, caramel. Easy to drink. This is more coffee than beer. I am not a coffee drinker but one doesnt need to be that to enjoy iced coffee & I quite liked this. Cheap & in 4packs, I would buy this regularly, it is quite easy to drink.

Big can in a teku. Pours near black with a thick, beige head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, a little toffee and nuttiness and caramel, some dough, and a light bitterness. Flavor a great blend of everything. Average texture. A really cool beer.
Brown pour from can at luckys in bucktown. Chocolate. Mild. Light. Smooth. Nutty. Good beer

Dark brown/black color; Medium body; Aroma of toasted malt, rich coffee, & some hops; Flavor of roasted malt, rich coffee/espresso, dark chocolate and hops; Finish is slightly bitter; Very nice coffee brew.

Can, thanks Chase! Pop the can and the intense coffee aroma with vanilla notes is evident. Pours a coffee-colored brown with nice foamy khaki head. Medium/light body with big time coffee flavors up front. Finishes smooth with a very slight bitterness. Yep, tastes and even drinks like an iced coffee... love it!

Poured from can to glass. Dark brown hue with off white head. Aroma is huge coffee, roasted, nutty, hay. Mouthfeel is watery with a light body and lacking carbonation. Taste is dry throughout with a slight astringtness and bitter following. Overall this us just like drinking a glass of cold pressed coffee.

Can (thanks, J!), opened this morning before the Seahawks game when I couldnt decide if it was time for coffee or beer. The answer: this. Pours cola brown with some offwhite head that dissipates quickly. No lacing. Aroma: coffee - cold, diner coffee. Some caramel, toast, and toffee behind it, but for the most part this is just straight up coffee. Not french press coffee, nor cold toddy, but diner coffee refrigerated, concentrated, then poured into a can with milk and sugar. And it works. Yes it does. Medium light body, average carbonation. Lasting roasty bitter finish, moderately sweet to start, but finish is bitter and reasonably dry. Overall: go Hawks!

Can from trade and forget who. But thanks! Pours to my tulip brown with some ruby red showing through in the pour. As it accumulates in the glass it ends up very dark brown with a one finger khaki head that's looks very creamy. Aroma is a giant smack of coffee beans, maybe a hint of nutty brown ale in there. Flavor comes in with, SURPRISE, big coffee, earthy and spicy as can be and nearly like liquid espresso beans. There is a light nutty and malt character mixed in there but it is certainly subdued. There is a small hint of bittering cocoa powder as well. The mouthfeel on this is on the thin side and it would have been nice to have either a bit more thickness to this, or more carbonation. As is, the carbonation is a low medium to low. It makes it sort of sit deadened on the tongue. Nevertheless the coffee flavor here is massive and this is rather enjoyable.

16oz can - pours a deep murky brown with medium tan head . Tons of espresso aroma with a hint of chocolate . Tastes like a medium roast coffee , smooth palate . Nice sweet finish . Very good . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 29, 2015 Old can from my last trip to MN in August 2012. Found in the back of my fridge. Pours a murky brown with a short-lived head. Lots of lacing. Nose is coffee, a hint of caramel. Taste is burnt coffee, caramel, hint of butterscotch. Palate is soft, and medium to light bodied. The burnt coffee flavor continues to increase, followed by pine sap and wet dirt notes. Hint of shoe leather. Probably should have drunk this a year ago. Oops. Still surprisingly decent for being as old as it is. I remember it being quite refreshing when it was first purchased. 

Update.  Canned 3/10/15.  Pours murky brown with a huge rocky head.  Medium lacing. Nose is coffee grounds, caramel malt.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Lots of coffee over a brown ale base.  Finishes dry with a hint of pine.  Pretty good.

They might need to invent the "coffee session ale" category just for this beer. On the entry it tastes more like an iced coffee than beer, but the malt comes in smooth on the finish. Very well done as expected by Surly.

Brown. Dusty coffee notes. Maine Caramalty roasted notes too. Dry intense roasted coffee flavours. Not strong. Fine brew

Bottle. Pours Coca-cola brown with a scant beige head. Smells just like the filter holder in my coffee maker. No, really, it smells that much like coffee. Flavor follows nose, this is cold brewed iced coffee, the beer has pretty much disappeared. Theres a little malt sweetness, alcohol and carbonation. The rest is coffee. Huge coffee aroma. Almost like a cup of coffee. Taste is strong coffee with a bitter finish. I dont find it pleasant. Theres some malt in there but the coffee overwhelms it. Not a favorite.

the problem with this is, its just coffee. you dont taste anything else. as with most coffee beers, you dont have the backbone of a stout or porter to match up with the taste of the coffee, provide it with depth. this just basically tastes like cold watery coffee. good, but lacks dimension.

Pours a nicely hued brown with a thin head. Aroma is a typical brown ale then a huge whif of coffee hits your nose. The descriptions says "coffee added" and boy can u tell on taste. Definitely a major, major player in the flavor and palate. You must love coffee to appreciate this! Awesome brown ale!
Nice coffee aroma. Nice coffee flavor. Wish it would have had a bit more brown flavor though. Happy Birthday Doug!

Wow, coffee aroma burst out when I popped the can open. Dark brown color reminiscent of coffee (duh). Taste is cold/iced coffee in a big, big way. Is there beer in here? Yep, some malt is in the background, and a little bit of hops. If you love coffee and you love beer, you have to try this one for the experience. I feel like I just drank a cup of coffee, not a 16 oz can of beer. Of the "unique and unusual" beers Ive tried, this one is one of the best.

Refrigerated 16 oz. aluminum can poured into an English pint glass. Pours translucent chestnut brown with four finger beige head. Aroma is roasty coffee, medium body, low carbonation, and big bubble lacing. Taste is lots of cheap roasty coffee. This one is not for me, really big coffee flavor.

Poured from a can. Almost black with a tan head. Big coffee smell, as expected. A lot of coffee flavor. OK.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep ruby to brown, finger light tan head.

Smell big roasty espresso and coffee

Taste espresso bean, burnt roast but not ashy

Lighter to mid body

Very coffee forward, almost too much, ok

Can. Wow, I never thought Id find a beer that would not only be good with doughnuts, but would actually be even BETTER with doughnuts! Pours a medium ruddy brown with nice medium creamy off-white white head (almost like Guinness with the widget), excellent lacing. Nose is almost all freshly brewed coffee with a hint of malt hiding in there. Mouth is straight up coffee forward (light roast) with a gradual appearance of the brown-ale heartiness of the Bender coming through. Had a lot of coffee stouts, and a few other coffee beers, but nothing anything like this. If they sold it in Seattle, no one would bother with Starbucks or Georgetown brewing anymore... they could kill two birds with one stone with this. Now to more pressing issues... what to eat with this? Custard, maple-glazed, old fashioned glazed, or an apple fritter?

Clear deep brown pour with a thin off white to khaki head ... aroma is of fresh coffee grinds ... you dont get much more coffee in an aroma like this beer wow also has roast malts, light chocolate and vanilla .... taste is of roasted and chocolate malts, vanilla with a nice iced coffee feel and a bitter hoppy bite on the backend ... finish is bitter and dry .... mouthfeel is a little oily and slightly creamy ... body is medium .... abv hidden well .... nice stuff

THis tastes like a cup of black coffee with the grounds still in it. Not very strong and pours black in color

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Reddish mahogany brown in color... Aroma is intensely cold brewed coffee... Minimal carbonation, no head... Flavor is black coffee, with notes of roasted malts, chocolate... More like coffee with beer added... Interesting and enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Big time coffee aroma. Good flavor, smooth, rich, chocolately, great coffee flavor without overwhelming the tastebuds. Very drinkable.

A- pours a clear mahogany and deep cola brown with a solid two fingers of lightly tan creamy head. Great lacing. S- coffee, coffee and coffee - but pre-packaged motel room coffee. Chalk, dirt, graham cracker pie crust, and stale oats. Some chocolate, light toffee and vegetal notes. M- light to medium oily body with a bitter light palate. Decent carbonation. T- coffee grounds, chalk and earth up front. Middle reveals strong hop notes of grass and soap that linger the rest of the way through. Root vegetable. Cheap Halloween chocolate and NutraSweet complete a lifeless mid palate. Ending is more grassy hops and chocolate with the sensation of sucking on zinc and wood.
Black pour with an off white head. Lacing present. Strong coffee aroma. Creamy mouth full of chocolate & coffee. This is pretty much like drinking a slightly sweet cup of coffee.

Really thought I had rated this! Pours oaky brown, immense 3 finger off-white head. Nose is cold pressed coffee and malted oats. Nice big mouthfeel, loads of coffee acidity and bitterness. Goes down easy and is the most drinkable coffee beer Ive ever had.

Can bought at Mikkeller & Friends july 2013. Dark brown body, huge light brown head. Aroma is (surprisingly!) coffee, cocoa, pale malt. Nice bitter ice coffee taste with a pleasant sweet caramel tone, nutty brown finish. I like the fact that they havent oversweeten this beer, as one might suspect from the iced coffee themed can

Dåse. Brunlig, let grumset. Lavt beige skum. Lækker blød kaffe-aroma. Smooth kaffe, blød sødlig malt, mild humle. Let kaffe-bitter finish


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from Mikkeller & Friends. Hazy brown body with a medium offwhite head. Lots of coffee with some smokiness in it. Sweet caramel malt. It's almost like a great iced coffee. Delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark copper colorr, small steady brownish head. Loads of rosted coffee, espesso in the nose. Medium-bodied. Lots of coffee, but in very drinkable form. Backing maltyness. Interesting.

15-NOV-2013, can @home, from Mikkeller & Friends.
Murky brown with lasting tan head.
Aroma is huge coffee and hops.
Taste is cold coffee, grape fruit and pine. A bit messy but quite tasty. Fruity, though a bit tired hops.
Creamy, soft carbonation. Fine brown ale.

Can shared at Craft Clerko, big thanks to Ryan who wasnt there in person, 25/10/13.
Lightly hazed chestnut brown with a good sized beige head.
Nose is coffee cake icing, light roast malts, espresso, tirimasu.

user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Can split at craft beer co clerkenwell. Big thanks to Ryan. Big fresh brewed coffee aroma. Dry and bitter with a touch of creme caramel. Ive had plenty of coffee stouts before, but never a coffee-infused brown ale. Would that even work? In the case of Surly Coffee Bender it definitely does. Its not as rich and intense as a coffee stout, but is just as robust, yet it has the smaller, more sessionable body of a brown ale. Impressive indeed.

I received a 16oz can from a fan in Minnesota (thanks, James!). I poured it into a mug.

Appearance: Opaque dark chestnut brown body. Forms a fairly large, beige, foamy head which lingers and laces very well.

Smell: Strong coffee aroma as soon as the can is opened. Up close its like sticking your nose in a pot thats been sitting on a burner for way too long. Not much genuine beer scents, though.

Taste: Ive often described coffee beers as tasting like iced coffee with plenty of cream and sugar, but in the case of Surly Coffee Bender its more like deeply roasted, unflavored and slightly burnt coffee. In other words, its a pretty darn bitter brew. Right from the get-go this beer is bitter with a dry, slightly spicy hop character. Though technically a brown ale, there isnt much in the way of traditional brown ale sweetness aside from a quick confectionery taste through the middle. The back end and aftertaste is all unflavored coffee. It imparts a dry bitterness and a taste akin to burnt popcorn.

But despite that description, the fact remains I actually really like the taste here. As a coffee drinker, but not a connoisseur, I do enjoy the robust, authentic coffee flavor. I also appreciate the originality of the recipe since it doesnt taste like mocha or iced coffee. And though its bitter its nothing unbearable. I would like to see more genuine malty sweetness to balance it out, but as it stands its more than a solid beer.

Drinkability: Surly Coffee Bender may not taste like a brown ale, but it definitely drinks like one. The mouthfeel is smooth, soft and low on the carbonation. It doesnt feel thick or heavy. Theres a mild coffee aftertaste, but its not only tolerable but pleasant. I am absolutely amazed that this beer is only 5.1% ABV considering how flavorful it is. Its something you can drink multiple servings of without being overwhelmed or suffering palate fatigue.

Thanks to the dudes at Surly for this.  16 oz can pours dark brown with a thin, brown head.  Nose full of coffee, some nice light roast, and some nuts in the background.  Definitely coffee in the flavor, but not overpowering.  Still plenty of nutty brown ale character showing through.  A damn fine beer.

By far the best brown ale I've ever had. Nose is roasted malts. Creamy mouthfeel with finish of coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown with a thin white head.  Smells of coffee but not overpowering.  Not my favorite style but a decent ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great beer from a can for a glass. $12.49 / 4 pack - Good morning beer while camping, but Id rather have Furious
Smooth slight  roasty taste. A little thin for a dark brew. The coffee comes through nice.

Sample pour, nice brown appearance with light khaki head.  Nose is lighter than I remember.... light coffee, roasted and toasted malts.. more toasted.  Somewhat pleasant... Flavor is much nicer, smooth but pleasant roasted malt, coffee, lighter nuttiness, and pleasant all over.  Not bad.  Not bad at all, Surly

Taken from my BA account, reviewed 3/16/12

Live tasting, can into Duvel Tulip... Huge thanks to OtisCampbell for this!! 

Appearance; pours a dark, maduro cigar colored brown, with a two finger khaki colored head... Retention is moderate, and the head dissipates over a couple minutes to a thin ring around the glass... Lacing is pretty good, with patches of lace on the glass.

Smell; Smell is pretty mild, some slight coffee aromas, and a slightly bready, yeasty presence... Nothing extraordinary, but certainly not bad...

Taste; a great coffee flavor without any of the associated acidity or bitterness. The coffee kind of "sits on" the beer, and by that I mean it is the first flavor that pops right out, and as it gently fades out, a great , slightly nutty, bready brown shines through... The way the flavors meld together is wonderfully complex and it is perfectly balanced.

Mouthfeel; medium bodied with medium carbonation... Drinkability is superb at a touch over 5% ABV, it goes down extremely smooth... I could drink this all day.

Overall; probably the best brown Ive ever had... Drinkability is superb, flavors are outstanding... Definitely a winner from Surly and I would drink this daily if I could... I also think it would make one hell of a beer bread...

Pours a muddy brown with an off white head and aroma of espresso and coffee beans. Taste is toasty, of coffee, espresso, chocolate, roasted malt, and caramel. Light with a thin mouthful, nice coffee brew.

Pours a dark mahogany brown with a small head. Nose is deep coffee and espresso. Taste is light, with a roasty, coffee, chocolate and caramel flavor.Carbonation is soft and texture light. Finish is all coffee as well. Drinks like a session beer.
Can.  The aroma has decent amount of coffee with some malt.  The taste is a little crisp and harsh.  The coffee come through, but not really in a good way.  Was expecting more.
Very dark brown nice thick off white head great string coffee aroma great coffee flavor smooth and crisp. served at gabf 2012.

Pours clear brown with a tall tan head.
Rich aroma of coffee and chocolate.
The flavor delivers pretty much what youd expect from the aroma.
lot so coffee and chocolate with just a bite of espresso. Very smooth for a coffee beer.
Sampled at GABF on Saturday October 13, first sessionDark brown to black color, brown head. Sweet, coffee scent. Sweet, hoppy, coffee taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

Can courtesy of GT2. Thanks mate! Pours tiny hazy dark amber with a frothy pale mocha head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with sweet dark bread, sweetened dark roast coffee, cocoa powder, roasted nuts, vanilla fudge, brown sugar, butterscotch and toffee. Taste is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with dark bread, roasted malts, sweetened dark roast coffee, vanilla fudge, butterscotch, banana bread, golden syrup, walnut skins, toffee, burnt caramel and moist wood. Mouthfeel is round, smooth, tiny watery and light to medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, sweetened dark roast coffee, dark bread, golden syrup, walnut skins, caramel and toffee.

Bottle at Bomber-o-rama, Göteborg. Deep amber/copper beer with a nice beige head. Cocoa aroma, chocolate, butter notes, roasted, fruity, coffee, caramel. Flavor from cocoa powder, coffee, caramel, roasted, dark chocolate, figs, hoppy, walnuts, slightly bready, quite nicely balanced and rather drinkable. Cocoa finish with caramel, walnuts and coffee.

Poured from a 16 oz. can into a Great Divide cervoise goblet. Canned on 6/24/11.

A: Pours a dark brown with some light deep cherry wood hues around the edges. The light squeaks through at random points. A light tan head forms on the pour, about 2 finger in height with some nice retention. Some splotchy lace down the edges of the glass.

S: Smells of wood, nuts and malts. The coffee comes through just slightly in the end in a bitter ground fashion. Slightly disappointing as I expected more of the coffee upfront.

T: Theres the coffee I was looking for. I taste some mocha and vanilla with a slight hint of chocolate. Nice bitter coffee grounds with a toasted malt at the backend. This tastes like a nice iced coffee.

M: Light prickly carbonation with a very smooth, but somewhat thin. Goes down very easy with a high drinkability.

O: What a great beer. While the nose slightly disappointed me the taste and drinkability more than made up for it. Nicely integrated flavors and no taste overpowered the other.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 09-01-2011
UPDATED: FEB 11, 2013 This is a great brew that is nice as a solid stand-by... It has a complex coffee flavor profile and allows much fun!

500mL can, sent from FullObs (thanks a lot, Brett), pours a dark amber / brown with a thick, creamy beige head. Nose is full of filtered coffee, and some light toasted nuts. Flavour is dominated by espresso notes, a little sweet malt, and some tea-like accents. Basically coffee upfront, and a tea-like character on the finish. Highly drinkable, with an extremely light body. Solid stuff.

Can. Pours a dark brown with a medium creamy beige head leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a strong coffee roast and nuts. Thin mouthfeel with a strong coffee flavor with chocolate and roast. Easy to drink with a smooth finish. A good brown ale from Surly.
Very dark brown color, medium tan head. Aroma is roast coffee with a hint of caramel. Smooth coffee bitterness mixed with sweet caramel, yet light and refreshing in a way.
Had this one canned thanks to Wyl!  Very much like adding coffee to beer, this was an excellent eye-opener.

Pitch black with big khaki head. Enormous coffee aroma. Taste is the same but with a small nutty chocolaty note at the end. Big rich palate. Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

garnet with a tan head. Nose is fresh ground coffee beans. At first, it obscures the malt, but the malt fights its way through as it warms a bit, melding well in the nose and flavor. Soft bittersweet coffee and chocolate finish, tinged with earthy hop. This beer is all about the coffee, and it does it very well!

Can. Huge coffee nose, grounds, light chocolate. Purple-red tints in dark brown. Flavor is coffee, fruity and minerals, a bit of chili. Doesnt seem the use of coffee was done right. Nose is too strong and acrid.

Can from Zipps in MSP. Nose of coffee and more coffee. Deep brown, with a very creamy, soft tan head. Initial is very much like iced coffee; mid brings a bit of pepper; final smooths out, with just a tinge of bitterness. Thin body. Okay. Maybe more like coffee than beer.

16oz can into stemmed glass. Pours dark brown with a medium tan head that fades to a slight halo and thick lacing. Aroma is slightly sweet and nutty with a generic iced coffee aroma. Taste is all coffee. Hits the tongue like carbonated iced coffee and it carries over to a slightly stale coffee after taste.

Pint can into Duvel tulip.  Black with light tan head.  Aroma is a lot of coffee with a little malt.  Taste is similar to the nose, a lot of coffee, a bit of malt, very little hops.  Palate is a bit thicker than regular bender, pretty smooth and drinkable.  I just dont dig coffee forward beers, so this isnt for me.  I would say overall its more interesting than Bender

16oz can poured into glass
Nice coffee aroma with a dark brown/black pour. Little head. Coffee flavored stout that is a coffeed up version of Bender. Great beer

A-- Poured a dark brown color with some red. Two finger light mocha colored head, very fluffy. Good lacing, medium carbonation.

S-- Light coffee smell, some roasted malts and a bit of sweetness to it.

T-- Coffee, roasted malts, some lemon acidity and a light sweet mocha taste.

M-- Some coffee bitterness, not much though and not overwhelming. A little light with some sugar sweetness.

D-- Very drinkable, easy to have two or three. it is on the thin side but it is quite good. Not as much coffee as had hoped but very workable.

A gift from Ryan. Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan foam. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and soda. Some biscuit and vanilla for good measure. Medium body with good toasty flavor. Coffee astringency in the finish. Low bitterness. A nice brown.
Can.  Thanks to bnielsen13 for the can.  Pours a deep brown with white head.  Coffee and roasted aromas.  Deep coffee flavor.  Pretty much your typical coffee beer.

Can at a recent bottle share...  Poured brown with an eggy, off-white head.  Coffee and malt sweetness on the nose.  Roasted coffee, toasted grains and nice malt sweetness for balance.  Balanced and not overly coffee-like.
Pours a cola colour with soft off white head. Smells like coffee and some vanilla. It is all coffee and malts on the tongue. So good. Quality coffee = quality beer. Great stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 7/24/12: Dark brown colour with brown head. Roasted coffee aroma and flavour, though distinct from a coffee stout. Re-rate 8/13/14 - I find this a bit too coffee-ish when Im thinking about it, but when Im just enjoying it, its near perfect. Very smooth palate. Score stays the same.

A delicious and flavorful brown ale. Aroma was alright..Could pick up the coffee aroma but it was drowned out by slight alcohol aroma. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a splotchy white near tan head. Taste was delicious and full for a session beer. Strong coffee flavor with dark roasted malt and notes of peanut. Very bitter and dry. Mouth is left with coffee bitterness and tingling from the heavy carbonation. Very nice!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sweet coffee malty aroma. Black not brown. Off white head. Holographic coffee flavor with nice malty undertones acting as a glue bringin it together. About as good as brown could be. But is it a brown? Or is it a porter? Either way very unique and imaginative.

pour is deep dark thick brown with a fluffy creamy head. coffee, huge coffee. its basically iced black coffee. again, coffee. a bit more subtle than scent but still dominates. light floral hops barely linger but can be found, a nice sweet malt backbone that does do some balancing out. sweetness in the finish, a touch of sugar on my teeth. however, this is mainly coffee. nice body for a 5.1% ale. pretty full with a nice moderate carbonation. this is damn good, much better than i remember it last time i had it. a nice touch of sweetness really rounds this out. if you like coffee, you will love this. Reviewed on: 01-09-2010

Thanks to ahalloin for hooking me up with this. Ive been wanting to try this brew for some time.

Served into a pint glass.

A: bubbly like a coca-cola with a nice head and good lacing

S: coffee, obviously, but not as much as I hoped for and expected. Im gonna try another can as soon as I can and see if I get the same result. It makes me feel like Im in Starbucks.

T: Creamy iced coffee. Again, I feel like Im in Starbucks. This is seriously tasty. You have to be a coffee drinker to really appreciate this one. Super smooth and creamy, I just wish it had more coffee.

M: nice mix of smooth with crisp carbonation. I wonder if the can contributed to that.

D: Honestly, I could drink this with breakfast, lunch and/or dinner. This is refreshing iced coffee beer. If you like coffee and beer, this is your session beer.

Tasted on 6/8/2012 at SAVOR 2012.  Aroma is like a shot of espresso. Pours a dark brown. Taste is of coffee, some nuttiness. Extremely impressed with Surlys ability to have crazy aromas yet balanced taste.

Can: Thanks Steve:
Medium tan head, airy on the side, vast in the middle, disappears slow, on top of a deep ruby to lightly brown colored beer.
Smell hops, coffee, coffee roast, light soapy, a slight hint of hops, some (roasted) grains and some fresh flowery coffee beans.
Taste coffee and coffee roast, not too dominating but still good present.
Other flavours are roasted grains, bitter (light hop bitter), a hint of oatmeal, some roasted barley malts, hint of coal but not smokey, a slight hint of flowers and some espresso tints.
Overall a good coffee/coffee roast.
Aftertaste is a mix of coffee and coffee roast (really?), some herbs and grass, (roasted) grains and some coal.
Low carbo, soft light tingly mouthfeel, medium to lightly fuller body and a light creamy texture.
Nice beer, good coffee roast, considering the alcohol percentage its pretty good, though there seems to be something  missing...
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: NOV 18, 2012 Tastes like you are drinking a light espresso.  Body is incredibly thin given how much coffee flavor is packed in to the nose and the front of the palate.  Finishes light and clean, but you get a large coffee kick in the front.
Smells like coffee.  Taste like coffee with malts.  Thin mouth feel.  A great session beer.

Pours a brown with a beige head.  Smoky aroma of coffee, with some nutty flavors as well.  Taste lots and lots of coffee.  Very bitter, some vanilla tastes, nuts, and I detect some fruity undertones after sifting through all of the darker flavors.  I believe it is lemon actually.  Medium bodied, with average carbonation, ending with a bitter aftertaste.  I have to say this one is pretty different than most beers.  Well worth trying.

Solid coffee beer.  The brown ale underneath is a bit on the weak side, offering more toffee notes than I expected and a moderately thin texture, but the delicious java finish washes away any complaints.  Smooth with a hint of coffee acidity, the fade is roasted and bitter, guaranteeing you some coffee breath to go along with your beer breath.  Might as well eat a gyro and go for the trifecta.

16 oz can poured into a DFH signature glass. No date stamp on the bottom of the can...

A - Super dark brown body that appears black until its held up to the light. An aggressive pour created a fluffy three finger high light khaki head. Eventually settles down to a thin cap. Decent amount of lacing.

S - Fresh steeped coffee with a bit of chocolate sweetness and roast on the finish. Simple and effective, smells delicious. 

T - Watered down coffee. Very tame and approachable. The finish is of lightly bitter roasted malts. Smooth with low carbonation. Super drinkable.

O - Its like a lighter version of Founders breakfast stout. Its pretty one dimensional, but works really well as a coffee infused brown ale. I wish I had another so that I could have drank it out of a mug alongside some bacon and eggs...

Can. Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma is filled with coffee and reminds me of ice coffee, I get some toasted malt, caramel and nutty notes with the slightest hint of vanilla. The flavor is also just filled with coffee, again ice coffee like flavors, subtle chocolate and vanilla, lots of nutty notes and the toasted and caramel malts. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a great Brown Ale, the coffee takes it to another level!

poured from a can into my ccb pint glass. Dark brown in appearance with a paper thin head. Aroma is all coffee, wow, so much coffee. Taste follows the nose, coffee takes over and knocks out the complexity of bender. Light carbonation and somewhat thick. Coffee bender isnt as good as its big brother. The coffee takes away from what makes bender so complex. I like coffee beers, this one just might be a little too much

Can.  Ok yes, im not one much for coffee beers, or coffee for that matter (dont even drink the shit) yet, i really dig this fine brew-pours dark amber, brown lightly hazy with a snice soapy kacki head what lasted most of the time.  nose is robust coffee beans, not much else going on however, thats not a bad thing for this beer.  I have never had a beer this coffee forward- puts breakfast stout to shame!!!! wow, long punchy coffee bean finish not much else to descibe-dank, bitter coffee beans here.  I hvae to say, this beer is so fresh, its like drinking coffee in the morning.  Awesome beer!

Originally reviewed: 4/21/10. Poured into a pint glass for a mid-morning drink. Its got coffee in it, this early is acceptable, no? 

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a massive tan head billowing out. Excellent retention on this one. Left lots of sticky globs and webbing all over the glass. The nose is not as coffee-forward as the can would lead you to believe. Im getting notes of honey, brown sugar, maple syrup and bread. Just the faintest of coffee scents on the backend. A little disappointing to say the least. Still, it smells great. 

The body is thinner than Id like as well. Compared to the regular Bender, this one is lacking in bite and depth. Maybe the coffee plays a part(?). The flavor as well is lacking the big bold coffee presence I was expecting. This beer carries the common characteristics to most browns: a nice bready flavor, some toasted brown sugar, light bitterness. There is a lightly sour note present. Coffee? Not sure. Some mild roasted aftertaste which I can assume is from the coffee added.
