I kept the score a little higher on the flavor, because though it lacked the coffee I was expecting, this still was a damn good brown. Better than many. Id have another, and even another. But they could "bold" it up a bit more IMO.
Deep reddish brown with a thick head. Smells of dry earthy hops and dark roasted coffee. Mild-medium bitterness suits coffee flavor well. Medium bodied with the slightest light creamy texture.
Can to oversized snifter (thanks Chris). Looks good; pitch black with some lacing. Smells good too; coffee and malt. Tastes Decent; kind of a watery body though. Decent, but not great IMO.

Pours a pure brown with an average size beige head. Aroma is sweet, nutty, and coffee filled. The taste is much more coffee oriented than anything else. Its got a coffee and cream type of thing with some cocoa, and roastiness. I guess the iced coffee cited in the description is pretty accurate. I would like to try the regular Bender, so I can taste more of what the coffee aspect did to this Brew. Great for Coffee Lovers.

Can.  Pours fresh-coffee black with an aroma of 5 am on a workday.  Pure, freshly percolated coffee.  Pure.  Simple.  Flavor is coffee, light cocoa, and roasted nuts.  Thick and chunky on the tongue.  Surly rocks.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: pours a very dark brown with one finger of foamy creamy caramel head. Tons of roast coffee aroma. Flavor is a good nutty, malty earthy brown ale, with a strong coffee presence. Its brewed with cold extract coffee, and that shines through incredibly.

From a great trader on BA - thanks!  Dark brown pour with a nice little drift of a tan head.  Aroma is pleasant coffee over a nicely roasted malt backbone that has a bit of nuttiness and some very mild softer malt undertones.  Taste is coffee up front followed by a nice, clean and evenly roasted malt profile and a surprisingly bitter hop burst before mellowing out into a bit of malt sweetness with more coffee.  Mouthfeel is clean with some creaminess but crisp in the right places and especially so for the hop bitterness.  Damn - this beer blew me away!!  Best beer Ive had from Surly by a long shot.

From the 4/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 16 oz can this beer poured a dark nut brown color with a small soapy tan head that left decent lacing. The aroma was strong coffee, cream and was a touch burnt. The flavor was strong coffee, cream and artificial sugar with an astringent undertone. The finish was long with lingering coffee and cream. Medium body. Interesting.

16 oz can to glass; recd in trade from emeinz; thanks Eric!  wow - 9 out of 10 on aroma; much great stuff happening - malt, roastedness, coffee, nuts - great aroma; great lloking dark dark brown pour with long lacing.  4 out of 6 for palate/mouthfeel.  the only thing not outstanding for me is the taste - similiar to bender - hops or something up front just diminishes the taste.  still good beer!!

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 16fl. can. Brown colour with a decent formation of a frothy, foamy and tan head, moderate lacing and lasting. Aroma has coffe notes, moderate malty and slightly sugary. Flavour has, above all, coffee traces, dry fruits hints, perhaps nuts and toasted almonds, toasted and roasted malts, slightly sweet with a moderate bitterness in the final. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily.

Can from DalzAle - free beer week - thanks! - pours a dark ruby with a moderate tan head - nose is whole bean coffee, vanilla, toffee, caramel, hazelnut - flavor is much drier than expected, with light roast and moderate coffee flavor (with not of the harsh acidity often extracted from the beans in some other coffee beers) - some light roasted nuts through the middle - leafy bitterness arrives late - some fruity hop notes - a touch of vanilla on the tail end - not as potent with the coffee as I usually like, but a damn tasty beer.

Can from Mane Liquor. Not as impressive as I thought it would be. Obviously its very coffe accentuated. Solid I suppose but was expecting more. Light and bitter coffee tones sums this one up. Solid but its basically for coffee heads

Pours a very nice reddish, purple,maroon color with a small white head.  The aroma is all roasted coffee, and it smells awesome.  The taste is mostly coffee with some roasted malt and hints of chocolate.  Im not a coffee drinker, but this beer is outstanding.
Draft. Clear maroon color, small tan head. Aroma of coffee grounds. Taste is roasted coffee, toast, nuts. Nice.

Can pours chocolate brown with a tan head. Aromas are chocolate and coffee. Tastes are coffee, and a bit of chocolate with not much else. Body is thin and very drinkable. Overall, this is a good straightforward coffee beer that would be great in the morning.
CAN: Great brown/red pour. Aroma of chocolate, nuts, and roast. Flavor is very well balanced with nuts, chocolate, coffee and hops.

Draft at Churchkey. Poured a dark color, with a small tan head. Aroma was espresso with notes of mocha. Flavor was chocolate notes, tons of toasted coffee beans. Mouthfeel a bit thinner than I expected (didnt know the style when I got it), but I guess being a brown ale its about on mark.

Black pour with a nice tan head. Huge mocha and espresso in the nose with big chocolate and hints of roasted malts. Cold seeped coffee and chocolate abound. Medium body with low carbonation. Excellent!

Love bender, Love coffee, that being said this beer is a pretty good blend of the two but I still enjoy the two separately more. Pours a very dark brown as to be expected, with great maltiness of a brown ale and a not overbearing note of roasted coffee. Would drink this again, just not if furious or abrasive is available to me.

Dark brown with decent head retention. Great lacing throughout. Roasted dark coffee smell but not too strong. Not like a coffee porter. Sharp bitter flavor right away-not what youd expect from a coffee beer. Coffee flavor for real coffee drinkers.
Now this is one of those rare brown ales that I would surly stock up on!

Can. Pours dark brown with a finger-high light brown head that settles pretty quick. Aroma of coffee, milk chocolate and some butter. Lots of fresh, good, bitter coffee in the taste, along with chocolate, fudge. Medium sweet, medium to full bodied, soft carbonation that works really well. Long finish with lots of coffee. Solid beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 2/22/2011.  Poured from a 16 oz. can into a pint glass.

This looks pretty much exactly the same as Bender, although a bit darker. A walnut brown color with a ruby tint around the borders of the glass. A frothy tan head forms initially, retains pretty well, and leaves sticky lace on the sides of the glass.

I have not had coffee from the Vinca Vista Hermosa plantation in Guatemala, but the aroma is overwhelmingly Dunkin Donuts coffee at first. The coffee is bold and aromatic. The original aroma of burnt sugar, hazelnut, and earthy hops is largely cast aside.

The flavor maintains a brown sugar front, with some toasted malt and hazelnut as well, but the coffee is already there. The flavor turns coffee bitter, with some earthy hops barely squeezing their way through. The finish is more coffee.

The mouthfeel of Coffee Bender gets a step up over Bender. A little creamier, although there is still that lingering graininess that I dont care for. The carbonation is tighter, but still at a medium level. The body is a bit fuller, maybe slightly above medium.

One of the few times I dont think coffee makes a beer better. I find it a little bit overwhelming, especially in the aroma. Maybe it was the type of coffee that I just did not connect with.

Decent sized light brown head of fine bubbles.  Strong coffee aroma with some chocolate covered espresso beans, dark roasted malts and a noticable sprucy hops bitterness.  Color is a very dark brown with a hint of red.  Lots of dark roasted coffee in the flavor along with some very dark and bitter chocolate and a bit of mint??  Coffee dominates the flavor though.  Bit of a gritty and chalky palate.  Lingering dark roasted grains and coffee flavor.  A bit too much coffee for my tastes.

Poured into an English pint glass from a 16 ounce can born on 1/3/12.

A: Clear deep garnet body with a huge foamy and rocky tan head, this looks excellent!

S: Strong coffee coming through with a nice sweet chocolate to balance it out well. Im very much enjoying this!

T: Coffee coffee and coffee! Theres a lot of coffee flavor here, I feel like I have a fresh coffee bean in my mouth, but its very mellow and balanced out with a slight chocolate and nut flavor. This is excellent, the best brown ale Ive ever had.

M: Light to medium bodied with lazy carbonation.

O: This is an excellent beer, well balanced with great flavor ad all at 5.1% alcohol! I wish this was in New Jersey I would love this over the Winter.

Can from bobbypaulson.Light to medium brown with a dark vanilla cream head  (as described by my wife). Fresh ground coffee with not much else. Moderate to light body, average carbonation, light sweet with a present bitterness from the coffee, smooth, definite metallic undertone until it warms up enough (so just wait), becomes dry, more coffee and some light hops at the end. Quite tasty but more session like (which is not a bad thing at all). Reminds me of Mill Street Coffee Porter.

Coffee Bender is a delicious beer that tastes like a coffee.

A: Brown colour and a great 5 mm head. 8/10

S: Smells of sweet coffee. Very nice. 5

T: Malty with strong hints of coffee and bitterness. Pretty sweet too. This basically tastes like a coffee. 8/10

M: Pretty low carbonation. Suits the style. 4/5

O: 15/20

Poured from a pint sized can. This is a very well balanced coffee beer. I enjoy the creamy, chocolaty, caramel base beer blending with the spicy coffee notes. I would like more of this. The only flaw, which is an esthetic thing, is how cloudy it is. Very nice!

Excellent example of a coffee beer. Smells like fresh pressed coffee. Not much else. Tastes like an iced coffee from one of those fancy joints. No alcohol taste present. Best way to start the morning after a long not of drinking or a BENDER! Great stuff.
nice beer. Had at the Blue monk not sure who brought it in. brown pour, some beige head. nose is dark malts and coffee. mouthfeel is thin expected more. flavor is sweet malts with a good coffee kick.

Canned on 09Dec2011, pours dark brown with nice head that mostly fades. Nose is smoke, coffee, milk chocolate and wood. First sip is caramel, brown malt, instant coffee and nutty flavors. Finish is coffee bitterness but slightly sweet like the last sip of a cup of coffee.
Can. Pours dark brown with thin tan head that retains. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Flavor is also coffee and chocolate. Outstanding brown ale.

Poured from a can into a pint glass.  Canned 12/20/11

A.  Poured a deep dark brown, nice foamy mocha head, about 4mm thick with a mild-aggressive pour, resides to a nice 1mm thick head after sitting for a few minutes.

S.  Smells nicely of coffee, somewhat sweet smelling for a brown ale, oats and brown sugar, slight hops with a mild chocolate.

T.  Tastes nicely of roasted coffee and brown sugar, mild chocolate, with a oatmeal finish and maybe even a little bit of honey taste.

M.  Medium body, which is nice given the rich smell, dry and chewy with a tingling finish.

O.  A very good beer.  Well balanced thickness and chewiness, the flavors are very well balanced and compliment each other well, the coffee is not excessively dominate.  A great anytime beer, I might have one with breakfast :)

The Dan Journal #494. Tasted 1/12/12. 16oz Can. Pours pitch and opaque with a thick cream colored head. Aromas of fudge brownies and coffee. Medium to full bodied with a huge malt bill. Rich and roasted with both sweet and tart flavors mixed in with the solid coffee character. Sticky finish with dark chocolate and fudge notes. Nice and solid drinking.

12oz can from Zipps Liquor in MN, shared with Brett and Brian. Nose is hugely coffee like fresh roasted, then iced coffee... taste is more of the same coffee taste with some hint of malt.. only downfall from this beer to me is the body is very thin still a fantastic smelling beer.. one of the best in fact.

Espresso brown, darker than most brown ales.  Off white frothy head.  Nose of roasted coffee beans.  Medium body, good carbonation.  Bitter, roast coffee prevails.  Some vanilla, lots of roastiness not much else going on here.  Pretty good beer, largely enjoyable...I feel like this beer is preying on my weaknesses, and doesnt deserve this rating, but here it is.

16 ounce can, canned on date of 12/09/11.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown with an inch tan head.  Both the head retention and lacing are good.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and some nuts.  The taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, but theres also a bit of vanilla noticeable.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy and slick and is well carbonated.  I think this is a pretty good overall brew, I liked it a lot.  Its heavy on the coffee in both the aroma and taste, and thats a good thing for me.  Its certainly worth trying, I know Id like to get more of this brew in the future.
Aroma is dark coffee and light chocolate.  Taste is heavily roasted coffee and coffee grounds and very dry.  Would have welcomed light sweetness but overall pretty nice.
Tallboy courtesy of mattyb83, smells like Dunkin donuts dark roast iced coffee. Taste isnt as strong, actually well balance of brown ale and coffee

It poured a dark brown color with a small off-white head. The aroma of coffee was strong with some chocolate and oats present as well. The flavor was of coffee and some chocolate. Not being a big coffee/beer fan, this was very good.

12 oz. can thanks to Tripplebrew. Used an English pint. Brown color with red highlights around the edges. Luscious dark roasted coffee bean nose noticeable as I cracked the can and pored. OOOH, nice! Taste is notes of chocolate, mocha but most of all deep, rich coffee. And if this was a blind taste test, Im not sure I would even know brown ale was in front of me. Smooth almost silk like mouthfeel.  Much like a good, weak coffee. I got to hand it to the brewers at Surly, they make great beer. If you like coffee brews, this is top notch! Can we really call this beer???
Pours a medium to dark brown.  Heavy notes of black coffee. Dry with hints of infection, really like drinking coffee.

Can from mattyb83.  Thanks!  Deep brown color with a decent tan foam on top that slowly settles as a thin film.  The aroma is pretty nice; fresh coffee grounds, toasted malt, and light chocolate.  The flavor follows that; coffee roast, toasted nuts, chocolate, very light ash, and a dash of vanilla.  This is creamy and smooth going down with great balance.  I liked regular Bender so its no surprise that I like this one too.
An excellent coffee brown ale/porter. Creamy mocha flavors, earth and coffee in each sip.

Big ole can thanks to bobbypaulson.  Not the first time Ive had it, but the first time Ive rated it.  Dark brown to black pour, but not too viscous.  Tan head and cold coffee and malt on the nose.  The coffee is nice, but it overpowers the tart oddity of the Bender, which I really like.  Wonderfully drinkable with a nice bitter coffee finish.  Not an overpowering brew, and a TON of taste for a 5.1 ABV brew.

Pours a great black coffee color.

Smells of malty, coffee and chocolate.

Tastes like awesomeness. Big Coffee and chocolate flavors come through. This would be amazing with a it whip cream on top, seriously. 

Excellent.

What a huge disappointment.  I was excited to see cans of this beer at a local place here in DC going.  Despite the steep per can price charged for an out-of-market beer, I bought a can and have been waiting to try it.  The pour was surprisingly translucent.  It really almost looks like coffee.  And the smell is fantastic--rich wafts of freshly brewed coffee.  However, the taste leaves a lot to be desired.  Its really nothing more than cold, watered-down coffee.  The mouthfeel is thin and it has an unpleasant aftertaste.  Id much prefer any number of stouts that have much bigger coffee flavors, if less compelling noses.  A big disappointment.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep murky brown, moderate to large frothy beige head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Sweetened coffee 

aroma, cream and sugar added. &nbsp Some candyish notes like caramel or toffee, but in the unsweetened area... if that 

makes sense. &nbsp Reminds me a little of carob. &nbsp Soft roastiness and sweetened coffee on the tongue. &nbsp 

Smooth, but not very hefty. &nbsp For a brown its better than your average. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. 

&nbsp I will say that I sat on this can for a while and it really held up. &nbsp Coffee with cream and sugar linger... 

not heavy, but its there, combined with a subtle malt roast that blends well. &nbsp Mild sweetness, start to finish, 

not overly hopped at all, very little in fact. &nbsp Very enjoyable.
Can to tumbler. Aroma of coffee grounds. Toasty malt flavor with overwhelming coffee flavor. I prefer the regular Bender.
Somebody thought it was a good idea to mix a good beer with a good coffee.  I prefer to have the coffee and beer mix in my stomach, not in my mouth.  This beer ruins the fun of both beer and coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2012 Pours dark brown with an addicting fresh roasted coffee aroma. Slightly hoppy but mostly a malty/toasty/nutty aroma. The coffee aroma seems overpowered a bit once you start drinking it, but still a good beer.
Pours a dark khaki head with a smell of a figgy, plum coffee bean. No huge splash of taste when it hits your tongue but a good aftertaste for the finish.

Canned 25SEP11

A: dark brown with a transient finger or so of off tan foam which falls quickly to a scattered surface. excellent clarity and spotty lace. (2.5)
S: Smells like breakfast coffee. Plain and black with the slightest hint of burnt nuts. Maybe a little bit of a cinnamon tone. (3)
T: coffee is present, but seems stale. The beer itself seems a bit stale with a bit of soil and bitterness. Again, a hint of nuts. (2.5)
M: Thin with moderate carb and a semi dry finish. Sadly, this so far has been the best part. (3.5)
O: Not impressed with this offering. Like the regular version much better. (2.5)

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Dark brown body with reddish hues. Light brown head that receded to a solid cap. Spotty lacing.

S: This is a unique beer. Unlike most coffee infused beers, this doesnt come across as roasted or burnt coffee. Instead, it is straight freshly ground coffee beans. Take some fresh ground coffee and rub it between your fingers right under your nose, and thats the smell of the Coffee Bender. Light caramel, toffee and nutty malts are in the background.

T: The fresh ground aroma doesnt translate as well to the flavor profile. By no means is it bad. It just loses that "freshness" of the coffee. The coffee is more of a roasted flavor here, and the malts shine through nicely.

M: Smooth, medium bodied. Lingering aftertaste. Solid carbonation from the can.

O: A very nice, if not unique, brew that anyone who enjoys a little coffee in their beer should take a chance on. There is a reason why Coffee Bender (and its kid brother Bender) rock the top of the American Brown Ale charts. They are that good. (review from 2009)

16oz can courtesy of CLevar. Pours a deep clear brown with a a thin cream-colored head that sticks around leaving a lot of lacing. Aroma is very pronounced coffee with a tosty malt background. Body is medium-full. Flavor is also very pronounced coffee with a malty finish. I could drink a ton of this, wish it were distributed in my area.

Appearance:
Dark brown. Imagine a strong coffee with a tiny splash of chocolate milk and youre probably getting close. A good sized head, very tan, which fades away very very slowly. Beautiful in the glass.

Smell:
Coffee dominates with malt taste falling in behind it. The coffee aroma prevents you from noticing anything specific about the hops. 

Taste: 
Coffee again is the dominating factor. The bitterness is more like hops than coffee though, which is interesting. A lot of the flavors that come out in the normal Bender are drowned out by the coffee, except for some possible chocolate notes.

Mouthfeel:
Thick, creamy, and smooth. It makes you feel almost like youre drinking an iced coffee with a bit of cream, though the flavor goes pretty quick. Not that I mind picking up the glass to take another sip.

Drinkability:
As a beer geek and a coffee nut, I could drink this all day. Ive definitely had it with my breakfast before. Its lighter than a coffee stout, and as a result significantly more drinkable.

16 oz. can. Pours a rich garnet with a small head. Aroma and flavor both hold really excellent mocha and espresso, touches of roast, and awesome balance. Just delicious; who needs irish coffee when you can just drink cans of this?
Sampled at ABR this fall.  A very nice coffee beer, although I am not a huge fan of coffee myself. haha

Serving: 16 oz. can from JCB.  Thanks Jason!  It pours a very dark brown with a foamy, tan head.  The nose black coffee and roasted malt.  The flavor is heavy on the coffee and fantastic.  Lots of roasty malt with a slight nuttiness.  Medium to full bodied with average carbonation leading to a long, coffee finish.  True to its name, its a solid brown ale with a heavy coffee addition.

Canette de 500 ml, dégustée côte-à-côte avec une Bender régulière. Arômes très intenses et complexes de grains de café et de malt grillé. Robe brune aux reflets roux, effervescence moyenne et légère dentelle. En bouche, on retrouve les caractéristiques de la Bender régulière (malt grillé, chocolat, caramel brûlé). Ceux-ci sont accompagnés dun très aromatique café, qui est cependant moins intense quau nez. Cette version présente également une texture légèrement plus huileuse que la version régulière. Finale présentant une amertume de houblon herbacé. Une très bonne bière pour les amateurs de café.

My favorite Coffee Brown Ale (not to be confused with Coffee Stouts) this beer has a nice coffee and brown ale nose. It pours a light brown with a touch of off white head. This beer is a very good balance between beer and coffee. If you have access I suggest you grab a 4 pack.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2011 Tap at SurlyFest. Pours a deep coffee brown (obviously) with a creamy head. Taste for this coffee non-liker was the best part of coffee without the yucky aftertaste. As someone who doesnt drink coffee, I am shocked at how much I enjoyed this beer.  Would definitely buy this again.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2013 Date: September 8, 2011 Mode: Can Source: Blue Max Appearance: Semi-opaque dark brown with red at edges, good amount of head and some lacing. Aroma: Coffee and nutty. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, thin to medium bodied, smooth, slight bitter finish and coffee aftertaste.  Other: Very good offering from Surly, coffee to the max, wish it had a little more body and more complex flavor though.

February 3, 2012 - had again during the super bowl and man this is good.  Bumped taste up 1 to get me to 4.0.

Serving glass: Poured from can into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Very dark brown with a reddish tint. Nice cream colored head and decent lacing.

Aroma: Espresso beans, dark chocolate and caramel.

Taste: Mix of semi-sweet coffee and chocolate, with some caramel and nuts just barely making an appearance. Lingering bitter coffee and American hops at the finish that seem almost too harsh in comparison to the initial balance and smoothness.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium body, almost too thin for a Coffee Ale but very smooth.

Overall: Nice, fairly easy to drink Coffee Ale, but I prefer the complexity of the standard Bender. Also, not quite in the same league as Founders Breakfast Stout and Bells Java Stout, but very good nonetheless.

Can at clyxs. Gothenburg, September 2011. Big thanks to Steve (fbm115) for sending me this amazing beer.

Pours dark mahogany-brown with a airy beige coloured head. Aromas of cream coffee, coffee candy, some chocolate and maltieness is apparent but the coffee is the dominant ingredient. The nose is quite soft with a dash of sweetness. The body is medium to light and it actually feels refreshing - just like the ice coffee that the can advertises! In terms of tastes it feels just right, the sweetness is not overpowering and the bitterness is under control. Its dominated by coffee throughout the whole experience with small fragrances of nuts and nougat. Dry finish. Another fantastic beer from Surly!

Aroma: Holly crap, is like a coffee drink with nougat.
Taste: Coffee, hazelnut and caramel.
Mouthfeel: Smooth, light, dry.
Notes: Great session beer, easy drinking and very balanced.

Pours black with a thick mocha head...pretty decent lacing.  Aroma has coffee and coffee...oh and a bit of roastiness, milkiness and some delicate hops that smell like tea leaves...and coffee.  Flavor has roasted malt and loads of...COFFEE!...also a bit of spicy hoppiness. Mouthfeel is silky but somewhat thin and the mouthfeel is roasty and lingering.  They nailed the coffee thing here for sure.

How early is too early to drink a beer on a tuesday??? 1030 AM, eh... Clear Dark brown touch of amber, tan head, fades medium, returns upon agitation... nice lacing... Black coffee, some mild chocolate notes, smells like a cup of coffee, lightly creamy, roasty, just a touch sweet, smells like it should look  milky brown... Coffee, but not bitter or sweet, lightest touch of fruitiness, roasty, lightly lactic perhaps, a little weighty mouthfeel, medium bodied, very very good, lively....

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 Received in trade from GPHarris, thanks for the opportunity! Pours a deep brown with garnet highlights when held to light. Tightly bubbled beige head shows moderate retention and lace. Smells like freshly ground coffee beans mostly. I try to find something else in the aroma but the coffee is overpowering my olfactory system. Taste really follows the aroma. Upfront I get bitter roasted coffee, midway through I get a hint of sugary sweetness (cream maybe?) finish is a long lingering acridic roasted coffee. Did I mention this tastes like coffee. Medium body and carbonation level, acridic bitter mouthfeel. I will preface this by saying I dont drink coffee. I enjoy some beer with coffee flavors or with coffee added, but this one is to far over the top for me. I cant find the beer underneath the coffee. One and done on this one.
Poured from the can.  Looked and smelt like an iced coffee, real tasty as well.  Had a nice balance coffee and bitterness.  A good drink to starrt off the morning for a tailgate.

16 oz. can from Dalzale, thanks!  pours a dark brown with some reddish hints and a creamy tan head.  nice dark roast nose with similar taste.  has that high end coffee flavor without a lot of bitterness.  medium carbonation and medium-thin palate.  good stuff!

Tallboy can from internet vendor, poured into Boddingtons english pint glass.  Hazy reddish-brown liquid with a thin white head.  Aroma is spectacularly coffee-y...seriously does not smell at all of beer, but *purely* coffee, and a very dark robust bean at that.  Flavor is similar, with a powerful shot of coffee up front and just a slight twinge of malts at the back.  Surprisingly watery and thin in body, palate is a weak point for this otherwise good brew.

16oz canned on June 8, 2011.  Served at around 45F.

Pours dark brown with a two finger light brown head that retains very well and leaves some spots of lacing behind.

Aroma is toast, bread, coffee with cream, toffee, brown sugar, nuts, caramel, a little chocolate, a touch of grassy hops.  Very good strength.

Flavor is coffee, dark bread & toast, nuts, caramel, toffee, some grassy hops on the finish.  Mild sweetness and some light bitterness at the end.

Mouthfeel is light-medium bodied with good carbonation.

An excellent Brown Ale.  The coffee is part of the supporting cast and is not the star of the show like some other coffee beers.  Exceptionally tasty and drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2015 Can from a generous trader. Pours dark brown, almost black. Tan head.  Nose of smoked malt, freshly brewed coffee and roasted barley. Taste is the same. Lots of freshly brewed coffee. Creamy mouth feel. The closest beer to drinking an ice coffee that Ive had. Full to medium body.

A tasty variety of a great brown ale (imo). I have always thought it was unusual for this beer to be a year round offering from Surly, but is a good change of pace. Pours a beautiful color with great aroma, obvious notes of coffee with the usual brown ale very prevalent in the back.

Poured from a can into a largeSam Adams perfect pint glass. Thanks to Mattyb83 for this one!

Aroma- smells of coffee and roasted malts.

Appearance- Pours a deep brown with over an inch of head, great retention and lacing.

Taste- very similar to the aroma, lots of coffee and dark malts. Very nice, as the coffee is well integrated into the base beer.

Palate- very pleasant on the tongue, no alcohol presence at all. 

Overall- very nice beer! A quality choice to fix the coffee beer craving without drinking a big stout. One of the better brown ales out there.

Very good coffee brown ale.  The coffee flavor has lots of juicy fruit flavor, and the brown ale has a great nutty maltiness.  Its creamy and a touch acidic on the palate.  Not too much bitterness.  Im not normally a big coffee beer fan, but this is a nice one.

Can. Darker khaki head; murky dark cola brown  Fresh, bitter coffee in the aroma, some malty sweetness, some dark fruits, and caramel in the aroma. Nice coffee up front, but not overly dominant, quite bitter actually.  Devoid of any real chocolate notes, but malty and slightly sweet.  Bitter coffee finish.  Thinner to medium body, but the carbonation seems a bit too low on this.  Pretty easy drinking.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2013 Can from AV3, nice dark brown with a red hue, tan head with a bit of lacing. Scent is all coffee with a super dark roast aroma. Taste is some nice coffee, malt and a decent bitter, outstanding coffee beer.

Courtesy of DalzAle.  Poured dark brown with a nice off white head.  Excellent retention, left lots of lace.  Aroma was straight up freshly ground coffee beans.  Some cocoa notes and lightly roasted malts crept in.  Flavors were dominated with big coffee notes, espresso like bitter finish.  Smooth all around.  Left a great aftertaste.  Easily the best coffee infused beer I have come across.  Nice!
Can on the RBSG bus trip. Pours brown with a beige head. Big coffee aroma with roasted malts. The flavor is lightly roasty with coffee and espresso. Nice.

16oz can.  Pours a dark brown color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, nutty, coffee.  A little thin on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is bitter, nutty, malt, with a nice bitter coffee finish.  A very good coffee beer, and not a stout too.

Can from mtjoseph.  Aroma is nutty, roasty, good dose of fresh coffee, some caramel.  Pours a dark brown, almost opaque, 1/2" of off-white head, few minutes of retention and some lacing.  Flavor starts off with coffee, lots of it.  Nice roast character, nutty and toasty, caramel and chocolate malts.  Firm bitterness, not a great deal of hop flavor though, as the roast and coffee dominate.  Some up-front sweetness but the finish is fairly dry.  Medium body and carbonation, coffee and roast character is a bit astringent, but it all comes together pretty well.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 Can from TheAlum.  All the great qualities of Bender plus... aroma bursting with fresh coffee.  Very well-rounded coffee with that little hint of vanilla and brown sugar.  Little to no coffee acidity.  Smooth, with lingering roast coffee.
Big coffee grounds aroma. Followed through on the taste. Pours black with a nice espresso foam. Some chocolate notes too. A really enjoyable beer.

Bottle shared at DLD. Pours dark brown but with a slight red tint and a large bubbly tan head. Aroma is almost of pure roasted malts with notes of burnt sugar, caramel, walnuts, and of course, coffee. Flavor is of bitter roasted coffee with a sweet caramel and vanilla finish. Light/medium bodied, very good.

A - Pours a dark brown-red color with a big finger of off-white head. The head fades slowly down to a thin layer leaving some nice lacing on the glass in the process.

S - Aroma is full of a mix of sweet caramel malts and roasted coffee. There is also a bit of chocolate and nuttiness mixed in as well.

T - Starts off with a hit of sweet caramel malt sand some nutty flavor. The coffee flavor starts off super mild, but builds up as the beer goes on. Through the middle, the coffee flavor explodes with a lot of roasted flavor and a touch of coffee bitterness. The finish is a mix of roasted coffee flavor and some sweet caramel malts that lingers really nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth and fairly crisp. The roasted coffee flavor really and coasts the mouth and lingers long after the beer finishes.

D - Very drinkable. The added coffee flavors are really strong and excellent on top of the brown ale. Everything feels right in place and mixes very well together.
Pours s dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is roasted malt. Caramel. Nuts, hoppyness. Taste is alot of roasted coffee. Hops, caramel and licorace. Overall a pretty tasty brown ale.

Can. Pours dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is coffe and mollasses with a surprising amount of hop influence. Flavor is mollasses and toffee up front and fades into bitter coffee and chocolate. Body is medium. Good beer.

Pours seriously dark brown with a huge fluffy beige head. Aroma is burnt caramel and a bunch of coffee. Flavor is chocolatey and like creamy coffee with an excellent balancing bitterness. Body is light and actually kind of refreshing. Kind of like sweetened iced coffee. Very tasty.

Poured from 16oz can, pours a dark brown with a nice off white head and lacing, aroma was full of malt with a kick of coffee, the flavor was very smooth with coffee and a finish of vanilla, another great beer from Surly, can these guys do any wrong?!

Can shared at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the Share. Dark brown with small head that retained. Not as much coffee coming through as I would have thought. Excellent brown ale backbone to this beer. Would like to try some more furious.

Someone came along and shared this one with us a DLD, Very nice and easy drinking coffee beer. It has a nice aroma of a coffee smell and the taste is similar, coffee up front with a nice malty finish from your typical brown ale, Overall nice offering.

I was walking around at Dark Lord Day at 3 Floyds in Munster, IN when I saw a can of this sitting on a random table.  Drunkenly, I asked the person sitting at the table if I could have some since I havent had this stuff in a couple years, and he graciously obliged and poured me about 4 oz of this fantastic brew.  Appearance a coffee like brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma of pure dark roast coffee with bit of lactose.  Taste of roasted malt and coffee very smooth but rich, highly enjoyable, cant wait to go back to MPLS to have this again.

16oz can poured into a pint glass.

AROMA: Malt, roasted coffee, hint of chocolate.
APPEARANCE: Coffee colored with very nice cream head.
TASTE: Roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, light bitterness. 
PALATE: Medium bodied, creamy texture, lingering coffee taste.
OVERALL:   Great go to beer.

16oz can, gotta love canned beer! I was lead to believe that this particular beer was perhaps a little bit light on the  body and coffee flavor. I may have been given false information because I really enjoyed this beer, and plan on enjoying the other 3 that came in the 4 pack. Dark pour with a thin bubbly off white khaki head. Slight lacing. Aroma packs a good coffee punch with touches of vanilla. Flavor is a little bit bitter but the coffee and chocolate come to rescue. It was more then just a decent coffee beer, but in fact a great one.

deep dark, opaque brown ale with a huge fluffy head. This is very warm in flavor, like a hot coffee, bitter chocolate, too, but still sweet. A very positive, warm beer. Hard to describe, but its very warming. I love that there is this much coffee flavor without it being overly high in the ABV department. Thanks via trade from DalzAle

Can courtesy of Tyloanderso: Glad I got to have this on the same day I tried the Bender, Remarkable what a difference the coffee makes in this one. Aroma is just fabulous, hitting the spot for this coffee lover, smelling like a fine espresso. Probably the most "coffee" aroma Ive had. Flavor is a little deeper than the regular Bender, with such an interesting coffee note that is miles apart from coffee being used in a stout or porter. Finishes smooth, with little bitterness.

The beer is a very dark fown with about a finger and half of light tan head that fades way to quickly. The lacing is good. As the head fades it sticks to the sides like a shadow from the past. 

The aroma is combination of wood and coffee, but despite these two normally dominating aromas the aroma overall is pretty light.

The taste is very light and somewhat disappointing because it is pretty flavorless. If it wasnt called coffee bender I wouldnt even think of coffee and be able to pick any out of it. To me its tastes like a light fun of the mill brown ale.

The mouthfeel is heavy and lasting but because of its blandness its not very drinkable, not because its filing but because its just bland.

On tap @ Happy Gnome. Dark black appearance with a tan head. Dark roasty coffee, dark malty nose. Deep black coffee flavor with dark malts but actually fairly light bodied. Coffee grounds texture is undesirable.

Pours a hazy coffee color with a frothy off-white head.

It smells like coffee, I have never had a beer that smells prety much 100% liek coffee like this before. i am not a coffee drinker but I enjoy most coffee beers, this one smells like it could be cold, carbonated, alcoholic coffee.

It tastes just like coffee too, Im not a fan of coffeee but this is somewhat tolerable. It literally tastes like coffee, thar bitter, roasty, but almost fruity flavor.

Overall it is decent, kinda gives you a stomach ache.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 07-16-2010 23:41:20

Smell is pure weak cheap coffee after its been sitting in the pot all day and someone turned the pot off cause they thought no way will anybody drink this but it was still a little warm and you were desperate.  Pours a pretty frothy head settles to a nice lacing.  Gorgeous (really) magenta brown color.  Tastes like good but weak coffee with caramel malt sweetness and medium light body.  Would prefer more body...seems like beer was just diluted with coffee.  Nice ale though...probably wouldnt buy again though just on the price 13.50 for a 4 pack!

From notes:

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color with a two and a half finger frothy beige head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves large chunks of soapy mocha lacing behind.

Roasted malt aroma with tons of fresh ground coffee bean along with hints of chocolate, caramel, hazelnut and toffee in the nose.

Medium bodied with some tight carbonation up front that smooths out mid-palate. Very roasty wiu a huge coffee bean presence but this beer is never to acrid or dry. There is planety of rich chocolate maltiness as well as some caramel, toffee and nut to balance things out. Well balanced, complex, delicious and very quaffable. Recommended, especially for breakfast!

As per Surlys suggestion, poured into a mug. Big thanks to OHLRangers for this one.

4.5 A: Dark brown color with one and a half fingers of thick creamy light brown head. Great retention (especially for having coffee involved) and tons of lacing.

4.0 S: Smells quite a bit like the original, with a coffee vibe added. Roastiness with a pleasant nuttiness to it. Coffee works well with the other aromas and doesnt detract. However, all the smells could be stronger.

4.5 T: Just like the regular, this is one hell of a brew. Nuttiness and roastiness found in the original mesh eloquently. Pretty simple, but it works marvelously. The addition of coffee only improves the beer. Flavorful, but not so much that the other flavors are less discernable.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body, closer to light. Good carbonation, creamy (but could be more so), and smooth as silk.

4.5 D: If the mouthfeel was a bit thicker, this would be pretty close to a perfect brown. The way it stands, its still very good and I could go through a number of these with no problem. Man do I love Surly brews.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 03-21-2010 23:36:18

A dark amber-brown pour with tan head.  There is no mistaking the coffee in the aroma, but there is also some dark chocolate mixed in.  The medium body has a slightly creamy texture with soft carbonation.  The initial sweet tastes disappears quickly, leaving a roasted coffee taste.  This is one of the only coffee beers that I can tolerate.

Pours dark brown.  Coffee, malts, and caramel in the nose, biscuit.  Taste is caramelly, biscuit, toast, coffee, Taste is dry overall but has some sweetness in the start.  Good beer but the coffee is very strong and pronounced.

Tasted on 12/31/10 from a 16oz can purchased at Discount Liquor, no date anywhere on the can.  Pours hazy dark amber with a very thick beige head that slowly recedes to uneven lace.  The nose is freshly roasted coffee with a hint of chicory, and just a bit of caramel, I assume from the malt.  The flavor is brown malt with chocolate up front, and then moving to the freshly roasted coffee bitterness, and a bitter chicory and endive flavor.  There is also a good amount of acidity in this beer, and something almost savory.  The body is light with average carbonation and a long bitter and acidic finish.
can thanks to somebody.  poured dark brown/ruby with a beige head.  aroma was coffee and brownie.  flavor was coffee, fudge, and chocolate.  light body with medium carbonation.

Im not a huge fan of brown ales, but if theres one way to make em awesome, its throw some coffee in em. This had a nice aroma - in addition to the coffee, there was a nice vanilla ice note to it, as well. Flavor was rich and full bodied, with a lot of coffee (but not too much) and vanilla. Thanks to grownfool for this one!

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 A: Dark brown with some reddish hue; tan head and good lacing.

S: Brown malts overshadowed by plenty of coffee notes.

T: Lots of coffee and a little bit of a hop presence. The coffee provides a little bit of earthiness.

M: Medium bodied and fairly dry.

D: The coffee is a bit overwhelming for too many, but the can my wife and I shared was gone rather quickly.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 10-01-2009

16 oz. can thanks to Skyview. A dark brown beer with a small head. The aroma is nice, like a pot of coffee in the morning or anytime you make coffee, and is also a little chocolatey. The taste has a nice coffee flavor, perfectly balanced roasted coffee and even some baked chocolate bread. Creamy mouthfeel and if you like coffee youll love this. This beer makes me say "Surely you love Surly". And if the people at Surly are reading this then please-BRING SURLY TO TEXAS.
Can. Pours dark brown.mahogany with medium tan head and good lacing. Aroms is fresh coffee with some malty notes. Flavor is slightly bitter with big coffee flavor, some caramel in the background.

Tall can - thanks bro for delivering it across state lines!  Pours a lovely reddish brown mahogany color with little head.  Aroma is completely sweet coffee.  Taste is a disappointing watery, subtle coffee flavor, without much other flavor to it.  Slightly salty perhaps.  Very little aftertaste remaining, with just a slight burn.  Perhaps too many coffee porters/stouts where I am expecting more body and depth?  Brown ale is not one of my favorite styles as I consider it too blah.  The coffee promises a lot up front, but in the end, still a brown and somewhat blah.

500ml can thanks to tbadiuk.
Appearance : Black with a medium creamy brown head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Lots of coffee. Very roasty. Like putting my nose in a fresh coffee jar. Light bitterscotch.

Taste : Lots of fresh coffee with light butterscotch. Finish is very roasted with a light coffee bitterness. 

Overall :  Very nice nose. Taste is not as good as the nose was leading to but its still very good. This is the most coffee oriented nose Ive had so far. Another great beer from Surly. I have yet to be disappointed by them !
You have to love coffee to enjoy this beer. It is a hard hitting coffee on the front end that is thin and lasts throughout. I am not a fan.

Brown color.  Some nice tan  head with spotty lacing left behind around the glass

Aroma is dominated by dark coffee. Flavor follows along very closely - it really tastes almost exactly like a nice dark iced coffee - possibly even more coffee-like than beer-like.  Moderate bitterness in the finish.

Nice light & thin mouthfeel with the right level of carbonation.  Very drinkable.  This stuff is delicious.  This is not the first time Ive had it and it certainly will not be the last.

YUM!

16 oz. can from Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI.  Pours brown (duh) with a creamy off-white head.  The aroma is pure roasted coffee.  The taste is exactly what you would expect; a brown ale with rich roasted coffee.  I typically find brown ales boring but the coffee really adds a lot to this one.  Well done.

16oz can from ericandersnavy--Sweet!!!&  Poured a dark brown body that was ruby highlit.  Tight, off-white head that left some lacing.  Aromas of creamy iced-coffee, fudge and lightly malt sweet.  Flavors are smoooooth coffee icee, light coffee bitterness, lightly sweet and some cocoa.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.

Aroma: would like more coffee in this area
Apperance: Great lacing around the glass as consumed yellow white head
Taste: Need more coffee flavor.  This doesnt seem to be much different than the regular bender.
Palate: Excellently rounded beer as surly is not shy about throwing hops into the kettle.
Overall: would like more coffee aspect to separate itself from the regular surly bender.

Can courtesy of Tangfoot from TBS.  Thanks!  This is pretty awesome....interesting mix of flavors.  Has the coffee throughout, obviously, but actually has noticeable "cream" flavor to it as well.  Very tasty, nice and creamy.

On tap at a few places in Minneapolis. Pours a dark brown body with a few reddish hues. Inch thick, dense and creamy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma has lots of fresh coffee up front. When this warms up a bit, some nice roasts, caramels, and toffee brown malts come out. A light chocolate, nuts, and vanilla. Flavor is similar. Lots of fresh, espresso coffee with a nice, rich brown maltiness. Caramel, chocolate, roast, vanilla, some biscuit, and a light earth. Finishes dry and lightly bitter with lots of coffee and a nice earthy roast. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium, somewhat watery body at times and a moderate, creamy carbonation. Overall, although I like the standard "Bender" a bit better, this was still a solid beer. Nice coffee flavor with enough of a standard brown malt backing to make this quite enjoyable.

i could smell the coffee as i poured this. dark brown with a thick pale tan head that lasts. smells of sweet cream and coffee, some smoked turkey with a perfect roast scent.  flavor is nice, with a sweet coffee and and light pecan taste. mouthfeel is a bit thin. grape and plum in the finish. some milk chocolate in the finish that keeps this going. although i prefer a black cup of coffee this is enjoyable. a nice light porter.
Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, caramel and toffee. Sweetish caramel flavour witth chocolate and coffee. Flavour not quite in harmony for me

On tap.  Pour is dark brown with a small off white head.  Coffee is strong in the aroma with chocolate and oats present as well.  Tastes of coffee with some chocolate.  Fairly dry with a small bitter finish.  Great balance, and a great example of the coffee beer.

Poured from a can.  Dark brown with an off white head. Intense roast coffee aroma.  Roast malt.  Bitterring hops.  Nice roast malt flavor with distinct coffee to the end.  Nice balance.  Medium body.  Overall, an excellent coffee brown ale.

16oz can courtesy of maximum12. thanks, corey! pours a clear brown with a two-finger, light beige head and sticky lacing. aroma is great with huge, fresh, roasted coffee, chocolate, charred almonds, and earthy hops with hints of sweet cream. flavor is damn tasty as well but not as intense as the aroma with big, fresh, cold coffee, cocoa powder, and toasted malts with hints of green hops, smoke, and burnt grains. palate is medium bodied with solid carbonation and a long, lingering, coffee finish. overall, a very nice, very coffee forward brew.

Can thanks to Ben! Pours a clear brown with a grayish brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of roasted coffee with just a slight grain backing. Flavor starts a bit more mellow with grain and bread but the roasted coffee quickly takes over for a nice finish.
can - dark chocolate, coffee grinds. Thin body, not great but drinkable. earthy bitterness.

Pours a light brown color with medium off-white head.  Aroma is coffee, light caramel malts, and a bit of hoppiness.  Taste is light and refreshing, coffee up front with some caramel malts and light hoppiness.

Easy 5 for appearance, a nice brown hue with head and lacing that cling forever.  Slightly nutty, coffee, modest sweetness, bitter finish.  Really, really good stuff, this is the first time Ive had a can of Coffee Bender that really amazed me but I am pleased to have it.

(can, courtesy of Andrew; sampled 4/10/10). Dark brown color. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Strong roasted coffee aroma. Flavor of the same. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin/slick texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
16 oz. can.  My favorite coffee beer out there.  Just a refreshing easy drinking brew that tastes like black coffee.  I could drink these for breakfast.  Keep em coming!
Can. Pours a clear and dark burgundy beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, cold coffee and sweetness. The flavor follows the nose closely. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer.

Can. No doubt this is a coffee beer. It tastes like coffee with sugar and cream. Brown, approaching black body with a frothy, tan head. The aroma has notes of mild coffee, milk chocolate, roast, sweet cream. The flavor is lightly to moderately bitter and lightly to moderately sweet. It finishes lightly sweet and modaretely bitter. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Nicely balanced beer, though a bit too sweet. I am not sure I would drink more than one can of it at a sitting, but that one can is good  sweet coffee with a bitter finish from the roast and hops. A nice after-dinner beer.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2013 16oz can.  Pretty close to 14 bucks a four-pack, ouch.  Brown-black, with a massive beige head.  Pronounced coffee aroma, not so much chocolate as straight up bitter coffee.  Smooth and medium bodied, this is indeed a great coffee-beer, despite the price that only a MN-homer could love.  Mellow, soft carbonation.  Coffee and chocolate tones, maybe some soft vanilla.  Quite well executed, this is very drinkable while being unapologetically and unmistakably full of coffee.  Worth seeking out.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, nuts and cold coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, light cold coffee and chocolate.

16 oz can courtesy of Greg.  Pours a dark mahogany brown with a medium sized creamy beige head.  Aroma of roasted coffee beans and malts.  Taste is dominated by roasted coffee beans.  Malts present along with hops.

Can 1pt.16fl.oz. @ home.[ Courtesy of Summer Secret Santa ]. Clear medium to dark red brown color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate malt, coffee, coffe dusty, moderate hoppy, dusty. Flavor is moderate to light light heavy sweet and light heavy bitter with a long duration, coffee, cold coffee. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100723]

16 oz can

After lurking for a month in the back of the fridge I cracked one of two cans open on a steaming hot afternoon. It not only hit the spot it made me wish I had not given two away. Well rounded, easy on the palate, and not too boozy that you could not have a few without wrecking the palate, this is the perfect summer / early fall drink. If Surly was ever in Ohio I would definitely be recommending it to people (and not just because of things like Darkness and Smoke).

Aroma / Appearance - Carbonated, the black body is offset by lively bubbles that force pockets of flavor to the surface. Strong black coffee wakes up even the dullest senses along with malts and other rich aspects that are somewhat masked. This is not subtle in the least about the "coffee" part of the title.

Flavor / Palate - Black coffee, dark chocolate, and an intense malty finish had me checking the label to make sure this was only 5% ABV. Very strong, balanced, and flavorful this is not a mild or meek beer. Like a toned down version of Breakfast Stout with all the same characteristics it has become one of my favorite brown ales after only a single tasting. I know what I will be getting if I see it on tap in the Minneapolis region.

1 pint can courtesy of a PUBN PLCB sympathizer.  Pours dark brown (mahogany through light) with 2-f clingy ow head that overhangs.  Great look here.  Nose is roasty dark malt, big coffee grounds, hops.  Tastes medium in palate, with a dark malt, coffee, dark choc, somewhat rauchy, and slight molasses.  Smooth and enjoyable,, and man does this one look good.

From trade with KButler1.  Mild pleasant coffee on the nose, some nuttiness, chocolate.  The flavor is again a pleasant smooth coffee flavor, some nuts, toasted malts.  The finish is again smooth coffee flavors, light hoppiness on the end.  Medium in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.  The coffee is not overly roasted, and the beer doesnt have that burnt, ashy quality so common which coffee infused beer.  Excellent overall.  Thanks, Kevin.

Can from a trade with phaleslu. Pours dark brown with khaki head. Aromas of coffee and toasted malts. Coffeee, chocolate and toasted malt flavors. Medium body with soft carbonation. Nice brew. Thanks Peter.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. 
Much more coffee than i was expecting, it doesnt have the bitterness or acridness that most coffee beers get. very smooth, almost like an iced coffee with a hint of beer. really remarkable.

Just finished the regular Bender, time to try the Coffee. Like the standard Bender, this one comes compliments of Skyview, who hooked me up in EPIC fashion for Summer Santa 2010. Pour is virtually identical to the standard Bender, clear brown, thick pale tan head, maybe a shade darker than the standard Bender, again the head is best described as pillowy, though the retention isnt as good as the standard Bender, but again the lacing is just stunning. Aroma is coffee, dark malts, some fruit, really love the addition of coffee here, as I felt the original Benders nose a bit lackluster. Flavor is big and coffeeish, but again with the caramel/malt/fruit balance and gorgeous mouthfeel of the original. Finish is all coffee. Great brown ale.
Huge coffee aroma like a fresh filled filter of coffee grains. Dark black with a thing tan head. Medium bitterness with a bitter finish that lingers a little while.

Thanks to Tharreld for the can!! The pour is very similar to the regular Bender. Deep brownish red with a small head. The aroma has same dusty/toasted quality along with a huge hit of spent coffee grounds. The flavor is the same. Nice toasty malts with some chocolate, nuts, and mild hop astringency. The coffee flavor persists throughout the beer, yet it reminds me more of the leftover dregs in the spent filter more than fresh ground coffee beans. Pretty good though. I could see myself requesting this again. My only complaint is that the body is a little thin, which goes for the regular Bender as well.

From can, courtesy of dpjuart. Nice coffee aroma, bitter grounds on top of light floral hops. Toasted malt and barley, dusty grain. Light caramel. Dark copper brown clear with thin off-white head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts fairly dry with roasted barley and dusty grain, light toasted sweetness and a bit of caramel. Good hoppy notes throughout with a touch of coffee at the finish. Bitter after and a little chalky.
Dark, heavy coffee notes, nice head w/lacing.  Great mouth feel subdued hop character
Can, via trade with ketchepillar, opaque reddish brown pour , thin tan foam, aroma of coffee, tootsie roll, vanilla, flavors of coffee, malted milk balls, vanilla cream, finiish is somewhat light

A-pours a deep brown color with hints of red on the edges, very hazy with particles floating around.  light tan head that is quite thick and creamy in appearance, decent retention with very little lace.

S-lots of caramel right up front, notes of carmelized brown sugar and a hint of molasses.  sweet with hints of coffee and a touch of dark fruits.

T-molasses and burth brown sugar up front with a good bit of caramel malt as a base.  roasted, slightly burnt coffee with a strong hop presence in the finish with floral esters.

M-extremely smooth but medium to thin body that falls off in the back and feels a little watery.  almost no carbonation at all.

D-smooth and thin, more like a strong ale, some balance and a light coffee notes.

Lovely dark ruby beer.
Aroma of roasted and ground coffee. Coffee flavour, too. Nothing much beneath this, a little caramel.

Dark brown pour with foamy white/tan head.  Huge coffee aroma.  For someone who likes coffee and dark beer a MUST try.  Personally I enjoy an occassional bender but the coffee bender really adds balance to the complex cocoa flavors of its original counterpart.  One of my absolute favorites, worth the extra $2 a four pack over the original.

Sampled on 5/21/2010. This brown ale pours a medium brown color from a 16oz can. Medium sized tan foamy head, with good lacing and nice retention. The aroma is caramel, coffee, nutty and sweet. A medium bodied brown ale. The malts are caramel, fruity, nutty and sweet. The coffee flavor is pervasive yet not obtrusive. The hops are earthy and floral. Nice carbonation. The coffee and malt mix well in this beer. Subtle and interesting beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Pours a clear amber color with a dark brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roast, and sweet chocolate.  Flavor is caramel, chocolate, coffee, roast, toast, earthy, and a light spicy finish.

Ruddy brown pour with massive beige, creamy head. Aroma huge is coffee beans and earthy hops. Simply massive aroma. Flavor of dry coffee beans, grass, pine and earth. Burnt sugar in the finish. Slightly bitter.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2013 The aroma of coffee and malts with a ruby coffee color and decent head. The flavor is notes of coffee but settles on my palate like iced tea, which is probably from the steeping of the whole beans. Rerating: The coffee flavors complement the brown ale malts really well! The beer pours dirty brown, but good for the style with a big creamy beige head.

16oz can courtesy of MikeTD. First off the smell on this one was huge roasted coffee beans and caramel. It poured a deep dark brown with a medium cream head. Taste was COFFEE, chocolate, COFFEE, caramel and more COFFEE. Mostly malty like Brown Ales should be but there was some hoppiness going on their as well. Great brew, now I just wish Ohio would get some Surly.

Um.....Im kind of disappointed and Im surprised I am so far in disagreement with the general site rating. The color was like a muddy nut brown, a very thin but foamy head disapated and left some nice looking lacing. The aroma offered slight toasted malt and coffee. The taste was actually pretty weak in the coffee dept. I got the malt but it was off and funky, a little metalic grape taste came through too. The body was really light and watery. This feels like a cross between a stale Newcastle and an old guinness out of the bottle with some used coffee grounds mixed in. Maybe Ive got a bad can- I would love to give this another shot but Im only going out on that limb if its on tap. Oh well, based on what I know of Surly, this is not the norm and Ill defnitely be trying all else that is Surly when the opportunity arises.
Can from StFun. Thanks Josh! Pours brown with off-white head. Aroma is mocha and brown malt. Coffee persists throughout. Solid beer.

Can.  Pours clear brown with a medium, creamy tan head, good retention.  Aroma is coffee, coffee, coffee; light caramel malt, all other aromas are negligible.  Flavor is coffee, bitter hops and coffee, and medium malt.  Medium body, moderate carbonation.

A- Body is a somewhat hazy medium brown hue. Pours with an approximately 1 finger fizzy off-white head that pretty much fades to a thin collar immediately-but has good retention from there.

S-Big nose of rich caramel malt, toffee, molasses, and a bit of roasted malt to balance and give it that coffee character.

T-Flavor is not as exciting as the nose. Upfront the main character is toffee and a hint of molasses is in there as well. It has a bit of a coffee impression but nothing huge. The finish is sweeter than the initial flavor.

P- Light to medium drinkable body with a feel that is smooth and creamy.

O- This is a nice, light, drinkable coffee brew. Not my favorite by Surly but still a very solid, well put together brew.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 04-01-2010 18:27:46

Can @ Papsø. Thanks. Pours unclear dark brown with small bubbles on top. Nose is roast and caramel. Flavor is coffee bean and roast. Quite mild with some caramel on the side. Smooth and full bodied. Ends dry. Really liked this. Very tasty!
Clear mahogany with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, coffee and caramel notes. Flavour had roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and hoppy hints. Finished dry and bitter.

Tasting at Papsø, canHazy dark mahogany color. Mild aroma, some roasted malt and coffee (the coffee that you brewed yesterday). Slim mouthfeel, dry dark caramel, burnt sugar and coffee flavor; the final is not strong, but it just has burnt malts and ashes. Even if aroma and flavor are not too strong, they are clearly not what I like.

Canned. Dark reddish brown coloured. Small light brown head. Aroma of light coffee, light chocolate, teabag and sweetness. Flavour of herbs, light coffee, light butter and cocoa. Surprisingly thin bodied. Grassy bitterness in the end.

clear amber, small offwhite to yellow  head.
aroma of coffee, caramel, toffee, faint hoppy.
flavor is caramel, coffee, malts, faint roasted note. ends coffee, roasted, bitter.

Can 50 cl. Courtesy of SecretSanta. Pours a clear reddish brown with a beige head. Distinct and very dry coffee accents in the nose - espresso style. Medium body, sweet roasted malt and vanilla again with distinct coffee notes. Dryish but not overly bitter finish. 230410

16oz can scored via trade.  Pours a watery although opaque black with a thin, creamy, slightly cloudy beige head.  The aroma is a nice mix of approachable coffee and sweet malts with a touch of nuttiness.  Flavor is again well balanced between medium roast coffee and sweet malts.  Tastes a bit like a cup of coffee with turbinado sugar.  Theres a distinct brown sugar sweetness as well.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet finish.  Theres a bit of creaminess to the mouthfeel that combined with the sweet finish makes one thing of a good, not overly sweet, coffee ice cream.

Can. Deep murky brown colour with small off-white head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, some slight ashes as well as mild earthy and wooden notes. Flavour is coffee, spices, some mild fruity hops as well as mild honeyish and wooden notes as well. Interesting and nice brown ale...

Draft @ Hackneys Chicago, IL. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty coffee aroma with hints of caramel. Roasted malty caramel and coffee flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty coffee finish with hints of caramel in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2010 Can shared by SoLan. Pours dark brown color with a beige head. Nose is full of roasted espresso coffee. Flavors are big on the coffee again, nice and rich flavors, creamy and ends with a nice bitterness from the coffee. Would be a great breakfast beer and love that it comes in a can.

Pint can from trade.  This is one unique and interesting brown. Pours a DARK brown cola colour with a medium tan head and foamy lacing. Big aroma of milk chocolate and roasted coffee. The flavour is complex coffee with not only the taste but the bitterness from the beans. The coffee doesnt overpower everything else though. Well done.

From the can. About time I got some of this one. Pours brown (obviously) with a very stiff head, laces very well. Aroma is espresso. Flavor of smoked wood chips and french roast coffee, but it overpowers the beer--I miss the subtler sweet, nutty notes of the brown ale. Finishes a little sour and leaves behind the good bitter aftertaste of coffee. Pretty dang good coffee beer.

Can. Pours a dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is subdued coffee and roasted malt. Flavor is right away iced coffee, some malt in the background. Finish is bitter, but fittingly so. I really enjoyed this, thankfully I have more to enjoy in the future.
Pint can courtesy StFun.  Wow huge coffee in the flavor and aroma... Some chocolates hanging out in there too. Very nice.
pours a rich dark dark red. nice roasted coffee aroma with a hint of sweet.  very tangy and bitter tasting.  definately getting the coffee flavor. decent feel and goes down smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2010 can. Pour is deep brown with red hues in light minimal head which leaves a ring around glass. Scents of toasted malt and strong coffee. Taste is spice malt and coffee which finishes dry. This is one of my favorite beers from surly out of the can. The coffee is what gets me with this brown ale style beer.

Pint-size can, courtesy of MatSciGuy. Thanks, Levi! Pours a dark brown color with thin golden edges; creamy, medium-tan head with excellent, glistening lacing. Very charismatic, iced-coffee aroma: lots of roasted coffee, bitter chocolate; well-restrained sweetness; really nice nose on this. Medium body: average carbonation, moderately creamy, non-astringent; Im not usually the biggest fan of coffee beers, and the character here is much closer to an iced, milky coffee character than the heavily roasted presence in other beers, but this presence works great for the Bender base: milky iced coffee, caramel, very light roast, and lots of lightly bitter chocolate; almost a milky, iced presence overall, with a very solid, moderately hopped (minerals, mostly; much of the bitterness comes through from the coffee and specialty malts) brown ale core; Ive always been a huge fan of bender, and while I generally prefer the base beer, this is a pretty lovely rendition as well; nicely handled. Long finish of iced coffee, bitter chocolate, and hints of cocoa; balanced ending.

Courtesy Eric.  Pours a muddy brown with red hues and a filmy, 1/4 inch tan head.  Smells of coffee oils, roast and brown sugar.  Great lacing.  Roasty coffee flavor balanced with subtle brown sugar sweetness.  Some oily, coffee flavor tries to poke through, but no such luck, the mild bitter cuts it off at the knees.Easy drinking, smooth and viscous.  Solid after of coffee and brown sugar.  Just an all around good beer.

Poured out of a can into a tulip. Deep brown color with a thick tan head. Strong rich coffee aroma (delish). Body is silky smooth. Taste of roasted malts strong coffee bitter finish on the palate. Delicious brew for being in a can.

Small brown head. Dark red body. Intense rich coffee grounds aroma, but little beyond that, except perhaps some dark chocolate. Dry dark chocolate and coffee grounds taste with beery fruity notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mouthfeel. Clean and clear taste. Dry wooden coffee aftertaste with rye notes. Funny, but perhaps a small sample is enough.  (0.5l can shared by gr0ve.)

A: The pour is a dark brown color with an initially fluffy tan head.

S: Pretty much what I expected from this one: big time coffee aroma with only some slight undertones of nutty, toasted malts.

T: The flavor profile is pretty much what you would expect from the nose. This is obviously very coffee forward on the flavor with a nice nutty sweetness that you expect from the base brown ale.

M: The mouthfeel is nice, but nothing spectacular. On the light end of medium in terms of body with moderate carbonation.

D: Fantastic coffee beer! This one really just tastes like a cup of coffee, and is just so easy to drink, especially with the lower ABV.

Can shared by GrOve.  A carpet of tan, creamy foam over a clear, dark ruby-brown body. Predominant aroma of coffe, cold coffee and coffe ground. Also a chocolatey malt scent and a whiff of roasted malts. Sourish, coffee dominated taste, coffee ground again, also som roasted dark malts with chocolate and licorice tones. Notes of dusty hops.  Slick in the mouth, but not as smooth as the original Bender. And guess what! Lots of coffee in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Appearance:  Pours a dark brown with a dense khaki layer of creamy foam.

Aroma:  Medium and Dark roast black iced coffee, spent coffee grinds.

Taste: Dunkin donuts coffee, some bread notes, and roasted malt.

Mouthfeel: Thin to medium bodied and fizzy.

Overall:  This beer is good, but didnt capture a great cup of coffee within a good beer.

Dark pour,  Cola-looking from can to glass.  Settles into a dark, cloudy, turbid-looking brown.  Minimal head.  Coffee notes highly prevalent with some hops.  Nice, chewy mouthfeel.  Tastes like it smells- coffee up front with some hop bitterness to match. A little sweet malt with a sweet yet appropriately nicely bitter finish.  Almost like drinking a coffee porter?

Can shared by gr0ve. Cheers! Pours a dark ruby red with a nice tan creamy nitro like head. The aroma took me by surprise. Yeah, I expected coffee, but unlike coffee stouts and porters which are accented by coffee, this smells almost purely coffee. Slightly sour coffeegrounds, actually, like I think larsga said, like a used coffee filter. A hint of dark chocolate is all I could pick up besides the coffee. Flavour is also dominated by slightly sour coffee, some chocolate and a hint of metal. It was definitely interesting, but sour, cold coffee isnt quite my thing. Would have liked a bit more of that chocolate sweetness to balance it out a little.

2 canettes de 16 oz partagées lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez MartinT. Arôme: Odeur de café noir. Apparence: La couleur est brune. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #2851)

Can thanks to DuffManSW.  Brown pour with ruby highlights and a small off-white head.  The aroma is rolled oats, toffee and coffee with some chalky, spicy, noble hops.  The flavor is coffee and milk, oatmeal, maple, and a slightly peppery bitter hop finish.  The body is soft and creamy with a medium-full mouth feel and moderate carbonation.

Thanks to exiled for sharing this can.

Pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is straight coffee with nothing else coming through. The flavor is coffee with some roasted malts. There is a nice bitterness at the end, either from the coffee or from hops. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation. One of the best, most interesting brown ales I have tried.

In short: An successful and original blend of nutty brown and a ton of fresh coffee beans.  Very good beer.
How: Cans 500ml.  A few cans sent to me by a few people.  Thanks traders!!  Consumed relatively fresh a month or two after receiving them.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Clear dark brown body topped by very small beige head
In long: Nose is intensely coffee.  This one doesnt have the type of roasted coffee beans that I get from coffee stouts.  This beer really smells like walking into a coffee shop.  Body is full and creamy and the carbonation is lively.  Really nice mouthfeel.  Malt base is very nutty, some brownies, toasted whole-wheat bread.  That thing really packs a lot of coffee, and it Good to the last drop.

Can! Got in a trade from arminjewell, thanks Armin!
  Aroma: consists of roasted coffee, hazelnut, vanilla, and malty caramel.
  Appearance:  Pours a hazy amber brown with great head retention and nice lacing.  Head is a frothy tan cloud that sticks around for the entire experience. 
  Taste: slightly sweet, then bitter with notes of chocolate that delves immediately into a robust coffee finish. Hints of vanilla and caramel blend the taste out nicely.
  Palate: medium bodied creamy texture with a soft carbonation and long bitter finish.

  Wow, so much pleasure from a beer out of a can, I didnt know it was possible!

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Courtesy of tytoanderso via trade
Can:  The aroma consists of roasted nuts, coffee, hazelnut, and vanilla.  It pours a dark brown with some orange highlighted transparency and a inch tall beige head.  The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel.  The finish has moderate roasted nuts and coffee along with some light-moderate piney hops and a hint of vanilla.  Light-medium bodied with soft carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.

My Bottom Line:
Biscuity and nutty coffee wealth dwells in a beautifully cushy mouthfeel, ending up in a light roasted malt bitterness for a very convincing Coffee Brown Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the ruby-laced brown.
-Even though the coffee flavors are upfront, they blend in wisely with the grain bill.
-The overall flavor profile is more complex than, say, Cigar Citys Espresso Maduro Brown Ale.
-That mouthfeel is something else. These guys are really impressive. 

Can.

( 16oz can thanks to mar)  Pours orange-brown with head that fades fast. Nose of creamy coffee, nice hops; smells great! Taste of lightly bitter hops, coffee with a nice creamy finish thats well carbonated. If this only tasted like it smelled.

Pours an all but opaque black under a creamy light brown head. The nose is coffee and light malt. The first taste is the bitterness of the coffee and that coffee is the dominant flavor. Interestingly, the ordinary brown ale light malt of the Bender base seems to be just about the right to balance this beer in the last half of its trip to the throat. Ive liked this beer since my first, but I never really thought that hard about how it worked until this rating. Its not especially complex: there are some chocolate notes that seem to be the result of the the malt and coffee, but it really just stands firmly on the malt/coffee blend and doesnt demand a lot, but commands respect. Good but not great. Solid and steadfast.
My first brew from Surly and I was definitely not disapointed. Great coffee aroma and taste, add to that the roasty malts and the chocolate and this makes for a hell of a beer.
Late entry from Noogfest High Five.  Light clear brown pour is attractive, as is the can.  Good clean coffee notes.  Not really for me as I dont care for coffee, but good enough to drink
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 9th October 2008. GABF. Smooth palate. Just a nice touch of coffee. Dry finish. Not bitter.

I bought a 4 pack of this on new years eve and am working on my 3rd of that right now.  This beer is very unique and very good.  The regular bender is a good beer, but I think this trumps it.  The coffee is very strong in the nose which is a smell I love so that certainly intriques me and the coffee is definitely highly prevalent in the taste as well.  And Im not talking coffee malts or any of that shit, actual real coffee flavors up in this brew and its quite enticing.  This isnt a beer you could or would want to drink a whole lot of, but its a beer you definitely want to drink here and there.

aroma is stunning crunch of REAL coffee. freshly ground crema floating atop an extremely hot steeping french press. flavor is the crunch of real coffee beans between my teeth: lightly acidic with a well balanced pass of sweetness devoid of cocoa elements. kind of a one trick pony, but a damn fun one at that.

What an excellent addition to the regular bender, the only thing it was missing. Pours dark brown/almost black with off white head.  Taste up front is huge coffee with chocolate undertones, that leads into the malt sweetness of regular bender and finishes bitter from the coffee.  Excellent brew, could have this in the morning instead of coffee!
Pours ruby-brown with a thick beige head. Aroma is roast malt, oat and nut. Taste is rich roasted malt sweetness with a bitter coffee bean finish.

Can shared by JoeTheYounger.  Pours a clear reddish brown with a lasting brown head. Aroma is raw nuts, malt, and yeast.  Flavor is dry and nutty with coffee grinds and some bitterness.  Medium bodied with generous carbonation.

Pours a clear brown color with a good size tan head.  Aroma is of pungent coffee, almost "spent" grounds tossed into it.  Some like caramel is evident as well.  Taste is rich coffee, light chocolate and caramel malt and light floral spice.  Finishes pretty clean and well balanced.  A good offering from Surly.

Can. Pours ruddy brown with a dense light brown head. Aroma and flavour of light roast, caramel and a noticeable coffee hit. Extremely smooth mouthfeel. Slightly dry and roasty with more coffee in the finish. The balance is great and this is very easy to drink and more importantly enjoy. Works well for me, a tasty beer! (RateBeer Sydney Xmas Gathering 2009 - cheers Oslo!)

Creamy, sweet, dry, roasted, this beer really incorporates coffee in dynamic fashion.  Coffee ice cream?  Well done.  Dark brown, some maroon tint, fluffy dense tan head.  Medium roast in both coffee and barley, harmonious.  Wow Im loving this.  Surly does great work.  Strong coffee, not overdone, always there, never dominating.  It works for me.

Im a sucker for a good American brown ale and the coffee here gives this one an extra lift. Very rich in aroma for a 5.1% abv ale - almost tokay-like with liquid brown sugars, peppery alcohol and ground coffee beans. The palate is a minor flaw - a fraction too fizzy for these flavours IMO. Sweet, quite alcoholic with a good caffeine kick. Sourish finish. This would be a great way to start the day and I bet its a good pick-me-up after a night on the sauce. Another impressive Surly. (Ratebeer Sydney Xmas gathering under the harbour bridge, 2009. Beer courtesy of Oslo - thanks buddy.)
