Dark cherries, mochacinno, toffee in the nose. Big espresso notes with caramel, but not in your face. The problem is the body isnt big enough to support the beer and is just a bit weak.  Taking this beer up to 6-7% would really help it out.  Not bad.

Murky brown with reddish hues and a frothy large slowly dissipating brown head and some sheet lacing.  Aroma of caramel, coffee, roasted malt, oatmeal and nuttiness.  Taste of oatmeal, coffee, roasted malt and mild nuttiness.  Creamy body with a touch of sourness and somewhat acidic as well.  Mild bitterness as well on the finish.  I prefer regular bender to this one.

16oz can HUGE thanks to WisconsinBeer!  Pours a very dark shinny brown with a wonderfully fluffy frothy sticky light tan foamy head.  Aroma of fresh coffee beans, nicely roasted, fairly bitter, some floral/citrusy hops match the sharpness of the roast and coffee, even brown sugar notes balance everything.  Flavor follows aroma leaning more towards the hoppy side with lots of bitterness, floral and bright citrus, very bitter, medium brown sugar that isnt excessively sweet.  Some sour cream in the finish, with a dryer biter coffee aftertaste.  A bit thin and watery in the body.  A very nice beer.  Definitely enjoying this more as it opens up and my tongue adjusts to the extreme bitterness.

16 ounce can courtesy of daknole. Thanks! Pours a dark brown color with a large brown head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of rich coffee along with sweet milk chocolate, cocoa and a bit of roast. Taste is coffee with cream, roasted malts, nuts and a fruity, faintly hoppy finish. Smooth, creamy, medium bodied. Very quaffable. Nice beer.

Disclaimer: I am not a coffee drinker.  That said, I do like a lot of coffee beers, and this was no exception.  16 oz. can from shawnm213- thanks, Shawn!  Pours a super dark brown, near black, with a resilient tan head.  Coffee dominates the nose, unsurprisingly, with notes of roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate, nuts, and tobacco.  The flavor follows suit- roasty, with coffee leading the way and some vanilla, tobacco, and chocolate notes.  Medium bodied, and at first seems thin but then has a grittier mouthfeel later.  Roasty finish.  The look and smell of this are really nice, but as a non-coffee drinker, the flavor was too strong for me.  My girlfriend is a coffee drinker and liked this a lot.
Poured from a can. Pours dark brown with very little head. Big coffee smell to it. Also has a big coffee taste with just a little bit of hops on the finish. I could drink this all day

Can from allendodd. The Surly enabler. Pours opaque brown/black with a foamy 4-finger foamy tan head that didnt stand up for long. Aroma is strong coffee. Maybe a chocolate undernote. Medium pluls body with mild carbonation. Flavor is coffee. Coffee. Coffee. Eventually a touch of chocolate. This is a strongly flavored ale. Finishes dryish and coffee. A mind altering experience.

16oz can from Erocks. Pours very dark brown with creamy tan head. Aroma is strong with coffee, roasted malt and some chocolate. Flavor is roasted coffee, chocolate, and some roasted malts. Finishes with bitter coffee. Good mouthfeel for a brown ale. Body is similar to a porter. Would like to try regular bender.

16oz can, thanks to Boamr. Pours out a mostly clear brown color with not much of a head. Very nice aroma of freshly roasted coffee almost like walking into a good coffee shop, a little touch of sweetness also hung in there. Taste is well balanced and drinks like a very good iced coffee with some sweet malty notes. This would definitely be a dangerous beer if more readily available here.

16 oz can shared by boamr, thanks Ryan for being enough of a man to share a beer from Minnesoate with the biggest NJ Vikings fan on the day they whooped the shit out of your Detriot Lions, AD and Rice baby!!!! Poured a deep dark brown with milk chocolate edges and a smaller foamy beige head. Aroma was like a cup of iced coffee, loads of fresh brewed coffee and even a touch of fresh cream with a slight nod to some bitter hops as well. The coffee flavor wasnt quite as strong as the aroma implied and the hops step up a bit to make this one a little more bitter then expected but hey it is a beer after all. This is one solid beer and for a 5.1% in a can is one of the most comlex sessionable brews I have ever had.

Can; pours a very dark brown with a large creamy tan head that has soapy lacing, good head retention. Aroma is very coffee with a hints of coffee grounds, some nuttiness amd a little chocolate notes. Also seems like some oats are present. Flavor is heavy coffee at first bit melds into nice chocolate, nuttiness, and good creaminess in the mouth feel. Very nice beer but not nearly as good as regular Bender.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 24/09/2009
Big coffee roast aroma. Copper mid brown coloured a little rich on the palate and fruity with a crisp and bitter coffee roast finish.
Looks smells and tastes like a cup of black coffee with a little bit of beer in it. Probably the best beer in a can I have ever had. I could drink this all day

can thanks to allendodd. pours dark brown with thick offwhite head. aroma of coffee beans, chocolate, vanilla bean,burnt malts. flavor is coffee, ash, dark chocolate. mouthfeel is a bit thin. good beer

RBSG 07. Tap at Surly. Dark brown, tan carbonation. Toasty, biscuity malt with a mild dose of earthy, bitter hops on the end. Coffee is strong but not overpowering. The roasted coffee and the malt are well integrated. Medium body, just a touch more carbonation than balanced, easy to drink. From notes.

Location: 16 oz can via trade with NickD717, 11/10/09


Aroma: The coffee is predominant in the nose, along with some  roasted malts, vanilla, and chocolate

Appearance: Pours a dark red-brown color with a decent amount of tan head, and quite a bit of lace

Flavor: The taste is quite similar to the nose, much of the same characteristics, again quite dominated by the coffee malts

Palate: Solidly drinkable mouthfeel, fairly thick and creamy with a decent amount of body

Overall Impression: 
This was a solid beer.  Not only my first rating from the brewery, but my first from the great state of Minnesota.  Overall, it made for a decent beer, but I just didnt get that much beyond the roasted coffee.

16 oz. can.  Pours a clear reddish brown color with a medium sized creamy beige head.  The aroma is coffee, with rich malt, and a surprising amount of nuttiness.  The flavor has a pleasing amount of dark coffee with a creaminess that is not expected.  Caramel malts are present early, but give way to an earthy, nutty and bitter finish.  Medium bodied and very smooth to drink.  The coffee is a bit too forward, but I think this is a push with the regular Bender.

Another awesome 500 ml can thanks to MattSciGuy- thanks. Pours a dark brown color with a medium beige head that goes down. A rich sweet coffee nose. A rich flavor; milky strong coffee, light toasted malts. Chocolate as well. Nice.

50 can, Fargo, ND, USA. Like smelling a cup of coffee with a splash of rootbeer. Head disappears quickly, pure coffee in the mouth. Sweet creeping flavor once the coffee wears down. Tastes like a cold black coffee with 4 spoons of sugar (in a good way).

16 oz can.pours very dark brown to black with a nice rich cream head.  powerful aromas of rich coffee persist into the chocolate and warmness of the coffee. long lasting finish of coffee and mocha.  a nice coffee beer, but not as good as others.

tall boy Can thanks to skyview and a darklord day trade pours brown and red around edges and hazy with a thick tan head aromas are of roasted malts,coffee,nuts and hops flavor is very smooth and creamy of coffee,nuts,roasted malts and a very nice hop balence this is one of the bset browns out there

Can thanks to MatSciGuy.  Pour is dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is fresh roasted coffee beans. The malt in faintly detectable under the huge coffee bean aroma. Light cinnamon and light chocolate pudding.  This is an impressive aroma.  if I was blindfolded, I would have guessed fresh roasted coffee beams for sure.  Not surprisingly, flavor is huge fresh-brewed coffee and a nice malty backbone.  A handful of other mild dark flavors like tobacco and hints of smoke also present but they are incredibly minor compared to the awesome coffee flavor.  If you hate coffee, youll hate this.  I only kind of like coffee, but I love this beer.  Not very complex, but certainly unique and quite tasty.

16 oz can Poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of coffee, mocha and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of coffee, roastiness and light cocoa with a smooth lingering coffee finish.

At a tasting, thanks David, small light brownish head, clear dark copper colour with with dark red taints, distinct aroma of fresh grounded roasted coffee, malty aroma with something soapy, strong distinct coffee dryness. The coffee traits are the hallmarks of this beer, but behind it is boring and one dimensional.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2013 Re-rate 9/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Dark brown with amber hues and a nice beige head. Great aroma full of coffee beans, dark chocolate and nuts. Bittersweet flavor with some roastiness, lots of coffee beans, some nuttiness and a bit of dark chocolate. Finishes with a bit of hoppy bitterness. Medium-bodied. Very good stuff. 8/4/7/3/15=3.7

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks David C. Dark clear brown with a beige head. Big pleasant coffee aroma. Sweet flavor with roasted coffee beans, some oatmeal, malt and some piney hoppy bitterness in the finish. Medium-bodied. 8/4/7/3/15=3.7

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2013 8/3/7/3/15[3.6]

Thanks David, pours deep red with a cream color head, aroma of ground coffee beans, nice acidity and some nuts notes, flavors of coffee, malt and  nuts, dry and hoppy towards the end. Medium bodied, coffee aroma was well preserved.6/5/7/3/13[3.4]

can, pours dark brown with a tall frothy tan head.  Aroma is very roasty, slightly nutty.  Dark malt, coffee, almonds.  Smells just like some of the great dark lagers of Prague.  Wow, very rich beer.  Tons of coffee flavors and a nice dark malt base but the coffee really shines.  It lingers in a bitter coffee grounds finish.  Nice smooth mouthfeel

16oz can This poured reddish brown with a thin head.  Aroma is nutty and malty, with lots of used coffee grounds.  Taste is roasted malt and coffee giving way to a slightly sweeter finish with some additional chocolate notes. Nothing particularly complex, but just really well done. The high quality coffee they use shines through particularly well.
Can from Hophead22. Reddish brown color with small head. Malty yeasty aroma and taste with some hints of coffee bitterness. Medium carbonation. Overall pretty good. Thanks Tim.

Source:500 mL can courtesy of hellomynameis. 
Glass:Killians English pint. 
Appearance:Clear amber pour with a one finger tan head.
Aroma:Coffee...plain and simple. 
Flavor:Coffee with a hint of caramel....but mostly coffee. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:If youre looking for a coffee beer, this is your man.  Not much else there though.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 16 oz can thanks to Tharreld.  Pours a light brown and settles into a brown with deep ruby notes and a lush 2+ finger tan head.  Big coffee roast nose with light chocolate and some grains.  medium body infused with coffee, dark malts, chocolate notes and a light citrus bitterness.  smooth body throughout.  Coffee Bender finishes like a desert loaded with coffee... lots of silky smoothy chocolate with light cherry notes.  wonderful beer! - wish I could get this regularly... love coffee, love beer - perfect match.

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09...  pours a light brown... huge coffee nose... big coffee notes throughout from beginning to end... medium smooth body... this is a really good coffee beer... I love coffee and I love beer, so this is a perfect mix!

Thanks Josh for sharing this!  Pours black/dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is the coffee I had with breakfast.  Nice and dark roast.  Opulent mouthfeel.  Flavor is what I expected it to be.  A nice roasty coffee flavor with a hint of chocolate on the finish.  Because I love coffee so much it was easy for me to drink this one.  And Id have it all the time if I could.

9/28/09 notes: poured at GABF, sampled three times.  Pours dark brown.  Nose is strong bold coffee, brown sugar and toasted malt.  Flavor comes off only half as strong as the nose, and sweeter.  A bit light through the middle.  Good bittersweet, almost nutty finish.  Body is medium-light, almost creamy.

Some coffee and chocolate in the arouma but far more coffee than anything, the flavor is strong black coffee , with lots of bitterness both from the coffee and seemingly from hops. There are some more subtle flavors as well some nuttiness and some chocolate, but not too much chocolate mind you, this is all about the coffee... and its damn good coffee too.

Can at Tampa tasting.  Poured a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is spent coffee grounds and a little ash.  Medium bodied with a slightly creamy mouth feel and weak carbonation.  Flavor is slightly acidic with strong coffee notes and a touch of nuttiness.  Finished with a fair amount of hops bitterness.  Somewhat one dimensional but I enjoyed it.  Good coffee beer.

Thanks again to Dansting for this one. 16oz can served in a shaker pint. Poured a clear dark reddish brown with a finger of light tan head. Nice aroma of coffee and cocoa. Coffee flavor was restrained and not over the top like a lot of coffee beers. The coffee didnt add to the bitterness, which I find distracting. Decent amount of hop bitterness. Chocolate malt. Dry finish from hops as well as lingering malt. One of the better coffee beers IMO.
On tap at the Map Room. This dark brown beer poured with a thin tan head and a strong coffee aroma. There is a rich coffee flavor with some treacle and carbonation and a long dry finish.

Poured from a can thanks to danielcurtis81 on his wedding week. Pours dark brown with red edges and minimal light beige head. Nose is a mix of coffee, dark malt, and more hops than expected. Taste is  sharp, spicy, bitter hop, dark malt, and black coffee. Very good brew, an odd mix of flavor, but its unique and I like that.

This growler of brew from a DLD beer festival poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were and left behind a transparent uncarbonated dark brown colored body. The mild aroma was brown malt and coffee. The thin mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of brown malt coffee and was softly acidic.  Id like to try this one again.
@Tampa Wkly Gathering courtesy ? -16oz can-pours a tan head and dark brown color.  Aroma is coffee.  Taste is strong coffee, some hops bite.
Pours a hazy brown. Nose is frsh coffe, toasted malt, bread and bitter coffe grounds. Flavor is fresh brewed strong coffee, sweet malted barley. Fairly thin bodied, but a damn nice brown ale.

Brown color with a bright umber glimmer when held to the light. Foamy light tan head. Dark chocolate and coffee aromas. Has a real pure coffee scent. Very smooth feel with just a little zip. Just a hint of toasted malt in the front. Light coffee creeps in from there. Seems simple, but to make a coffee brew that has just a hint of malt and then is pretty much all about the coffee is a nice feat. A nice coffee brew that isnt over the top in roasted malt and alcohol. I like it. I really need more of this for the early football games this fall.

One of many of the Surly pint cans that I brought back from the last trip up to Minnesota to visit family. Purchased at Haskells in White Bear Lake. Poured to my SA Lager glass, a deep brown with amber tones showing through. The head was tan, frothy, and left some impressive, clingy curtains of lacing. The aroma was mainly strong roasted coffee notes with chocolate and a bit of caramel following up. The flavor was similar along with some potent hop bitterness that stayed on the palate well into the finish. A medium + body with some creaminess contributing to the mouthfeel. A very enjoyable Brown Ale.

On Tap t GTMW - Poured dark brown with tan head.
Aroma - coffee and beer.
Flavor - strong black coffee infused with beer. coffe grounds!!
Palate - medium bodied with bitter coffee finish.
Overall - Way too one dimentional. Coffee and thats about it. If youre a coffee addict you will love it!!
Can courtesy of Tim.  Thanks.  Dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Big huge coffee aroma.  Bright velvety to sticky texture.  Chocolate, mild coconut, and a strong coffee taste.  Good.

16 oz. can - thanks BVC; hazy dark brown with thin, tan head; pure coffee grounds aromas more like cheap coffee, but pure and clean; slightly sweet and well balanced; served super cold, which I think was the good way to go for this; coffee, toffee and some brown sugar; very nice

Trade - STFun
Aroma: Nice coffee and dark malt aroma.   
Appearance: Dark brown in color, hazy with a light head.  
Flavor: Nice dark malt flavor with tons of coffee.   
Palate: Dry Coffee Finish, with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: This was a fun beer big coffee flavor for sure.

Dark coffee brown, go figure.  Coffee flavor on the front and back, and hard to taste the beer underneath.  Surly turns out much much better, but if coffee is your thing, then youll probably love this for breakfast.

Bottle thanks to Barrythebear (BA)!Chestnut with a moderate beige head. Nose of ashy coffee, the brown ale practically overwhelmed here and adding slight nuance at the edges in robust grain and slight sweetness. Flavor is also coffee, lightly bitter but with some milk chocolate lingering through to the somewhat empty finish. Pretty good balance between the coffee and the malt, but dont expect anything more than that.

Canned, thanks Baggio!  Chocolate brown, small head. Aroma of coffee and toffee. Medium sweet and medium bodied with firm malt. The cooffee flavor is highly upfront and dominant, making it rather one-dimensional. Fortunately I happen to like coffee so this beer right down my alley.

16 oz can brought back from Minnesota by my dear friend Kathy. Consumed tonight in honor of Ted Kennedy, a surly man who enjoyed going on a bender...zing! Poured cola brown with a moderate tan head that faded quickly. Aroma is pretty much all coffee with a light bit of chocolate involved. Flavor is basically just cold coffee with some metallic notes and a light bit of chocolate as it warms. Definitely more flavorful the warmer it gets though.

16oz can thanks to photomike.   Dark brown with a small, creamy head.   The aroma is a pleasant mix of chocolate-toasty grain and plenty of smoothly roasted coffee.   The flavor is pretty much iced coffee with a hint of acidity and medium bitterness balanced by some sweet toasty and chocolatey malt, all finishing with a light herbal hop bite.   The body is on the light side, which I was a little let down with at first, but came to enhance the whole coffee presentation in the end.   I really think that this is coffee done right in a beer, without to much sweet and roasted malt to get in the way and clash with it.   Cheers to Surly for not just throwing coffee into another stout.

Can courtesy photomike. Pours a clear ruby brownish copper with a nice light tan head. Not exactly a brown brown ale. Aroma is straight up coffee grounds. I wish I could say more but thats pretty much it. Flavor is iced coffee with half and half. Slightly green coffee beans with light acidity and moderate astringency. Body and mouthfeel are otherwise fine, and if you like coffee beer, this is pretty much the definition of it.

Pours a very murky red/brown with a nice crown. Excellent lace.

Smells of fresh coffee beans, like opening a new bag. No alcohol or hop presence, this is straight coffee, but unlike most roasted malts, this is more fresh bean.

Tastes..excellent. I cant say Ive ever had a beer like this. Iced coffee. I cant believe this is a beer, and its so damn good!

Mouth is medium in body and carbonation.

This is an incredible beer, period.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2009 Thanks baggio for charing the bottle. 
I dont drink coffee and dont like the taste of it, unless it is well combined with a big stoute or porter. This beer is not any of those, it is a brown ale that is totaly over powered by the coffee. It could bee that Im sensetive to the coffee and dont find any malt or hops. For coffee lovers this must bee a much better beer than for me.

Can, a gift from WeeHeavySD, thank you! Pours a deep dark brown with a small off-white head. Big coffee aroma, a bit creamy, with malt and dark chocolate. Taste is quite bitter, lots of coffee, bakers chocolate, and malt. Lingering coffee bitterness that has a watery underside. Quite nice.

Can sample at Noogfest High 5.

Poured a clear brown color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt and coffee aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Solid  roasted sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration.

Good complex brew.
Can sample at Noogfest High 5 thanks to heemer77. Poured a light brown with a thin off-white head. Sweet aromas of roast malt and coffee. The flavor found caramel and coffee. Light body.

Can thanks to Hophead22.. Pours dark red brown with a creamy off white head.. Aroma is fresh coffee beans and earth..Nice coffee flavor that is slightly hoppy.. Super smooth and easy to drink.. Damn I wish Surly was easier to get.

Dark brown in color, total coffee aroma.  Smells more like a great brew from Caribou than Surly.  Wonderful coffee flavor permeates the brown ale.  Dare I say this is the perfect beer to drink in the morning?
16oz can. Dark amber with a red tint. Pretty good coffee aroma, couldnt get much more than coffee. Dry and roasty with a lot of coffee aftertaste and a bit of hop bitterness, pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Poured a clear deep brown-amber color.  The aroma was of old coffe and vegetables with notes of an ash tray.  Roasted malt flavor with some sweetness.  Coffee finish.  Light bodied.

This poured a darker brown color with a big off white head. Aroma was just loads and loads of coffee, some caramel as well. Flavor was lots and lots of coffee some sweetness as well. I think this stuff is much better at room temp than chilled.

On tap at The Happy Gnome in St. Paul, MN. Pours with just a ring of head. Its a fairly dark but translucent beer, almost with a hint of red to it. Lots of coffee in the smell and taste. I also got a pretty hoppy flavor from it.

Can at the 3rd release of CL Cuvee de Castleton: Pours a hazy brown with a dense tan head. Lots of dark crystal malt character in the aroma- deep and toasted with just a mild coffee roast hint. Light body- but with firm malt character. Lots of crystal malt in the flavor- dark husky flavors and mild coffee presence offering a touch of tannic roast.  I like that the coffee is subtle. Pretty nice.

Can @ Cuvee de Castleton release. Nice coffee infused brown ale. The act that the base beer is a brown ale gives it a different flavor than most coffee beers. Great aroma and flavor and the fact it doesnt fit the coffee mold makes this a must try.
On tap at brewery for brewery tour. Bender with coffee. Duh. Very nice. Tons of coffee in nose and body but as a brown ale, no dark color.

Can - Pours reddish brown with a massive frothy tan head. It looks like a root beer float! Feels like one in the mouth, too--all creamy and smooth. Smells of sweet, caramelly malt, but not really much coffee on the nose. Theres a bit though, along with just a hint of chocolate. The taste is nutty and malty, with some bitter coffee and lactose coming through. Theres just enough hops on the finish to bitter it out and balance it a bit. This is really my type of beer, and if it was sold in WI and wasnt $12 for a 4-pack, I might replace my water intake with it.

Can brought back by my lovely wife. A dark red brown with a huge fluffy tan head. Aroma is slightly sweet and fresh coffee. Flavor was caramel, a little chocolate, and then the most awful coffee flavor I have ever tasted. Most coffee beers have a lovely deep rich coffee flavor but this was crappy pre-ground Folgers that had been left unsealed in the freezer. Bad bitter and stale coffee. This beer could be great if a better coffee was used, I had a hard time finishing it, stick to the standard Bender.

Can.  Pours deep coffee brown with a 2 finger thick tan head that left some spotty lacing.  Tons of fresh ground coffee on the nose along with roasted dark malts and faint hops.  Flavor was very roasty with lots of coffee and a fairly dry finish.  One of the best brown ales Ive had?......I think so.
Noogfest High 5. Sample from a can thanks to heemer77.  Solid brown-red with an off white head.  Aroma is sweet malt, coffee.  Taste is brown sugar, cocoa, caramel, coffee.
Brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma is caramel, light coffee, roasty.  Taste is caramel, and coffee.  Pretty straight forward.
Can from mcbackus. Nose of coffee, malted milk balls, and caramel. Clear dark brown with a medium lightly lacing beige head. Flavor is coffee, with light bitterness and light chocolate.

Very good at doing what it says it will, which is have a very strong coffee component. Pours opaque  reddish-brown, very dark, almost black, with a small tan head. Aroma is almost all roasted coffee. Flavor is also very strong on the roasted coffee, but theres a bit of maltiness detectable and some hoppiness toward the finish. Palate is effervescent, with a very fine but still somewhat aggressive carbonation.

Can from stfun... Shared with wolf. poured into a snifter, light brown in color, small head. Aroma of all coffee beans. Taste is a brown ale with a ton of coffee beans. I am not a coffee fan but this was bad, just a little too much coffee for my liking. Texture was a little on the lite side. Overall not bad... If you like coffee this beer is for you.

on tap at busters on 28th.  Pours a very dark brown color with little head.  Smells of obvious coffee and smoked wood.  The taste is instantly of coffee but has a bitter aftertaste.  I was a alittle disapointed with this beer.  I enjoy a good bitter beer but this one wasnt nice on my palate maybe cause it was at the end of a long tasteing menu I will have to give this another try though.

A great inclusion from skinnyguy. Opaque brown color. A nutty and woody aroma as you would expect from a nice brown ale. The coffee comes through nicely in the flavor and mostly in the finish with a bitter roastiness that lasts for a nice long while. A hint of cocoa on the back side too is interesting and unique for the style. A touch of roasted coffee but very faint in the aroma. Well added and subtle coffee flavors.

Can, thanks to tytoanderso. Really nice roasted coffee bean aroma with a hint of nutty malt beneath. Flavor keeps the coffee coming, great dry roastedness, pure coffee goodness, with some sticky fruitiness there as well. This is the first time Ive had this having hammered into my head that its a coffee BROWN ALE, not stout or porter, and having gotten that into my head, Im quite impressed with the bold, dry, smooth coffee presence.

16 oz can.  Pours a cloudy dark brown body with a one inch frothy beige head that left some nice lacing.  Very nice clean coffee aroma that mixes great with the dry nutty malt.  Throw in the moderate hoppiness and yet get greatness.  The flavor is just as well balanced, hard to tell where the coffee stops and the beer begins.  Did Starbucks make this?  Hoppy cold coffee?  Did they make this just for my tastes?  Medium bodied with a nice crisp hop bite on the finish with the coffee lingering on even further.  I love the subtle light-roast coffee flavor, theres no astringency or burnt flavors at all.  I hope they keep making this, I love it.
Aroma is of sharp coffee (go figure).  Flavor is coffee but not much else.  Not the most complex.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 Draft at ACBF09.  Pours brown with a small head.  Aroma of sweet malt and light coffee grounds.  Flavor is sweet initially with a coffee ground finish.  I would have liked to see a stronger malt backbone to balance out the bitter coffee but perhaps that is expected when using a brown ale as the base instead of a porter or stout, which I am more used to.  Anyway, it was very good for a brown ale.
7/4/8/4/15 (3.8/5)

Brown and opaque like coffee with a yellowish tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and sprucey hop notes.  Taste is the same as aroma with hops on the leading edge with more coffee in the finish.  Not really as coffee forward as I expected with rather tea-like elements, and rather typical brown aleness.  Perhaps the can aged too long and the intensity died down.

16 oz can from Skinnyguy. Pours a brown color with a small off white head. Nose is sweet malt with some nice dark notes. palate is fairly simple with a light velvet feel. Flavor is all coffee, where was this in the nose? coffee overpowers the flavor, its actually kinda nice...nose is malty, flavor is coffee...blends nicely.

Can acquired via trade.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a small head.  Aroma of coffee, malt, and nuts.  Flavor is loads of coffee as well as some nutty brown ale malt and roast.  Palate is medium-light and slightly creamy.  Good but I thought regular Bender was a little better and more well-rounded.

Can at the 8th Richmond Gathering courtesy of maniac. Dark brown pour. Strong coffee aroma. taste is almost pure coffee. Some roasted malt, and cocoa come through as well. Body is medium, chewy and creamy. Rather bitter as well. Ends with more coffee, choco notes and roasted malt. Very nice coffee beer!

Can.  Aroma has notes of roasted malts and heavy roast coffee.  Very dark coffee brown with a small off-white tan head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is bitter and tastes like cold carbonated coffee.  Palate is light bodied and lively.  All I can say is why?  Left me with no desire to drink another coffee beer.

Drank nearby with bender.  Bottle thanks to tytoanderso.  Pours a dark brown with thin tan head, laces pretty well.  Aroma strong of coffee and has a very mild grain, roasted malt, and chocolate to it.  Flavor is obviously dominated by coffee, but enjoyable.  Mouthfeel is creamy.  Overall a nice coffee brew, but nothing uncharted.

Deep brown.  Pleasant coffee aroma.  Flavor is nutty and coffee combined.  Really rather nice.  Some hops show up on the finish, sort of leafy.  Surprising in a coffee accented beer, but welcome.  Great way to finish off this Richmond gathering.

Pretty good. I love Surlys stuff, so its a treat to finally get to give this a try. Great coffee nose, nice lacing and a deep rich color. Coffee is very apparent, but not much else in there. Very well-balanced, but not too intricate. I like it, but I dont love it.

On tap at the Happy Gnome.  Pours hazy reddish brown with a nice beige head.  Huge coffee smell with roasted malt and oatmeal.  More caramel sweetness and less coffee in the taste.  Roasty finish, a little too watery for my taste.

Pours a nice brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of coffee, roasted malts, and nutty.  Taste is sweet and definately coffee.  Mouthfeel is light to medium, very easy and smooth to drink.  Very tasty brew, the coffee flavor is really well done in this brown ale.
Big coffee aroma.  Smooth coffee flavor.  The tiniest hint of sweetness and impeccable balance.

2009 Can - Thanks skinnyguy! - Pours a pure brown with a smaller beige head.  Aroma is sweet, nutty, and coffee filled.  The taste is much more coffee oriented than anything else.  Its got a coffee and cream type of thing with some cocoa, nuts, and roastiness.  I guess the iced coffee cited in the description is pretty accurate...  A fun brew.

Thanks to sliffy for sharing a bottle. The beer is a deep brown color with a medium thin beige head that dissipates steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Roasted coffee and milk chocolate aroma with a hint of malt. Medium body with flavors of coffee, dark chocolate and malt. Touches of hops at times too. The finish is mildly bitter with a lingering coffee aftertaste. Enjoyable all around.
Nose of coffee. Lots of flavor here. Coffee. chocolate, roastiness, malt and sweetness make their show in the nose on this one. Pours brown with a fluffy beige head. Ends on a coffee bitter note.

Pros: Not light struck.  Cool Design.  Lots of taste for a 5% beer.  

 

Cons: Brashly hoppy upon tasting.  Overly bitter and burnt.  Not a lot of body or nuance.  Aroma is fairly muted.  Short finish.  Out of balance for my tastes.

Big thanks to Buebie for sending another Surly want my way.
Can poured into my Sam Adams glass produced a good finger worth tan of head that settled down to a thick lace. The body of the brew was brown in color with red highlights

Guess what it smells like coffee ;-) Probably no surprise there, but it also has a nice sweet aroma a well. The flavor mimics the nose with a light bitter finish. Comparing it to other coffee brews I have experienced this is a lot more like a Ice coffee flavor and feel in my mouth. I like it, I could easily see myself kicking back a few of these on a hot day and feel quite refreshed. If you are into ice coffees you got to give this a try

2009 Can - Thanks skinnyguy! - Pours a beautiful amber brown with a medium tan head...aorma is cocoa, coffee and malt, with some light hops...flavour is similar, with a terrific char bitterness that lingers...great brew...

Deep, rich medium brown pour with a two finger off white head.  Aromas of fresh brewed coffee, white chocolate, and toasted malt.  The flavor is where this beer really shines: coffee, mocha, sweet malt, dark chocolate, and earthy hops.  The bitterness is spot on and does not linger on the palate.  It is a crisp, clean, interesting brew that successfully retains the characteristics of its parent beer.  The coffee is well controlled, adding complexity to an already fine brew.  If I lived in MN I could see this becoming my session beer of choice - outstanding.

Pours a dark brown with a medium, light tan head. Aroma of coffe, malt, and oats. Medium body with low carbonation. Tastes of coffee, chocolate, caramel, oats, malts, with some hops. Very good overall.

Can, thanks to Daknole. dark brown and clear. Nice mellow coffee aroma. Strange flavors, though. Somewhat lactic. Thin with low carbonation. Has more acidity than expected and is not roasty enough but still has redeeming qualities.

Can, thanks to tytoanderso. Clear mahogany with a large head. Aroma of coffee, cereal, nuts and earth. The coffee flavor really shines in this; roasted, smooth, not bitter. Medium bodied. A n outstanding session beer.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 Rating #209 for this beer.
. . . . . . . . . .
4/25/2009:  Surly Coffee Bender is probably better than I have given it credit, but its so hard to be truly objective about a beer when it follows not only a huge, deeply flavorful and rich Imperial Stout, but the second highest rated beer on the site?!  Needless to say, I would love to try Coffee Bender again, so please consider sending me a can or two if you have some to spare!  At any rate, this beer has a good coffee flavor all around and is balanced in everyway.  I like the bitterness and roasted quality that the ground coffee beans impart.  This is a great beer in general and even better since it is available in a can!
Sample from can at Dark Lord Day 2009.  Rating:  7/3/8/3/16 = 3.7
. . . . . . . . . .
11/02/2009:  Surley Coffee Bender...  Aroma:  Iced coffee latte; nutty.  Appearance:  Opaque, dark reddish-orange-brown head that is frothy, ivory-colored, and lasting; detailed lacing marks top to bottom.  Flavor:  Rich, intense iced espresso coffee with a touch of cream, plenty of caramel maltiness, and a wonderful blend of coffee-like acidity and earhty, resin hop flavor and bitterness in the finish; lots of nutty coffee bean flavor and a moderate bitterness overall.  Palate:  Medium-bodied, goes down easily.  Overall:  Very good, but the coffee definitely dominates a bit much.
16 fl. oz. can ( 5.1% ALC/VOL; IBUs - 45 ) from Skyview via trade.  Thanks Bob!  Rating:  8/4/8/3/15 = 3.8

can poured a brown amber color with a thin foamy tan head. aroma has dark chocolate, light coffee, faint vanilla, and brown malt. flavor does have some bitterness and light roast not in the nose. black coffee, dark chocolate, hefty malt, and some earth. more of a coffee porter but still tasty.

Canned. Deep brown body with pretty garnet when held to light. The head is thin with a light khaki color. Deep coffee nose with some notes of dark chocolate and plums. The taste is medium coffee with some roast and milk chocolate. There is also a little bit of fresh raw soybean in the finish. Overall, a nice brew with coffee being th dominant flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2015 bottle at DLD 2009 ...  Dark red copper ... huge coffee nose ... and again huge coffee huge coffee very 1d3.1

Keg at the hanging bat.. Dark chocolate coffee roast malts nose.. Dark roast.. Dark chocolate.. Big coffee.. Dark chocolate.. Big coffee 3.9

A- Pours a deep brownish red letting almost no light through. Creamy, two finger head fades with a little lacing.

S- Coffee Coffee and more Coffee! Lots of roasted malt.

T- Very coffee heavy all the way through slightly acidic, bitter coffee flavor is left on the tongue.

M- Medium bodied with medium to low carbonation.

D- This is very flavorful for the amount of alcohol. I personally felt the acidity and raw coffee flavor was a little too much to handle but im sure coffee lovers will get their fix on this one.

Can

Pours a very dark brown with ruby highlights and a nice thick long-lived tan head. Sweet oats and coffee aroma. Serious coffee flavor in here, almost sour (in a brown-ale way) flavors that recall an iced coffee without milk. Coffee flavors totally drive the late end, mingling well with some hops, and putting together an all-around kick-ass coffee beer.  Also poundable, with is not a flavor in the least.
Holy cow!  This beer has more coffee in it than any other that Ive ever had!  Really delicious, and very intense, but still complementary to the notes of the original Bender.

Traded for on DLD to a random stranger sporting a cooler.Smells like old Folgers thats been sitting in a freezer for when relatives come to town.Pour is a dark brown with a lake pollution head. Flavor is an almost sour- mash- old- coffee -thats -been- sitting since -morning kind of filth with a touch of acidity. As I drink it it gives love back to me like a dog recently beaten and looking for forgiveness, so I try to love it back and find only a "like" for said dog...A smattering of hops and bitter coffee show themselves toward the finish leaving me to question  "why didnt I drink this in the morning?

Boo-ya! COFFEE! Yum. Not sure how this is good, but it is. Really good. Lots of roasted barley taste which merges well with roasted coffee beans. Some vanilla flavors present. Smells like coffee, not beer. Tastes more like coffee than beer. This is a breakthrough. Is there caffiene in it? Very creamy. Im amazed this works, and equally surprised that more people are NOT writing bad reviews because this seems to be either an 1) I love it beer!, or 2) this is disgusting beer. For me it is the former.

Thanks to rustychiles for the share on this. The aroma of this beer is sublime. It is cold high grade coffee. Taste is much the same, only carbonated. On the palate it finishes a bit chalky, which leads me to think they have water profile issues or the high level of coffee has taken its toll on the acidity of the beer or something. Anyway, it just isnt quite right. I think this might have been a better beer had the coffee been a little less present and the beer a little more present. Not once did this remind me of drinking beer, which seems wrong. Eventually my coffee connoisseur gag-reflex of good coffee gone cold kicked in and I couldnt drink anymore. Still, pretty amazing to get that level of aroma and taste in a beer.

Can courtesy of tytoanderso. Pours a nice brown with a nice light brown head. Aroma is super duper awesome coffee, roast, malt, water. Flavor is coffee, coffee, coffee. Finishes a little chalky but still very good. Nice brew.

Can with thanks to skyview.  Pours a medium brown with a thick and frothy tan head.  Aromas are of stale coffee... like the stuff that has been sitting around for too long.  That smell buries any other aromas that might be present.  The beer tastes a lot like a fizzy and cold coffee.  There is a bit of hops that pokes through in the finish, but for the most part, this tastes like a coffee beer... but not like an imperial stout or something where the coffee compliments and plays off the other flavors.  Here it buries them alive and walks away from the grave.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
16oz. Can:  Thanks waolsen!  Aroma of coffee, malts, light nuts, light cocoa, light toffee, and some oats.  Poured brown in color with a medium-sized, rocky, dense, creamy, tan/light beige head that lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes of coffee, malts, cocoa, caramel, slight resin, and a hint of tar.  Medium body.  
It is pretty darn delicious for a brown ale.  Extremely chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Sweet, coffee, caramel, finish is very chalky.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2009 (Bottle thanks OSLO and Guerde) Pours dark brown with a mahogany red glow.  Deep sand colored to light nut-brown head. The aroma holds a fantastic but quite subtle coffee roast with tones of earth, gravel, mild jalapeno oil, parsley, cocoa, ice coffee and oily coffee beans. The nutty, light chocolaty malt plays well with the coffee. Tiny whisper of caramel and red berries. Light herbal hoppy. The flavour is nicely balanced between the coffee and the malt with light hop bitterness in the background. The mouthfeel is soft and quite smooth with a light carbonation. Light acidic and light sweet. Complex, light bitter and earthy coffee roast lingers. Bit watery, light to medium bodied.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Poured dark reddish brown, coffee, roasted malts, nutty, slight hops, dry finish.

Can thanks to mreusch, pours deep reddish brown. Beautiful when held to the light, with a medium bubbled tan head. Nose is mainly smooth coffee and little else. The flavor is also subtle coffee with a touch of nuttiness and roasted malt. Dry, slight bitter lasting finish.
thanks to stu aka "hey you in the bushes" .. . Pure pure coffee goodness, amazing .. . iced coffee mouthfeel .. . great coffee flavours, perfect harmony. . .. truly gods gift to coffee lovers!

Can courtesy of theisti. Thanks Tim. It pours deep clear brown, almost mahogany, with a large, creamy, beige head that laces nicely. The nose is initially all about the coffee, then your brain toggles back and forth trying to hone-in on just what its smelling...hops, coffee, perhaps chicory coffee...something is just a bit "off". You circle around it never settling on one definitive aroma. I guess the best way to describe it would be to say that it smells like an iced coffee with "something" else added to it. That something is earthy and herbal but I cant lock down a specific descriptor. The mouthfeel is fairly light-bodied yet creamy and slick with a punch of hop bitterness coming at the end. (It is a Surly beer...) The flavor is of coffee over a round malty body, concluding with a nice hoppy bitterness. Notes of coffee and hops linger long after the swallow. Overall...this is an odd bird. Its more-or-less all over the place, and although I really like certain qualities it possesses (the mouthfeel and nice bitterness), it lacks the continuity to make me want more. A benchmark American brown, I find the "regular" Bender more enjoyable than this version.
Clear brown color, ring of white head.  Aroma of wet coffee grounds, slight earthy hop background notes.  Mild bitter coffee taste, lighter hop finish.  A nice coffee brew.

Pours a reddish brown with a beige head.  Aroma is overwhelmingly coffee-y to the point where you cant notice anything else!  All brown ale qualities are masked pretty much.  Tastes of coffee (duh), huge roast,  burnt caramel.  Extremely single minded, but in a night with at least 4 coffee beers, this was by far the most coffee-y and also least complex.  I like the way Speedway and Darklord do coffee: subtle!  Still, this was enjoyable despite its faults.

16 oz. can shared by goldtwins.  Pours a clear brown with a moderate off-white head.  The aroma is dominated by fresh coffee.  Any of the aromatic qualities of Bender have been wiped out by the coffee.  Fortunately, I like coffee so this beer works for me.  The coffee in the flavor does not come across as fresh as in the aroma, and some of the traits from Bender sneak in such as some chocolate and pine.  Bitter coffee finish.  Enjoyable.

16oz can acquired in trade with wetherel (thanks!). Poured a deep and dark amber color (almost brown) with a an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of coffee, roasty, pine, earthy/diirt, and nuts. Tastes of coffee, roasty, vanilla, and caramel. Light lacing left on the glass.

Poured a translucent brown color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, coffee, pine, toast, and some floral hops.  Taste of caramel malts, some roasted coffee beans, vanilla, and tobacco, with a dry finish.

Can shared by hopdog. Pours a deeper brown with lots of ruby notes coming through and a medium creamy off white head that laced.  Aroma of coffee (duh), vanilla, some hops peaking through, caramel, nuts and toasted malt.  Flavor of coffee, toasted malt, nuts, tobacco and light hops.
tasting at the bluebird.  just like it says - coffee beer.  it tastes like an iced coffee with no creamer.  good brew - just what i needed to pick me up.

This is the best smelling coffee beer Ive ever laid upon my olfactory sense.  Strong coffee flavor.  Perfect aroma.  Flavors are strong malts, coffee and a nice toast.  Flavor is very good.  This is a great brown ale.  One of my favorites.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2009 draft at maproom.  i really liked this beer.  one of the best brown ales out there. 

Just had this from a can.  It is FUCKING A SWEET BEER!  Awesome fresh ground coffee aroma, taste and feel to it.  some chocolate, grahham crackers, vanilla, and roast.  this is damn good.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2009 Pint can via trade with Scoobydank. Pours a cloudy deep chestnut brown with a small cream white lacing head. Nose is of coffee, nuts, and malt. Nice mild coffee flavors, a strong nut flavor as well. Mouth is medium bodied and a little sticky. Very flavorful 5% beer! Reminds me a bit of the Nestea instant mix Grandma use to make, yum!
Samples from can and growler. Both similar and heavy on the coffee and seemed to have lost any nut or biscuit flavors. Some burnt toast makes this unenjoyable for me.

very strong aroma. very dark color. very bold taste. a great breakfast beer. much like the regular bender, its darker, but not very stout taste is good for a meal..or meal substitute, but this one has coffee in it!

Thanks to Moelikebeer for this one.  Dark brown in color with a light tan head.  Aroma of fresh, smooth coffee and alot of it.  Some molasses and chocolate in the background.  Taste has a good amount of fresh, smooth coffee, almost like eating a coffee bean that has no bitterness/astringency.  Malt backbone is there enough to hold it all together, some molasses sweetness, as well as some light chocolate and brown sugar.  Damn, this was a really good coffee beer, glad I got to try it.
very good beer. or maybe this was a coffee with alcohol in it. I cant really tell, I know Id drink it again if given the chance, must try

Can at the BA Decadence line tasting. Pours a dark brown-black with a small beige head. The aroma is pure coffee. The taste is more coffee and more coffee. Did not get much else, but hey, I love coffee, so this went down real well. Only disappointment was that the mouthfeel was a bit on the thin side. Overall: very simple in its approach, yet quite good. Thanks to whoever brought it.

Can shared with Sparky27...thanks Eric!!!  Mahogany pour with a 1/4 inch eggshell head and a couple of nice rings of lace.  Aroma is 100% Folgers...not a ton of complexity here.  Aggressive roasted coffee, faint caramel malt, and a dash of brown sugar.  Would take this over a cappuccino any morning!!!

Pours a dark brown with a smallish light brown head.  Smells of really nice blend of coffee and dark brown malts and roast.  I really dug the nose on this.  The flavor was pretty tasty as well.  not as thick bodied as i was expecting, but then i have to remember its just a brown ale.  Very big on the flavor with hints of some roast and chocolate as well.  I think its an excellent brown ale, and wold drink again.

Can thanks to rollinhard.  The smell is like good iced coffee, malts, roasty, and boldness.  The look is brown in color with decent red highlights and an ok beige head.  The taste is coffee, roasty, malts, very taste, cappucinno like.  Good.

From puggy...thanks man.  Pours a nice cloudy dark brown with a good tan head.  Aroma is really cool...hops, malt and lots of coffee.  So often coffee infused beers are stouts/porters this is a refreshing new look for coffee beers.  Flavor has some great coffee, light malts and a nice amoutn of hops.  Some of the nutiness in regular bender has been lost with the coffee...but it doesnt hurt the beer. Good stuff.
Bottle thanks to rollinhard. Dark brown with an average sized beige head. Aroma is of bold coffee and roasted malts. Taste is the same...lots of coffee.

Can thanks to rollinhard. Pours with a dark brown head over a hazy brown body. Aroma of coffee, nuts, spice, roast, and vanilla cream. Taste is coffee, cinnamon, and French Vanilla. Watery mouthfeel, light bubbles.
can thanks to rollinhard.  deep brown pour with a ring of cream froth.  nose is ground coffee beans.  good on the palate with a huge flavor of coffee and a nice finish.

Can thanks to rollinhard. Pours a brown with some ruby hues, beige head. Aroma of fresh coffee beans. Flavor of fresh coffee, dark roast, faint tartness. Medium body with medium carbonation. Pretty good!

Can. Body-thin brown, thin ring of bubbles. Nose-spent wet coffee grounds, soil, old storage building-basically a mix of soil and coffee. Taste-light skunk, body odor, clay, earth ,soil, light wood. Very nice.
I like this beer anyway, but add the extra complexity of coffee flavor and it makes a different beer.  I had it at the 8th street grill.  The only thing that is weak is the coffee cup it comes in.

Big ass can shared by JCB.  Strong coffee grounds taste and aroma.  Nice mix of bitter coffee and sweet brown ale.  Think espresso and chocolate chips.  Taste is more like sweet coffee.  Very easy to drink, and you gotta love the 5.1%

Courtesy of markwise. Pours clear amber with tan head. Not much to be said about the aroma except it is full on coffee grounds and little else. The taste is similar with loads of coffee mixing with mild notes of maltiness in the background. Solid coffee brew but I think CCBs coffee stout has ruined me on all others at this point.

16oz can
This poured reddish brown with a thin head. The aroma and flavor were of used coffee grounds. The finish is slightly bitter and a bit dry.

16oz can.  Pours a ruby-hued Coca-Cola brown with great carbonation and a nice mocha colored head.  Aroma is nutty and malty, with lots of roasted malt and coffee alongside some notes of chocolate and wood.  Taste is medium-bodied and dry, with a taste of roasted malt and coffee (GOOD coffee, even!) giving way to a slightly sweeter finish with some additional chocolate notes.  Nothing particularly complex, but just really well-executed.  The high quality coffee they use shines through particularly well.

copurtesy of markwise.
Pours black with beige head.
Aroma of roasted malts and coffee.
Taste is easy to drink, light and plenty of nice coffee as well as caramel. Overall palate is thin. Goes down easy.

Can from trade with valpodogs.  Pours dark cola brown color with small khaki head.  Nose is roasted coffee beans with some roasted malt present.  Flavor is fizzy black coffee- none of the sweet qualities present in some other coffee beers.  It is like an iced coffee with alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel with bitter coffee from start to finish.  Not bad, but not my favorite.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head that dissipates to a lacing.  Aroma is dominated by coffee but there are hints of cocoa and caramel.  A little watery but this is not met to be a big beer so its good for the style.  Flavor is mostly coffee with maltiness in there.   Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Can, courtesy mgumby10. Pours a very dark brown color with a small, tan colored head that quickly fades a sudsy film. The aroma is nice and shows a good amount of roasted coffee blended with some nuts and caramel malt. A touch of creaminess balances things out. The flavor shows a good balance between the roasty coffee and the sweet caramel. Some cream and peanuts add to the flavor quite well. Medium bodied and very smooth, but could probably use a touch more body. Good carbonation and very easy drinking. This is a really nice brown ale. Glad I got to try this.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 Can, courtesy kiefdog I believe. Black pour, thin brown highlights, creamy hazy head. Nose is pure black coffee, some cinnamon and slight hazelnut. Nice, simple, and lovely. Flavor has lots of coffee roast, chocolate, some dry grainy malt. Dry, slick and tasty. One-dimensional overall, but it works, and its thoroughly drinkable.
Can from DazAle I think.  Thanks!  Smooth, easy to drink.  No roastiness.  Nice, fresh sessionable.  Not sweet or dry.  Great job Surly!
Pours dark brown, with a tan head. Nose is roasted coffee beans a some malt. HUGE coffee taste, with caramel, creamy malt, nuts. Mouthfeel is somewhat creamy, goes down nicely. Very tasty treat.

Can courtesy MGumby10. Pours slightly thin with a brown cola like look to it with a small tan head. Huge aromatic coffee aroma with touches of caramel, very nice. Slightly thin body and more coffee with touches of caramel and chocolate malt. Seems to have lost a little bit from aroma to flavor, but decent beer.

Pint can courtesy of cas. Pours a dark cola brown with reddish highlights and a one finger tan head. Aroma is strongly of roasted coffee and malt with lesser notes of honey, caramel, some chocolate and ripe dark fruit. Flavor is also strongly of coffee with less prominent notes of caramel, toffee, smoke, wood, roasted veggies. Generally medium to full body with a strong roasted coffee finish.

Pours a dark brown, almost black (much darker than regular Bender), with a creamy tan head. Awesome aroma of intense coffee with a little bit of caramel sweetness and roasted malt in support. The flavor is nearly as intense, with the coffee really coming through again. A little bit of chocolate and caramel, but this beer remains pretty bitter throughout. The palate could be a little heavier, but is pretty smooth regardless. One of the best coffee beers out there, and possibly my favorite brown ale, if you can even call it that.

Sampled at the First BA Nashville tasting. Pours a beautiful dark mahogany with beige head. Great aroma of coffee and sugary malts. Lighter side of medium bodied with average carbonation. Flavor of nutty malts and coffee. Simple but tasty. Someone mentioned is was thin, but its an effing brown ale. I think the body is fine for the style. Another winner from Surly, if you like coffee.
can.  thanks Joe.  dark pour with tin soapy head.  aroma is milky, roasted malt.  smooth, creamy body with just enough bite.  coffee, light nuttiness.  great brew.

16 oz. can via trade with tytoanderso - Pours a brown color with a one finger thick tan head.  Light layered lacing.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor is also coffee and roasted malt.  Finish has some roasted bitterness to it.  Mouthfeel seems a tad thin.  A nice beer.  Thanks Ty.

16 oz can.  Clear, deep brown with a thin tan head.  Toasty nose with brown sugar fading into French roast coffee bean.  Medium body but finishes a bit thin and resiny. Mild fizzy carb.  Taste is burnt molasses, cola and bitter coffee.  I prefer the original.

Can, courtesy mgumby10.  Pours a dark and translucent chestnut brown color.  A small, fading, beige colored head leaves a sudsy wash that mostly rejoins the body.  The nose shows notes of rich coffee intertwined with a caramelly, nutty malt base.  A good amount of lactic creaminess lends an inviting softness, taking some of the edge off of the coffee roast.  Flavors follow suit, showing fantastic balance between roasty coffee and rich caramel notes, with cream and oats bridging the gap quite well.  Medium bodied and silky smooth, the palate is nice, but a bit more substance would be welcomed.  Im not sure that this is significantly better than the regular Bender, but it is damn nice.  Great for a brown ale.

Can thanks to mgumby.  How the hell does a brown ale turn into coffee sex?!? Smell was better than the taste, but still very good. Creamy and caramelly.  Extremely cool...you need this.........you do.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2010 Starbucks iced coffee is cheaper,the price of this beer is astronomical yet the colour of the head shows a minimal use of any malts.Tastes like Todd saved all his coffee that sat on the burner all day.Same beat up 16 oz.cans as always,no date code.This brewer is now on the profit bandwagon,save ur monies for imported brews where pride is still incorporated in the brewing process.A highly over-rated brew.
Seek out a Belgian brew in this price range

Can courtesy mgumby. Ruby-garnet color. Very nice coffee flavor, with a tight central american bean tone. Nice iced coffee flavor, too, with touches of cream. Dry palate. I really like the coffee elements but on the whole it lacks depth and oomph.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Pint can my Dad brought down to me from Minneapolis.  Pour is mostly clear mahogany dark brown with pretty settling that builds up a thick and lasting 3 inch light tan head. Aroma of somewhat stale coffee, pine hoppiness and roasted malt. Nice enough, though this was a pretty blah coffee nose. Taste is very much the coffee aromatics and taste at the beginning, middle is the brown ale of Bender with a pine hop bitterness to the finish. The hops are pretty understated, and the coffee dominates throughout. I didnt mind the concept of this beer, but it really suffered from a flat, dull coffee profile. Not sure what technique they used to extract the coffee, but it ended up tasting almost like instant coffee. Palate is creamy medium, coats the mouth nicely. The finish is quite long, and features even more of the coffee.  Having said all of this, it is still a clean beer that is easy to sip, just a little dull.

I had this for the first time last year at EBF.  Now that its readily available I decided to stock up since it was by far the best thing Surly had to offer at the festival last year.  Overwhelming aroma of a great coffee smell.  If I had to compare this to anything else out there try a Starbucks double shot espresso and I think it taste identical aside from there being the added bonus of alcohol in it and the beer is not as thick.  I was very impressed with it at EBF last year and still am today, this might be my new staple beer to turn to.

16-oz can. Thanks, BVC! Pours a murky dark brown with rubied highlights. Loose gray film. Big, rich, delicious coffee nose. They didnt use the pinnacle of gourmet coffees, thats for sure, but it still smells pretty good. Easily could have notched a perfect score with good coffee, though. Creamy medium body with coffee, brown bread, black bread, and caramel on the mid-palate. Long coffee finish.

Can and growler at CL Rosso Release Party.  Pours a nice deep dark brown almost black with a nice lasting tan head.  Aroma ia awesome smooth roasted coffee- espresso like - awesome nutty dark choclate without the char or bitterness.  Good smooth nutty coffee flavor, smooth espresso, toasted almonds, moderatley sweet toasted adn caramel malts, and a smooth coffee finish.  Great coffee infused beer.

Growler shared by some of the excellent people at the Rosso release at Captain Lawrence. Pours a deep brown to black with a soft tan head.  Coffee and malt, malt and coffee.  Crisp roasted scents and a hint of smoke and chocolate.  Body again echoes (or perhaps rings true to) the coffee.  Clean and easy drinking, this was actually quite remarkable at about 11 am.

16 oz. can, courtesy of Skyview.  Clear, dark brown color with a thin, white head.  Aroma of black coffee with some cocoa hints.  Flavor is really nice.  While the coffee comes out in the beginning., a  subtle chocolate tone lurks in the background.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but doesnt distract.  Finish is slightly bitter.  What a great beer.

16oz can thanks to vwcraig. Dark brown, red tints, smells like a handful of roasted beans. The flavor nails the coffee aspect and reminds me of a truly enjoyable morning cup as opposed to a lot of the other coffee beers that taste more like old grounds than fresh coffee. I dont usually like coffee beers but this one is an exception.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-13-2009 04:03:23

Can in trade from br3meister.  Thanks man!!  Pours a lovely dark chocolate brown with a lasting creamy light tan head.  Smell is nice and of fresh roasted coffee beans and a touch of sweetness.  Taste is smooth and coffee up front with a light malty brown ale sweetness behind.  Nice bitterness and a nice coffee flavor, but with a lighter body.  Really interesting having the coffee flavor in a style lighter than a porter.  Very good.

Can courtesy of Buebie poured into a tulip.

Pours dark mahogany and settles almost completely black in the glass underneath a huge beige head that lingers as a cap and leaves tons and tons of lacing.

Fresh roasted coffee aromas jump out of the glass with hints of the caramel malts in the background.

A quick roasted coffee hit gives way to the caramel malts in the taste.  The roasted coffee comes back strong and leaves a slightly acidic bitterness in the finish.  There are hints of chocolate in the background that enhance the sweetness and keep the coffee from thoroughly dominating.

The mouthfeel is extremely smooth with good carbonation and has an overall velvety feel to it.

Another winner in a can from Surly.  A very drinkable brown ale with some good coffee character.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2011 Tap at Rodan in Chicago. Pours a dark brown with a very thin tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, espresso, molasses. Taste is more watery than expected with a taste more of black tea and slight chocolate than rich coffee. Neutral finish. Not bad but not that impressive. 2/9/2009 7/4/7/4/14=3.6Can thanks to TheTomG. Pours is a clear reddish brown with a lively, tan head. Very big lace. Sheety and sticky. Aroma is heavy mocha and caramel as it pours into the glass. Later some lemon tea but still very heavy chocolate and caramel come forth. Taste at first is creamy and quenching and then watery with off-flavors that remind me of DMS but I think its just old chocolate and sticky sugar added to barely noticeable bitter coffee. End result is not very appetizing. 3/26/2011 7/4/5/3/12=3.1
Hazy dark brown pour, tan head and some drippy lace.  Espresso on the nose.  Bittersweet chocolate and coffee.  My only problem with this beer is it was a tad thin. Otherwise very solid
Pours a dark reddish brown. Aroma of coffee.  Pretty tasty beer.  Mixture of dark chocolate and coffee.  Delicious.

Can.  Dark mahogany pour.  Lots of fresh brewed coffee (with cream) as well as some vanilla on the nose.  Not too heavy, with moderate to high carbonation.  Flavor is dominated by the coffee, but there is a little malty sweetness to it.  Long coffee accentuated finish.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 Can from Ed at Heritage.  Pours, smells, and tastes as advertised.  Notes of black tea and hops characterize this as a Surly beer, to me.  A noticeable improvement on the Bender recipe, but a bit thin on the palate.  No matter the temperature, this beer seems to taste like iced coffee.  Upon re-rating, I found that after a few months of again, a really dried red pepper taste seems to come out in the aroma and in the flavor, which is more than welcomed.
Can shared by JCB. Thanks Jason. Pretty tasty brown. Smells great and tastes like some tasty coffee. I could stand a few more 4 packs of this one.

Thanks to JCB for sharing. Pours a dark brown that allows light. Head is frothy and light tan. The nose shows a nice pronounced coffee character, a good smooth roast, some grainy malt character. The flavor and aroma both show the character of the cold extracted coffee in that there is less bitterness and acidity and a much smoother coffee flavor that integrates better with the beer. Flavor has a good pronounced coffee character with a nice balance between the malt and coffee bitterness. The roast adds a really nice character. Nice coffee brown.

Can thanks to Skyview.  Pours brown with brown frothy head.  Big roasted coffee nose.  Flavor is rich dark roasted coffee with roasted malt sweetness.  Some notes of dark chocolate that round out this gem.

Can from tytoanderso - thanks, Tyler! Man, Ive been eager for this one for a while and it doesnt disappoint. Dark brown pour with a surprisingly frothy head. Im a fan of the base beer, which is far more complex and quirky than most browns, with a signature toasted malt and slightly bitter flavor. So the coffee addition - and seriously, this is lovely, full coffee flavor - really works well. Long and smooth finish complements the full mouthfeel. Some bitter choc in there too, along with a faint woody note. Really great. I would drink tons and tons of this were it available locally.

Dark black, head fades rather quick. Aroma is very pleasant- like a good black coffee with a noticable back. Im pretty impressed with that aspect. Taste is good. The original bender is still apparent, but its accented with the wonderful coffee flavors, and either more chocolate, or the chocolate flavor is also created with the addition of the coffee. Im getting a kick out of these Surly brews. Worth a taste for sure.

Can pours dark with red brown highlights with a small head that laces.  The aroma is coffee and Bender.  The flavor is somehow sweeter than I anticipated since Bender really isnt this sweet as I remember.  The palate is rich and slick.  Overall, this is another good effort.

Pours dark brown with a lasting thin creamy head.
Aroma is coffee, some chocolate and burnt malt.
Flavour is col coffee, dark roast bitterness combines well with nutty chocolate tones. I like it better than regular Bender.

16oz. can, from the ever awesome tytoanderso!  Pours a clear dark brown with burgundy highlights and a one finger tan head, good retention and lacing.  Aroma is fresh coffee, with some subdued chocolate, toffee and caramel.  Flavor is more coffee, again with background notes of light chocolate, toffee and roasty malts.  This is a well done coffee beer that works well for me.  Not the intensity and complexity of espresso, but the cold pressed coffee does its thing nicely and is a good enhancement to the regular Bender.  Thanks again Ty!
12oz handbottle from iowaherkeye.  Pours blackish broen with a tan head.  Sweet coffe nose.  Taste is coffee and malt and overall very tasty and interesting.  I like it.

Tap @ Hop Leaf.  Black, minimal head w. very nice lacing.  Nice roasty malts, soft chocolate-y coffee.  Flavor is rich roasty malt, some toffee, bitter (but in no way astringent) coffee.  Lingering bitter coffee finish.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2009 CAN, TAP: pours reddish/brown with beige head. Nutty and chocolate on the nose, with flavors of chocolate, caramel, nut, and of course, coffee. A little hop at the back end with some coffee bitterness. Great beer, Surly rules!

pitch black with tan head.  coffee strong on the nose, huge coffee flavor with some roasted and chocolate malt interspersed.  could benefit from some alcohol adding some depth, but a nice coffee flavored beer

growler from psprings... wtf! who just pulls out a growler and hands it to you?

this poured a chestnut-y brown... im gonna go with a shade darker than the regular bender and a creamy tannish head. 

if i smelled this blind i wouldve told you it was stale coffee. crazy... aromas of whole medium dark roasted beans beans, brown sugar, toasted nuts and vanilla. im amazed by the sheer volume of real coffee stink coming off of this thing!

awww, the flavor is a bit of a let down. not bad, just not very... esoteric... a cold cup of mildly sour coffee with notes of brown sugar, faint chocolate and some nuttiness with a very bitter dry finish. theres just not a whole lot happening. its damn good just a bit too simple and straight forward. it is medium bodied with a nice creamy mouth feel.



i have this fairy tale dream in my head of surly finding a way to get some bacon in this stuff... my personal heaven of my three loves in one glass!
9/4/7/4/17/4.1

Sample via growler courtesy of hellbilly at his holiday tasting. The beat coffee aroma on the nose from a beer I’ve had. Black body with tan head. Roasty burnt cold coffee flavor. Good brew, thanks Josh.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2010 On tap at the hop leaf. I dont like brown ales. I find them too sweet, too boring. Bender though is awesome, easily one of the best browns Ive had. Obviously, I was excited to get Coffee Bender on tap. And, yes, it was big, complex and bitter with a great addition of coffee. Surly is awesome.

Re-rate: Big coffee aroma, with insane coffee flavor, creamy mouthfeel.  Bam.

Growler courtesy of hellbilly at the hellbilly holiday tasting.  Dark brown body with reddish highlights and a creamy tan head.  Big roasted coffee aroma and flavor.  Much like drinking an iced black coffee.  Very good brew!  Thanks Joshua.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 Huge thanks to DalzAle for grabbing me a growler of this. Even sitting for a few days, it is every bit as good as I remembered. Aroma is coffee beans and nothing else. Thin (but not wayery) on the palate. Flavor is wonderful coffee, lots of roasted bean, with a touch of cream and hazelnut. Slight acidic bite on the aftertaste. I am still partial to Bells Java Stout, but this is one damn fine coffee brew that I could drink all the time.

Sample via growler courtesy of hellbilly at his holiday tasting.  Pours a clear reddish brown with a nice tan head.  Nose is lots of French roast black coffee and toasted malt.Tastes just like cold black coffee with a sourish coffee grain finish.  Medium mouth feel.  I really enjoyed this, but you better like coffee.  Thanks Josh!

On tap at Stub & Herbs, University of Minnesota. A nice dark brown with a two fingered head. Has a brawny coffee aroma that jumps out of the mug.   The taste is a great balance of coffee with malt and a hint of vanilla that creates a truly creamy and textured drinking experience.  One of the top coffee beers I have had.

Growler picked up from the brewery today.  Poured a dark brown flavor with a slight coffee and vanilla aroma.  Flavor was excellent, all the creamy and slgiht vanilla flavor of bender, but with the pleasant aroma and flavor of coffee.  Cant wait until this comes out in cans!
Draft: pours dark brown, aroma of coffee, taste of coffee on top of the very good regular Surly Bender.  This one is some damn good stuff.

On tap at Flossmoor Station.  Pours a dark brown with a big off-white head.  Aroma of coffee and coffee and a touch of coffee.  Huge coffee flavor with some creamy sweetness and a nice amount of hop.  Amazing beer.

Myfirst introduction to the amazing coffee beer catagory.  I now have a new hobby.  Coffee Bender won the gold in the 2007 GABF and it’s understandable.  This is more of a nut-brown ale than a stout.  Smell is coffee, plain and simple, with mild nuttiness.  Mouth is light with normal carbonation.  First taste is coffee, second is coffee, third is roasted nuts.  This is phenominal and worth a drive for it.  Surly, time to can this and sell it.

On-tap at Barley John’s. The aroma is coffee-ih. Good looks, black with lots of white head. Better tasting than Town Hall’s coffee stout, average mouthfeel. Appropriate carbonation. Just too coffee, what is it about these local coffee beers?I just couldn’t take more than a couple sips. Overated.

I absolutely love this beer, when I going to drink a lot of beers in one day.  It has a terrific complexity and overall flavor.  The coffee is somehow infused in the beer; it’s not so much a flavor in the beer, but rather a part of the beer.  It sounds weird, but I love the way it marries with the other flavors,and actually makes the other flavors stand out more!  My biggest negative with this beer is the mouthfeel and appearance which really go hand in hand.  It is much too thin, much to carbonated, and lacks the characteristics I enjoy with this flavor profile.

On tap @ Map Room.  I have missed this beer so many times I finally made a special trip once I saw it back on tap on their website.  Bender is already a really great smooth brown ale, and you add all that great coffee flavor it is really amazing.  Good coffee aroma and flavor, incredibly smooth.  I have to have this again.

FINALLY!!!!!!!  On tap @ Flossmoor Station:  Fluffy and frothy head atop a nice-looking mahogany pour.  Amazing coffee nose, like a day-old coffee filter.  Flavor is a Kona-esque coffee punch in the mouth.  Finishes roasted and dry, almost with a tea-like dryness.  A must-try for the coffee lovers.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Much more unique than the regular bender.  Incredible coffee nose.  Flavor is good but I actually found the coffee flavor a bit overpowering--there was a bit of coffee ground effect.  Still, a very unique brew.

Guest draft taster at Flossmoor Station. When sampled after the roundhouse punch of Matt’s Black Pumpkin, this just whimpers and hides. A foamy head even in a taster glass. Definite origins as a brown ale, with a nicely matched proportion of lighter roast coffee. Easy and dry taste. Most coffee beers are much stronger than this one, so this is a nice diversion.

On tap, pours a deep brown with half a finger of mocha head. Nose- huge waft of coffee rinds, very fresh and medium roast, some chocolate just beautiful. Taste- fresh coffee in forefront, with nuts, caramel and light milk chocolate. freaking delicious! Mouthfell is medium bodied with carbonation on the low side to made it go down like melted butter. Hops show up in the finish to help clean away the strong coffee flavour and make you go back for more.

dark dark brown, purple highlights, thin tan head, scum of tiny tan bubbles.  aroma of coffee, malt.  sweet coffee, chocolate in the flavor.  full-bodied, bitter finish, kinda dry.  long lasting coffee bitterness, quite enjoyable.

On tap at Flossmoor Station and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a dark brown with a few ruby highlights and a huge head of tan foam that slowly settled and lasted for most of the glass.  Some decent lacing was left behind.  The aroma included roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and nuts.  The flavor consisted of cold, moderately bitter coffee, chocolate, and nuts.  Rich and malty, and the coffee blends in nicely.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and had moderate carbonation.  The coffee adds another layer of flavor to an already good beer.  Well done.

Pours nearly black with a small brown frothy head. Aroma is a bit one dimensional in that it is straight forward freshly brewed coffee, maybe with a little bit of milky creaminess. Lots of roasted malts. Flavor starts off very bitter much like black coffee. Then it gains some sweetness like some milk chocolate was added. Tiny hop presence appears towards the finish and gives some balance but the finish is mostly bitter rye malty. Medium body and lively carbonation. This is quite the bender, in fact I could swear I was drinking coffee if it was heated up. I would say it was too one sided except I love/need coffee enough that I still gave a decent rating.

Pours a deep chocolate brown with reddish highlights.  Nose is most definitely COFFEE.  Caramel/toffee/nuts/raisins/chocolate...and COFFEE.  A nit thin, but not a distraction.  Very fine brown, but the coffee should have been a little more restrained, I think.
Draught at GABF 2008. Dark brown - offwhite head. High coffee aroma and traste, malty, nutty, raisins, ryebread, dryness, dark bread. Lots of coffee - lovely.

Tap:  This poured a deep mahogany body, lightly highlighted in ruby, with a tall fizzy head.  The aroma is all about fresh coffee and little else.  It’s a bit thin, but the flavor sees the addition of dark caramel, a touch of chocolate, and some nutty bitterness.  And lots more coffee.  Not bad, but I don’t think the style can support that much coffee added to it.Flossmoor Station, Flossmoor, IL

Poured on tap at Binny’s South Loop (Chicago, IL). The second of the surprises I found awaiting me on tap at Binny’s. Poured a very hazy, opaque except around the edges, dark brown with red notes on the edges. Head is big and brown, sticking around and lacing pretty well. Aromas are coffee and grainy malt, reminiscent of the brewhouse at Flossmoor Station. The coffee dominates this brew, with the malt profile sweetness shining through in spurts and some nice touches of hops. As I have never had regular Bender, I cannot compare it as such. But I must say this was enjoyable, albeit very strong on the coffee. I really liked it, but found it a touch one-dimensional as the coffee covered up some of the intricacies of the malt profile.

Tasting this was a bonus to D-Day at the Surly Brewery, picking up six bottles of Darkness.  The coffee was intense, with just enough nutty sweetness and malt, and a stiff taste of hops in the background to make this a toe tapper.  I look forward to trying again.

This stuff is delicious, and I only wish I had it on tap in my room, so I could drink it on the way to work or class instead of plain old coffee.  The aroma is just like a straight shot of espresso.  There’s the caramel and vanilla sweetness that you get with it being Bender, but mostly it’s like a cup of coffee.  The flavor is roughly the same.  There’s a little bit of forgiveness from the coffee there, but mostly it’s just coffee.  The only real weakness is that the body is a bit disappointingly thin.  Definitely prefer this over regular Bender.

Pours a dark brown, almost black (much darker than regular Bender), with a creamy tan head. Awesome aroma of intense coffee with a  little bit of caramel sweetness and roasted malt in support. The flavor is nearly as intense, with the coffee really coming through again. A little bit of chocolate and caramel, but this beer remains pretty bitter throughout.
