The palate could be a little heavier, but is pretty smooth regardless. One of the best coffee beers out there, and possibly my favorite brown ale, if you can even call it that.

Multiple samples at GABF.  Pours a deep brown color with ruby highlights in the light and a beige head that receded to a ring.  Aroma consists of strong roasted coffee with some hints of caramel, chocolate, and a light nuttiness. Nice roasted coffee entry with some chocolate maltiness  gives way to sweet caramel flavor with nice oat smoothness that finishes with a light hoppiness to even things out.  Smooth and full on the palate.  Decent, but I think I may actually prefer regular Bender.
GABF 08.  This really didn’t improve Bender from what I remember.  I would like to see this down a bit bigger, b/c as is, the flavor nuances don’t really do much in their small fashion.
Draught. High creamy and lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Funny coffee caramel aroma and flavor with a fair amount of hops bitterness.low carbonation and a long bitter aftertaste.

Draught at GABF 2008.
Clear orange brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet aroma of coffee and caramel.
Sweet flavour of coffee, caramel and hops.
Roasted and hoppy finish.

Objectively speaking:
A heavily hopped and easily drinkable brown ale where the coffee just extends its roasty arm. 

I like:
Its deep brown shade fitted the Delilahs bar where I had it. Malty but not thick. Well roasted nutty ale. The coffee ends up feeling perhaps a bit beany, but its generally well-blended. The roast and hops mixture offers a fair bit of acidity, but not in excess.

I dislike:
The small white head quickly departs from the clear light amber pour. A certain huskiness coats the palate. I quickly grew tired of my pint, which should not happen with a lager.

On draft @ MacKenzie’s. Very dark brown in colour with medium carbonation. Huge coffee with cream aroma, with a bit of caramel. Coffee dominant in the mouth, but notes of caramel, vanilla, milk chocolate, and munich-ish malts start to poke through. Medium bodied, with a very smooth mouthfeel. Seemed more like a coffee porter to me, but very tasty nonetheless.

On tap at the Happy Gnome in Saint Paul, Mn.  Perfect coffee infused taste.  Aroma of espresso coffee and dark chocolate.  Medium  bodied.  Very similar to the java stout from Bell’s but a little stronger on the coffee side.  Well balanced hops and malts.  I prefer this over the regular bender.

On tap at the Maproom Chicago.  I’m glad I got to grab this one this time around.  A pint for five bucks is a good deal with this brown ale.  Pours a medium brown with a tan head that fades as I drink this down.  Roasty nose.  Coffee, chocolate, nuts, and earthy hops in the aroma.  Medium body with adequate carobonation.  The roast/coffee comes on strong and leads to the nutty, chocolate, and earthy hops.  The flavors don’t carry the punch of the initial roast but the earthy roasty bitterness lingers after those other flavors are gone.  Solid coffee beer that wasn’t all about the coffee but used it well.

On tap at Jerrys. Dark mahogany with big, foamy brown head / Rich semi-sweet chocolate & roast coffee nose / Medium body, acidic, with balanced malts & hops, and with good finish / Flavors of roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and oak / A coffee porter.

Pours brown with a tan head. Aroma is very earthy. There are hints of malt, nuts, and straw as well as the overpowering aroma of coffee. Taste was mainly of coffee at first. After the coffee taste settles in, the malty and nutty flavors lingered on. The more you drink, the more the coffee is subdued for the taste of chocolate and roasted malts. Too much coffee for my liking.

GTMW 2008: Brown hue with reddish highlights. The aroma is coffee (duh), roasted and chocolate malts, walnut, some herbal hops and an earthy yeast ester. The taste is sweet malt and walnut with a straight forward coffee character. A hint of fig and juniper like flavors as well. The mouth feel has the problem many coffee beers do, thinner than it should be. Despite the weak mouth feel, I still liked this beer quite a lot.
OBF 2008. Beautiful coffee/sweet roasted malt aroma. The coffee taste is done just right, and I love it. Give me more.

GTMW 08. Poured a clear dark orange-brown color. The head was light tan with an almost orange-ish tint. The aroma was subdued coffee. Light to medium bodied with coffee and chocolate notes. Good, but didnt bowl me over. I preferred the regular Bender.

Sampled at Surly in Brooklyn Center.  Another good brew from Surly. Pour is a dark brown . The nose is highly roasted coffee. Comes across the palate with strong notes of coffee with a hint of chocolate on the finish. I don’t much care for coffee, I loved it, & I couldn’t get enough of it.

At Oregon Brewers Festival 2008 Pours out a dark brown topped with a tan head. Holly coffee batman. Aroma was very nice. Tast more of the coffee and some sweetness from chocolate. A very tasty brew. I think they should have called with one Coffee Blender.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 A major improvement over the regular Bender.  Nice, sweet aroma with coffee and hints of roasted malts.  Appearance is dark brown with a dark tan head that fades quickly.  Flavor is well balanced that is predominately coffee and hints of chocolate, malts and hops.  Very smooth with a balanced finish (not bitter, not dry, not sweet).  Impressed because I wasnt expecting much since I was disappointed by the regular.

Sampled at Oregon Brewers Festival 2008--Dark brown-black body.  Bubbly, somewhat thin though opaque with an almost nonexistant head.  Nose of straight up espresso.  Super coffee!  Thin mouthfeel.  Little flavor outside of coffee.  A little bitterness and acidity, but it is hard to say if it is due to hops or java. Not my bag.
OBF 08 Its beer, its coffee, its a coffee beer that really really smells and tastes like coffee. How much do I love this? Alot. Beer is now a morning drink.

Another good brew from Surly.  Pour was very dark brown with the aroma of highly roasted coffee.  Flavor was very coffee-ee with a hint of cocoa towards the finish.  Again, very high roast which disguised the hops very well.  Must like coffee to like this brew.  Luckily I do so I’ll buy it again.

On tap OBF 2008. Tastes like coffee, yep, bitter, earthy, fresh and aromatic. Pours dark brown with a smooth khaki head. The palate is broken up from the carbonation, seeming to amplify the bitterness and roastiness.
delicious caramel aroma with a big white head. super smooth with lots of roasty malts and just a hint of hops in the finish...fantastic.

Draft at MacKenzie’s.  Pours a dark brown body with thin, light brown head.  Aroma of earthy coffee turning to hints of mocha.  Flavor is mostly coffee with some hints of pipe tobacco and cocoa.  Smooth mouthfeel with a slight wateryness near the back of the palate near the finish.  Bitter roasted coffee aftertaste.  I really couldn’t pick out any aromas or flavors of regular Bender, as this brew is dominated by coffee.

Tap at Kuma’s. I’m convinced this what was served, as I’ve had Bender numerous times and it’s always more hoppy and less roasty. The nose was rich and chocolatey, roasty and coffee. Darker head that usually. Taste is bold and thick, plenty of bitterness, both from coffee and hops. Rich mouthfeel and roasty/sweet. Nice one!

Poured out black with a nice head that retained well. Smell was of old coffee, maybe a little cream to the nose as well; wasnt good. Taste was full of old and not enjoyable coffee. Mouthfeel was medium bodied and medium carbonation levels. Drinkability is not good. I didnt even finish my first glass of it. Surly makes good beer, but this was disappointing. Give me the regular Bender.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 Draft at EBF and it was one of the few that i went back for seconds and 1 of 3 that i went back for 3rds.  With beers like darkness, darklord, bourbon angel share, red poppy, both BA old stocks!  Wow that says something IMO.  Dunno what to say about this other then mother of god this is incredible!!  WOW, this is the Best coffee flavored beer ive ever had.  I feel like im drinking a cup of perfectly brewed joe without all the roastiness that i could do without in a coffee stout.  This well "brewed" beer is dominated by coffee i dont taste bender but if i could have this instead id never have it again.  This is amazing!  4.8
After having this just recently i must pretty much agree with my rating.  The Aroma is perfect, the flavor is more or less perfect, the only downfall i can really find is that the beer is a bit thin on my palate but thats more or less it.  Awesome! 4.6

Draught, CBCChestnut, cloudy.  Gorgeous, complex chocolatey, earthy coffee nose is probably the best coffee beer nose Ive come across, at least in a long while.  Smooth, complex coffee, lightly balanced.  Good backing sweetness.  Stellar example.

Wow this is a coffe bomb. The second I recieved my glass I was blown away by the coffee aromas. Coffee dominates the whole experience, which is fine by me. Body is nice and creamy and carries the coffee flavors well. This is a very tasty treat if your into coffee.

[tap] Poured a dark brown with a medium off white head. Aroma of coffee right in the front, with malt lingering. Very little hops on the nose. Flavor is quite balanced and the mouthfeel is not thin like many other coffee beers Ive had. Finishes a little dry with some bitterness from the coffee. Very tasty.

Happy Gnome Surly dinner: pours brandy tinted mahogany brown with thick, wispy, burnt yellow foam piling on the surface.  Aroma is pure coffee ice cream with an irish cream base; shades of creamy chocolate, cinnamon, and irish whiskey, with scant suggestions of acridity throughout.  Coffee integrated freshly, sweetly, and smoothly.  Flavor is a dense roasty sweetness; earthy, compact, rustic, never astringent.  Roasted hazelnuts.  Grounds.  More a cold fresh espresso taste than a juicy, vibrant light roast; sweet, smoky, and lightly tart.  Palate is somewhat thin and only mildly abrasive with bitterness; warm, spicy finish offering a lingering, tense vanilla sweetness soaking the mouth long after.  High quality unmistakeable; a refreshing example.

tap at the maproom....surly two blew out and this was its replacement.  no complaints there.... an opaque dark brown pour with reddish brown edges that was topped off with a light brown head that accumulated around the glass rim.... the aroma was pretty one dimensional and consisted of fresh coffee beans.... flavor threw me off a bit with its lactic sourness that was a little misplaced.  outside of that, it was really smooth and had a nice creamy mouthfeel.  the bender aspect of the brew was lost but it was still decently tasty overall.

Tap @ Maproom too! Straight up iced coffee... Aroma of coffee beans... Taste is of coffe brown ale something something. Not a beer I would have again. This was diffrent and nice to have tried but thats about it.

Another Maproom review.  This hits hard with the coffee, its really the only flavor going on.  Iced coffee is exactly what it tastes like.  Its an incredibly strong taste, but im not sure if its a good thing.  Cool for a taste, but there is no way I could drink this regularly.

on tap at the maproom in chicago.  Beer has an excellent coffee aroma but that is the extent of enjoyment on this beer.  Was not very complex and the coffee flavor did not mix well with the beer.  I was not very impressed with this brew, it tasted more like iced coffee than beer.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 on tap at the map room. pours hazy reddish brown with creamy off white head. nose is loaded with a soft espresso and hazelnut. flavor notes of chocolate, coffee, and nuts but extremely smooth and manages to not take on bitter or harsh ashy notes from the coffee. although the coffee tends to dominate.

On tap at Map Room, Chicago.  IMHO-- way over-rated.  Tastes like someone sprinkled coffedd grounds into my blass of brown ale.  Almost tastes like an ice coffee.  The body of the brown ale just isnt big enough to allow the coffee flavor to blend.  Instead, the coffee sticks ou like a sore thumb.  Nice try-- nto thumbs down on this one form Surly.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2009 On tap at the 2007 GTMW: Aroma and taste are reminiscent of coffee with a whipped cream topping along with some roasted barley. Very strong coffee in the aroma & flavor, but it was still pretty tasty.  
16oz can, served in an English pint.Good coffee dominates the aroma and flavor, but the underlying beer has enough malty and hoppy (floral/citrus) aromas and flavors to make a very nice base beer and the rich, smooth mouthfeel stands up to the coffee. Bumped a point overall.

Nice light tan head that dissolves slowly to a fine film and roamy ring. Aroma has immediate morning roasted coffee, roasted malt and a touch of flowery sweet hops. Taste has coffee character, smooth, and slight sweet bitterness to sides of tongue. Finish has a malty and slight berry after taste. Excellent balance of a dark brown ale and coffee character.

From the brewery tap. Very dark brown/red color, with a slight wheat color head. A very nice coffee aroma suprisingly comes thru quite a bit along with a sweet malty tinge. The flavor swims between ale spice and the almost oily dark coffee (in a good way). A rich and smooth mouth feel will keep you wanting more. Hit the brewery tour, the samples are good stuff

2008 Debut release at Common Roots Cafe, Minneapolis. Coffee ground in the nose. Most coffee-smelling beer Ive ever had I believe. Not much head or lace. Could be the  lack of attention to proper beer glass detergent from a coffee-centric establishment. Murky dark red body. Tastes a bit like flavored iced coffee with alcohol. Not sure how my thirstyness from working out just prior is playing into my enjoyment of this brew, but I cant have enough of it. Softly carbonated which is compensated for by  the tartness from the coffee grounds. The best coffee beer I can remember having.

tap at the brewery with hazy notes from drinking at 10 in the morning after being up for well over a day.  Brown with a nice sized tan head.  Very big coffee aroma,  roasted malts,  more coffee.  Flavor is huge with coffee as well,  but has a nice chocolate matly backbone as well.  Finished creamy.  Exactly what I hope for when I pick up a coffee beer,  but I think it could have  been more complex.  Still a great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009 (on tap at the brewery) Poured brown with tan head.  Nice strong aroma of roasted coffee and roasted malt, not much else, but this smell alone is wonderful.  Nice taste of dark roasted coffee with a really nice long lasting roasted finish.  Im a big fan of coffee and this was spot on with both the aroma and taste. After trying this several times, I have found that there is little to no complexity displayed in this beer.  I have also realized after drinking better coffee more often, that this beer is nowhere close to tasting like a quality coffee, and its chock full of charred flavors.  Theres a bit of chocolate and some walnut, but thats about it.   After another can, I have found the aroma to be quite insufferable, and it smells a lot like a slough on a late September morning.  Not even close to good coffee.

An aroma you would be with with from a cup of Starbucks,one of the most pleasing coffee aromas I have had yet from a Coffee ale. That s the aroma,roasted coffee,taste is roasted malt and cold coffeee mix,just a little thinner then you would expect,but the roasted flavor is wonderful with no real bitterness in aftertste. Another one that should be bottled or canned

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 12/16/07. On tap at brewery. Very strong coffee aroma, also very light hops presence. Similar malt aroma as the bender hiding in there as well. Taste is strong coffee as well. Im not a coffee connoisseur so I wont elaborate on that, but it seemed to be very good quality. Bitterness in finish appears to come mostly from the coffee, and is quite nice.  Seriously, you could carry this around with you and anyone that smelled it would probably just think it was coffee. 8/3/8/4/15-3.8

10/25/08. Very roasty. Great coffee finish-dry. 8/4/8/4/16-4.0

On tap at the brewery. Dark brown color, some haze, minimal head. Fresh roasted coffee nose, sweet nutty malts, nice hop presence at the end to clean it up. Smooth. Tasted this at 10:30 in the morning, and it worked really well for such an early morning libation. Seems that quality beans were used for this, making for a good, smooth, not overly acidic coffee beer. Thanks to Omar at Surly for breaking out the good taps for Darkness Day 12-15-07!

Dark brown color, minimal head. The head that is there is a deep tan. Aroma of coffee grounds and nutty smell. Sweet nutty malts. Flavor is of chocolate covered coffee beans. Light body. Flavor fills your mouth. Well choice in coffee to use for this. The guatemalan beans are a good choice for this style of beer, as the bitterness is balanced and there isnt much smokiness to this bean. It is  a well-balanced bean and makes for an incredibly well-balanced coffee bender.

Draft @ Brewery. Black pour with a tan head. Aroma of coffee...and lots of it coupled with some roasted malt and dark chocolate. Flavors of roasted coffee beans, dark chocolate, light caramel malt and a tinge of smoke. Medium body with a soft carbonation, roasty/bitter/nutty with a roasty/nutty/bittersweet finish.

Growler shared by kp at the RBSG grand tasting on 6/23/07: Pours a barely transparent dark mahogany with a spotty-lacing light tan head.  Nice fresh roasty espresso coffee aroma has some sweet caramel and dark chocolate notes.  Body starts fairly full with nice sweet dark caramel and chocolate flavor and lots of big espresso bean balance.  Finishes with lingering dark chocolate and light sweetness.  A very nice coffee beer.
Draft @ Brewery: Dark brown, nice head and lacing. Nose of coffee; dark nice coffee. The flavor is like coffee, balanced sweetness and coffee, all coffee. Nice coffee though. Not too dry.

GTMW 07- Pitch black color, small off white head. Nose is pure coffee, fresh roasted coffee. Flavor is more coffee, and it really contributes a majority of the bitterness, finish is similar to coffee with the mouthfeel quite nice.

Draft at GTMW.  Pours a a cloudy brown with a thin tan head.  The aroma is all coffee, rather pleasant.  The flavor unfortunatly is all coffee as well.  I say unfortunatly because I was not impressed with the coffee flavor in this brew at all.  It tasted more like Folgers than a good locally roasted coffee.  This beer was a huge dissapointment for me.

Some beers are better left alone to be enjoyed as the brewer created them. Some beers become awesome when tons of coffee is dumped into them! The body is murky and dark brown with soft burgundy hues. A mid-sized tan head is very well retained, still present as the last sip dissapears. The aroma is just screaming with fresh coffee. Lesser notes of caramel malt, brown sugar, nuts, fruits(grapefruit, orange) and cocoa. The flavor is so lovable! The coffee and hops create a formidable bitterness that fortunately only releases a very mild acidity and a mild astringency. Sweetness is medium-high, never cumbersome or remotely cloying. The finish is loaded with coffee, grain and cocoa, of lengthy duration, semi-sweet and heavily bitter. Medium-bodied, highly though pleasantly carbonated, decently smooth. Though the mouthfeel was nothing memorable, the flavor kept me coming back for more the entire afternoon I spent at Surly. Great concoction.

On tap at the GTMW.
Poured hazy brown with a frothy tan head of foam.  The coffee character really does dominate the flavor and aroma here.  I cant really say that much of the original beer is left.  On the other hand.  It was the best iced coffee Ive ever had.  I mean for real.  Id drink this stuff every morning if give the chance.

On tap at GTMW.  Poured deep iced tea brown with a rich, creamy beige head.. just lovely!  The cold toddy really stood out in the aroma.. a nice coffee in there, but it went a bit too far in masking the chewy, nutty goodness beneath.. some nutty notes and cocoa did peek through, but the coffee stole the show.  The flavor was not unlike a fine iced coffee.. some drier chocolates and caramel came through on the middle, and the finish reverted back to the coffee.. the long bitter coffee finish was a bit too drawn out for my liking.  Medium-bodied and a bit too heavily skewed toward the coffee flavors and bitterness.  Solid brew overall, but a bit too focused on the coffee addition.
GTMW.  Dark caramel color.  Smell of malt, coffee, nuts, minor chocolate and hops.  Taste of malt, caramel, hops, chocolate and roasted coffee that has a waterdown taste.  Still nice.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2009 Draft at the Great Taste of the Midwest. pleasant aroma of cold press and roasted sweet malt. Not as coffee dominated as some other coffee beers Ive had lately. Good balance of coffee and malt on the palate. One of the better coffee beers Ive had, if only because the coffee was a tad restrained. 

 Can... ya know... it really doesnt do it for me. Not a whole lot of brown ale characteristics... just a lot of cold press coffee. Meh...

RBSG 07 tour of Surly. A jet black pour with a gooy light an head. A huge aroma of espresso dominates the nose. It reminds me of  a pot of coffee that has cooked down to almost burned. Coffee dominates th flavor as well. A bitter on the finish is smooth as well, not harsh at all. Palate is smooth but just a tad thin, carbonation is good as well. All over good. Aroma is awesome and the coffee flavor is pleasant as well.

Bender ok, coffee Bender Fuckin awesome. Ive never had a beer that was so different than the original by just adding another flavor. The quality of the coffee was superb. The rich, espresso flavor, massive. Nice use of chocolate but use better chocolate and youll have a really nice Bender.

Draft at the Surly brewery, RBSG 2007. Garnet with a tan head. Nose is fresh ground coffee beans. At first, it obscures the malt, but the malt fights its way through as it warms a bit, melding well in the nose and flavor. Soft bittersweet coffee and chocolate finish, tinged with earthy hop. This beer is all about the coffee, and it does it very well!

Sampled at the last Surly open house/RBSG Surly tour.  Pours a nice dark brown with a gorgeous dark brown/tan head.  Very nice dark roast and chocolate on the nose with very little hops.  Flavor is dominatingly coffee and chocolate, and easily fits into my top 5 coffee beers.  A great under-rated Surly offering.

text: (Draft)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee.

Draft... RBSG 07... Hazy, dark ale (burnt orange when held up to the sun) with a small, creamy, lightly tanned head. Good retention. Smells like coffee and Simcoe® (cat piss) hops. RBSG 2007 Tour at Surly  Deep Brown, creamy white head.  Nose was full on ground coffee with underlying piney floral notes.  Toasted coffee flavors dominate, but are lightly backed with a nice hop presence.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, soft bittersweet finish.  Nice surprise here for the coffee lover in me...

The nose:  all coffee--if I were blindfolded, I think I wouldnt nose if it were beer or coffee.  Like snorting coffee grounds.  Color: brown, clear, lighter than average.  The flavor:  all coffee.  Relentlessly coffee.  Slightly bitter finish.  This is more thoroughly "coffee" than any coffee beer Ive ever had.  Well done.

(draft) Tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, fresh roast coffee, light earthy.  Taste is medium sweet, coffee, Coffee, COFFEE.  Medium body, light oiliness.  Id like it much better if I genuinely liked coffee.  As it is, its the most coffee-like beer Ive ever had.
On tap at the brewery: Pours black with a tan head. Aroma, lots of coffee, roasted malts, some bitter chocolaty notes. Flavor, earthy roasted coffee, with a dry bitterness. This stuff is good.

Sample from tap at the brewery. Pours dark brown to black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Flavour is coffee with malts kicking in a bit later. Long bitter finish. Adding 1 overall due to the coffee compared to the regular bender, I really enjoy that.
Yikes a great coffee--too much coffee.  Needed the caffine to work for me and needs cream and suger.  Somewhat oiley with litte lacing.  Should be called an expresso.

On tap at the RBSG 2007 Surly Tour. Slightly hazy dark cherry black body with a small creamy light brown head. Sweet coffe and roasted malt aroma. Sweet coffe, roasted malt flavor with a hint of chocolate.

RBSG 2007.  For a coffee beer, this was spectacular.  The nose and body had an excellent coffee taste with none of the horrid bitterness I associate with coffee beers.  Dark brown color with faint head.

RBSG 2007.  Pours to a dark brown/mahogany body with a light tan head.  The aroma is marvelous with tons of chocolate covered espresso beans.  Holy crap!  The aroma is great. RBSG 2007.  Doled out for the Surly tour.  Black color with no head.  Monster coffee aroma that borders on being the same as sticking your head in a can of Folgers and taking a deep breath. Can, thanks to footbalm. Pours dark vrown, with a tan head. Aromas are roasted malt and coffee. Flavors are coffee, roasted malt, and some hops. Not bad, not great.

Sampled draught at the Autumn Brew Review in Minneapolis, October 7 2006.   Damn theres a huge split on this one!  My thoughts:  dark brown/black, translucent with a huge lasting dark tan head and lots of thick lace.....insane, I mean insane dark, roasty coffee nose, easily the most intensely java-spiked aroma I have experienced, at first there is nothing else evident but fresh bitter beans, but slowly hints of caramel cream and burnt grains show up with some faint pungent hops....much less impressive on the tongue though Id have been surprised if it hadnt been, that particular kind of intensity works best aromatically I think....sweet, but thin milky coffee taste with lots of burnt grounds and a hint of orange acid and sugar....rather too watery at the finish to really hold together, this is nonetheless a fascinating, near-great experiment that needs better balance and more body but is worth experiencing for coffee-lovers just for that amazing nose.

ABR. Very dissappointing as it was like a glass of iced coffee was allowed to melt down and they served us the watery remains. Nose was all coffee and it did taste a bit like coffee but it stops there. Pretty letdown by this after I had had the Darkness offering prior.

If you like coffee a lot, you will probably like this one.  It has a very strong coffee aroma and flavor. It is really watery though without enough malt and hop character to balance the coffee.  There pours were way overly foamy, so I will give this one another chance.

Solid ebon color, browish at bottom, with a beautifully hued head, a deep cocoa tan looking for all the world like a shot of espresso, with a generous dollop of froth.

Aromas where its at, wide open and long-lastin, rich with coffee, with a hint of cream. 
Herbal, nutty, chocolatey, brimming with coffee essence. A treat to drink in with the nose.

But now lets let the lips and tongue go to work. More delights. The coffee has overpowered the subtler parts of Benders character, but theres no sorrow in this, as the coffee flavor that controls it now is an exceptional playmate for the palate. Really sticks to the tongue and lays long in the finish.

Medium to full body, long, coffee-tinged finish, unflinchingly flavorful, and still an easy treat to drink down. This has met with near unanimous praise among those Ive witness enjoy it, and I can only hope its attempted again and again, so that more may discover this jolt of joy for java freaks, and beer geeks alike.
